description:
Long overdue review.
El Castillito is an institution. 
Open late so great place to grab a bite after a show.
*You order in Spanish
*Enormous burritos (size of a small baby so lunch&dinner)
*They have veggie options
*Friendly service
*They melt the cheese on the tortilla
*Delicious Al Pastor
*Free chips and salsa
*Happy hour $6 dollar burritos
*Giant TV to watch sports while you eat a million calories
*Seating by the window so you can watch junkies and techies
*Super fast and they make it in front of you

DON'T FORGET YOUR CASH (but they have an ATM, smarty pants...)

Goodness
author: Monkey B.

description:
This place has tanked in such a short amount of time. Truly sad. This was one of THE best taquerias in the city for a while.

The good line cooks are long gone, left with the most unfriendly, stingy men on the front lines. The dude who looks like Mario from Mario Bros. is a dick, plain and simple. He treats almost everyone disrespectfully like you're inconveniencing him by placing an order. It's not even to me, I watch him act this way to everyone. 

Even with this, I continued patronizing the restaurant, meanwhile the size of the burritos dwindling by the week it seemed. Not only that, but the quality dropped. Things weren't as fresh, their health score started plummeting. 

What is up with the short haired cashier woman who always tries to upsell you like you've ordered a super when you didn't? I see her do this to every single person and most people don't actually understand her and nod yes and end up paying $12.00 for a burrito that should only be about $9.00 and only costed $6.00 18 months ago. I don't get how the price goes up and the quality goes down, or how this woman could go to sleep at night knowing she's a conniving piece of trash.

In the last two weeks I found a penny in my nachos (they smiled and offered to remake the nachos) and got food poisoning in two separate trips. I've never had food poisoning. I didn't know what it meant to have it come out both sides until my last experience here. I also noticed they are no longer posting their health score. For the first time ever, it was missing, coincidentally my last visit.

Let me just end by saying they've lost ANOTHER loyal neighborhood customer.
author: William L.

description:
I'm glad to have found El Castillito! Although I can't say this is my favorite burrito in SF (I'm looking at you, El Farolito!), it's a very solid option for Mission-style burritos in the Castro/Duboce Triangle area. 

For one, the portion sizes are enormous (I've never been able to finish a burrito in one sitting and I'm not a light eater) and the prices are quite reasonable for food and drinks (beers and sodas are both very cheap!). Your burrito is also assembled in front of you and they ask for your input along the way, to make sure they only include what you want. As a person who hates sour cream, for example (I know! Blasphemy!), knowing I can omit it easily here is a game changer - I can actually enjoy a super burrito! I've only tried the chicken as far as meats go, which is always tender and flavorful. 

The ambience is super low frills with limited seating, but it works. The line can be long at times, but I've never had to wait too long to eat or had trouble finding a place to sit. The servers are pleasant and help you catch on to the "rules" of how to order if you aren't familiar, which is appreciated. They offer free chips and a salsa bar with some good options. 

Cash only so make sure you stop at an ATM first!
author: Christine G.

description:
Feels like a joint right out of the Mission, but conveniently located in the Castro.  Got that hole-in-the-wall authentic feel.  The big mound of al pastor looked amazing, but was a tad disappointing.  Everything else was fine though, hence the A-OK (i.e. 3-stars).

Quesadilla Suizas w/ Al Pastor: Well this isn't the type of half moon shaped quesadilla you'd get at a chain restaurant.  It's burrito shaped, but filled with just meat, cheese and sauce.  None of that unnecessary rice or beans or vegetables.  And there's a ton of cheese, I saw them cover the whole tortilla surface area with slices.  I was really looking forward to the al pastor, because I saw the huge spit of pork roasting in the kitchen.  Unfortunately, my al pastor wasn't sliced off fresh but rather came from a pre-chopped bin.  It got reheated on the griddle.  None of it was particularly crispy unfortunately.  Also, tasted a bit gristly like it was cooked too fast instead of slowly turning on that spit all day.  I liked the general format of the quesadilla, but perhaps another meat choice would have been better.

Cantaloupe Agua Fresco: This was huge!  Almost like Big Gulp territory.  There was a lot of sugar water, but still enough cantaloupe to be legit.  Very refreshing.
author: Adam B.

description:
El Castillo was conveniently across the street from the grocery store where we were shopping, so we stopped in for a quick lunch. I ordered street tacos and my husband had a burrito. It was clean and the staff was friendly to us. The food was average, but I would go back if I was in the area. 

The price was also pretty average for San Fran. We paid about $20 for the two of us, which I thought was a little high for what it was. I didn't order a meal, I just had two of the regular tacos and my husband had a specialty burrito.
author: Hillary S.

description:
I went here recently meeting a friend for veggie burritos. I got the regular veggie burrito. To customize it vegan simply omit the cheese as it doesn't come w/ sour cream. I added avocado.

My friend went w/ the supper veggie burrito which comes w/ sour cream, cheese, & guacamole.

My friend said they used to offer more veggies in the burrito including zucchini etc yet they no longer do.

The cook asked if I would like it spicy & said sure. I got it w/ black beans, rice, avocado, spicy salsa, & lettuce. It came w/ a side of corn chips.

There was a salsa bar as well. I didn't find my customized vegan veggie burrito spicy at all yet I had a roasted pepper perhaps jalapeño or even habanero on the salsa bar that was ridiculously spicy.

Normally in the Mission I can handle the roasted jalapeño on the salsa bar yet this was the spiciest I ever had as seemed like it was marinated in ghost pepper oil. 

Besides the overly spicy roasted pepper I found the burrito to be quite alright especially for the Castro as won't compare it to the burritos in the Mission. I wouldn't hesitate to return here yet will proceed w/ caution w/ the roasted chili peppers.
author: Shane S.

description: My favorite burrito spot in the Bay Area. I love the meat burrito and the way sour cream and guacamole mix into a delicious sauce to compliment the meat.
author: alex w.

description: Al pastor Quesadilla castilla - a massive suiza that was basically a burrito. It was bomb! When watching them assemble the suiza, I wasn't sure if I'd like it cause the jalapenos were the picked ones and i assumed it would be grilled or roasted. It was surprisingly really good and I would totally order it again
author: Genica R.

description:
CASH ONLY!!
Big disappointment not only did the prices go way up there is only minor improvements. New menu more seating. Still the same hole in the wall spot  mediocre Mexican.
author: nancy w.

description:
This is one of the better burritos in the city. 

Super fast and predictable quality almost every time. It's also usually not a biohazard waste zone like some other burrito establishments.

There is plenty of parking if your not a total and complete moron. I'm not suggesting you park at Safeway, (or use the bathroom there to wash your grubby hands before you eat) I'm just pointing out a fact that parking is easy.

The only real downside for me is the burritos are too damn big. I get it, the mission burrito is a beast but the gut busters coming out of here are enormous. I usually get 'em to go so I can walk around the hood burning off ten of the 15,000 calorie monsters I consume on a regular basis.

Get the Carnitas Burrito. It's one of the best I've had in the region. I don't know anything about how they prepare their meat but however it's done it's spot on. Almost as importantly the ingredients are fresh and measured perfectly. The faster they make these suckers the more on point they are. 

It's a trip!

There is usually ralways a wait and I'd argue this place is better when it's very busy. 

Something clicks back there and it magical.

Cash ONLY!! but there is a scary ATM that is likely running very old software.
author: Justin S.

description: Amazing burritos which can potentially fill two people, their portion size is huge. Great place for a quick bite. This is cash only place.
author: Soumen B.

description:
Five stars for the outstanding super burrito al pastor! Three stars for the side of guacamole - it lacked flavor and seasoning. 

Stick to the burritos at this hole-in-the-wall Mexican joint. For about $10 you will get a perfectly filled and perfectly wrapped burrito the size of your forearm filled with rice and beans (choice of black, pinto or refried), choice of meat, guacamole, sour cream, and salsa (I might be forgetting things - there was so much packed in). Two of us shared one cause it was that huge but all the power to you if you can crush one on your own!!
author: Sol C.

description: Carne asada super burrito with a small melon agua Fresca hit the spot! When El Farolito is just too far and you need a quick legit fix - go here. Just the right amount of salt and spice. The chips are fresh and salsa is homemade. Looking for a good picnic spot? Walk about 0.6 miles to Painted Ladies at Alamo Square to enjoy your food - it's worth the walk and you won't feel as guilty if you finish your entire SUPER burrito.
author: Jess C.

description:
Wow this is a hidden gem outside of the mission, but cash only!

I went with a friend on a Friday night and there was a line with 5 people in front of us. You walk up to the open glass kitchen window to order then pay on your way out.

After I decided on what I wanted, I started watching the burrito masters in the kitchen shove mounds of rice, meat, and toppings into these huge flour tortillas and each burrito wrap was executed with impeccable skill. I mean these burritos are almost the size of a nalgene water bottle. 

Order one and weigh it before you eat it. It's close to 2 pounds.
author: Jasper L.

description:
Ordered a zapata burrito with carnitas and was not disappointed. 

Granted price point was a little higher than normal ($9.73 after tax) but the burrito was the size of my forearm and definitely weighed of a newborn infant.The burrito was juicy and packed with all the goods. It did get a little too liquidy towards the bottom but that's to be expected with all the saucey ingredients.

My only gripe was with the cook. He seemed to not understand anything I was saying. Luckily I had a friend who translated everything for me.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
El Castillito is a fantastic place to come to for a quick meal when you are on the go.  I usually get their burritos.  Order any of them and you can't go wrong.  The burritos come with a bag of tortilla chips.  The cooks are comedians.   They're always cracking jokes with the customers.  

After you order and pay, head over to the self served salsa bar to top off your meal.

Cash only so make sure you stop by the atm before coming.
author: Peter C.

description:
Meat is super tender, flavorful and packed but depending on which one you get really changes the profile

My friends Al Pastor was far superior to the carne asada 

Overall Thoughts

Decent burrito spot but doesn't crack my top 5 in the city
author: Eddie W.

description: This place is easily a solid four stars. I ordered a super burrito half Carnitas and the other half Carne Asada. The thing was absolutely gargantuan. I haven't seen a super burrito like that in years. It seems like in San Francisco the super burritos keep shrinking and getting more expensive all at the same time. For $9.95 you get a huge burrito that I could not even come close to finishing. And it tasted pretty darn good. I can't say it was the best burrito I've had in my life - but I have to say this place is a tremendous value for what it offers. This establishment is a keeper. In the words of our former California governor-I'll be back.
author: Robert C.

description:
if I'm being challenged and only given one chance, one food (that is non Michelin rated food) to make anybody happy.
I know what I'm gonna do.
I would bring them a Quesadilla Suiza from El Castillito.
case closed, I will win.
their Quesadilla Suiza is really something special.
author: Rudy H.

description: I love this taqueria! The staff is always so friendly ! The agua frescas are really good and their tacos are one of my personal favorites in the city. Simply amazing!
author: Ruby S.

description:
I am a lactose intolerant vegetarian so Mexican food does not always have options for me to dine. Luckily, El Castillito has a vegetarian burrito (which my boyfriend had) and vegetarian tacos (which is what I had). I asked for no sour cream or cheese so then the cook asked if I wanted a veggie mix consisting of mushrooms, zucchini, carrots, peppers and onions. I added that to guacamole, black beans, tomatoes and rice on a soft tortilla. 

IT WAS DELICIOUS - And the customer service was great, the staff were friendly and kind. Will come back to El Castillito again!
author: Amanda H.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmm
Al pastor burrito with guacamole all day. Get the green salsa & green tortilla.
Cash only.
author: Kylie F.

description:
Fantastic "basic" place for a quick takeout!

This is one of those smaller Mexican joints which feel a bit like home food, nothing too fancy but consistently good.

I ordered the super vegetarian burrito and veggies tacos on two different occasions. They we're both very good. As you place your order, you can tell them what you'd like and what you wouldn't. You can also choose between three types of beans and make it spicy if you'd like.

The veggie taco was very memorable with lot of cheese, beans, salsa and what not. Two tacos is a pretty solid portion. The burrito was mostly brilliant except he missed the red sauce which I was sad about - partly my fault that I didn't notice.

I was going to say I'd definitely go there again but I already did, so.
author: Vignesh B.

description: Found this little hole in the wall Mexican restaurant. This is authentic Mexican. The people here are so nice and the price is right and they give so much food. They have a happy hour from 3 to 5  for $6.99.....And yes they have vegetarian.
author: Penny P.

description:
Got a regular shrimp burrito. Dry refried beans. Dry ass rice. Salsa that was suppose to be spicy but was bland.

Lots of shrimp but they had zero flavor. Cooked with basically salt and nothing else. 

Unmemorable. One star due to being open late. Would not return
author: Atif J.

description:
A few blocks away is this great Taqueria on the J line across the street from the Safeway. Tonight we ordered two quesadillas, one chicken and one pork. Te quesadillas were both as thick as a burrito. It also came with chips and salsa
 or guacamole. Talk about getting a value. The meat on both were so flavorful and delicious. After I was done, I wished I had remembered to take a picture. I may update this with pics the next time I return. Sorry, but after taking a bite, I had to continue eating. I'm so happy that this is the neighborhood. For the sake of my waistline I will have to make sure I temper this treat to once (maybe twice) a month.
author: Matthew R.

description:
After going here regularly for a year (maybe every couple weeks) I can say the best things to get are the tacos. If you are super hungry or want leftovers, you can go for a burrito but I recommend getting 2 or 3 tacos otherwise. They load the tortillas with meat to maximum capacity. Carnitas and al pastor are a must. 

It's cash only. Don't step into the line if you don't know what you want.
author: Huey N.

description:
Best. Burritos. Ever.

This is the BEST burrito place I've EVER experienced. I've lived in Texas, California, traveled a lot in Mexico and nowhere else comes even close. 

El Castillito has the gestält of burrito making down cold. And they're wonderful too. Highly recommended.
author: Jack D.

description: Living in SF all my life, i have been to a lot of Taqueria places and this is far the worst i have been. I ordered the all meat burrito and i get a lousy portion of meat. They give you about 25% meat. I thought it will be at least 50% given its name "all meat burrito. I paid $10 for this sorry ass burrito. I'm better off going to El Farolito even if there's a crazy line up. Being a native San Franciscan, try another Taqueria other than this place.
author: Joel A.

description: Cash only and there is a ATM inside. Food was served hot and fresh and you get a good amount and the prices are good. I also enjoyed the fresh juice of orange,beet and carrots.
author: Shaneel R.

description: Perfectly respectable little taqueria in the Castro about five doors down from another little taqueria, also on Church Street. This one is the smaller, though arguably, the better of the two. Very good breakfast burritos.
author: Sean B.

description:
I am so disappointed that I didn't check their ratings before actually going and I actually feel bad for adding another bad review. But we were across the street and wanted to grab a bite before heading back to LA. 

Food: Was not the best we got the Ceviche de pescado tostadas and the pepper or whatever they put on it was not enjoyable. Let me just say I LOVE SEAFOOD so when I go somewhere and decide to eat some seafood I expect to come out with a smile from ear to ear. So I also got the shrimp cocktail and wow it was not warm as I had at asked for it to be and there was jalapeños!! Yes I like some spice but I also like to enjoy my food. I guess I should've looked closer to the menu since I'm definitely not in the valley. But you learn from your mistakes! The tostadas we got along with our shrimp cocktails were so stale we used the other little chips. 
They have their own self serve salsas with endless chips which is great!! 

Customer service: My family and I only interacted with the girl who took our order.  She was not friendly, there was no welcomed feeling. Unfortunately when I come back to the Bay Area I won't be returning to this place nor recommending.
author: Maria C.

description:
Five stars for the most delicious, giant, unforgettable super burritos north of Market Street.

I accidentally ended up at El Castillito last night (stayed longer than I meant to at work, took the wrong train, and then ended up feeling ravenously hungry. Stumbled across this place on my walk home). I didn't know what was good, but I went with my usual carnitas and decided to treat myself to a "super." OMG. It was so good. And it was huge. My arm felt legitimately sore from carrying it by the time I got to Duboce Park. I have a huge appetite, but even I could only finish half, and you bet I spent the entirety of my hour and forty minutes on the shuttle this evening dreaming of my leftover burrito. I can't say it was as good today as it was yesterday, but man, that was one special burrito.

Can't wait to come back.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Very solid taqueria. El pastor is on
Point. Highly recommend. 

Chips are not the best but I don't really care about those.
author: Evan S.

description:
5 Star food
5 Star prices
5 Star staff

There are so many overpriced meals near Castro. Castillito's burrito is twice as good and half the price of some nearby places serving similar food. Only differences are you get walk up and order from the cook directly instead of having a server. 

Love this place for breakfast lunch or dinner.
author: Adam B.

description: This unassuming place makes a really good (messy) plate of nachos. Even though the place has zero ambience inside I recommend eating in because nachos are always best hot. We ordered the super nachos (no sour cream) with al pastor. They don't look like much. Like I said a messy plate of nachos. But boy are they yummy. There's nothing really special about any of the ingredients. It looks the same as any other place. Yet it all comes together into a delicious plate of nachos - like everything you might imagine taqueria nachos to be.
author: Jean K.

description: This is my first time in San Francisco, but not my first time eating a burrito. I have been told that the burritos on the East Coast do not compare to the ones on the West Coast and I have found out today that this is true. There was such bold flavor and freshness. If you are looking for an authentic Mexican burrito, this is where to go.
author: Angela R.

description: I always wanted to try the burritos from this place I read the reviews and wanted to give it a try.  first of all the guy that prepares the food is the same guy that got a bad review. He seems like he's angry but he's nice I got the zapata And was huge, very huge. To me this is one of the best burritos I ever had I will keep coming back and try the rest of the menu.
author: Jonny O.

description: I love the breakfast burrito here! Breakfast burrito is available all day and the scrambled eggs with the ground beef mixed with some salsa is heavenly. Chips are also delicious always add chips! Guac salsa is my favorite. Just make sure you bring cash since it's a cash only place.
author: Johnny L.

description: Whenever I am in San Fran a Super Veggie burrito with Black Beans is a must Get the Green Sauce at the condiment bar and pour it all over your food.
author: Rae M.

description: Killer late night burrito place! $8.79 for a super burrito that was by all accounts massive. What else is there to say. The place is divey, and I probably wouldn't sit around to eat there especially at 11pm at night, but hop in for a quick burrito. There is typically a line, but I believe you can phone ahead. Looking forward to going back to try the al pastor and the quesadillas.
author: John W.

description:
This gritty establishment stands in stark contrast to Chipolte. The inside is a little dingy, the chefs are brusk and the employees are usually speaking Spanish. This might lead one to believe that this is an authentic taqueria, with delicious food. That couldn't be more wrong.

The size of a burrito is definitely large and the salsa bar has actually spicy salsa, but that's where the positives end. The meat is usually flavorless and hard. Mexican rice is traditionally cooked in a tomato and animal broth, giving it a rich flavor, however the rice here is watery and weak. I have come in starving and ordered a burrito, but usually lose my appetite halfway through. It's just not good. 

The service is abysmal too. I asked for a regular burrito, and the cook started making me a super. As I saw him about to put cheese on my burrito, I let him know I ordered a regular. He got upset and called me a f*cking dumb*ss in Spanish to his coworker. I'll put up with that for a decent meal, but nothing here makes that treatment worthwhile. 

In short, avoid. Go a few blocks south and get something that tastes good.
author: Michael H.

description: I'm always around Church and Duboce for some reason when I get off the N and head to Valencia St. I like this place a lot. Today I had the quesadilla suiza and asked for some pico de gallo in it. Delish and satisfying.
author: Denise C.

description:
I come here often because it is the closes great taqueria in the Castro district. But I just cannot stand the cook. Big Latino bald guy. He gives me attitude looks at me with a mean look all the time. I personally think he doesn't like Mexican Americans. (Sorry) He corrects my Spanish all the time. And I'm a regular. I'm now like what ever to this place and considering walking extra to the mission to get my Latino food. 

The food is great, I love it!!!
But the cook and the cashiers need to shape up their attitudes! I'm now considering on not coming back to this place.
author: Kevin R.

description: This place has the best Al pastor super burrito in the entire world. Extremely flavorful meat and salsa, huge portions, and cheap. You should go here.
author: Swaraj B.

description: I'm debating whether this is the best super burrito in SF. Which puts it in the running for best in California. Thus, best in universe. Salsa bar, free chips, and nice people. Cash only, and a super is ~$10
author: nick p.

description: I've ventured far and wide to find the best alpastor outside of the holy Grail of Mexican restaurant in la Paz called tacos del sur, and this is it! It has the perfect balance of the subtle sweetness and soft spicyness you'd expect to find in Al pastor! They marinate it overnight and slow cook it all day which is seldom to find here in the city or the bay even. Besides the bombtastic la pastor their salsa bar isn't slacking either.fully stocked with guac-oil salsa, super picante and a good pico de Gallo. This place gives my taste buds a sense of ineffability when it comes to put the superior taste into words, all I can say is if you like Mexican food, this spot is a MUST!! And I may help get you in here the first time but your taste buds will bring you back countless times thereafter!! Enjoy!!
author: Joseph E.

description: This steak and chicken SUPER  burrito was so good ! Everything was flavorful and made to order. Ingredients were all fresh. Sour cream amd guacamole is so yummy ! I will be visiting this place again soon !
author: Tatiana M.

description:
One knows not the burrito unless one has eaten a Mission burrito. Having eaten almost exclusively Chipotle burritos until visiting El Castillito, this was like visiting burrito paradise. Upon the suggestion of a friend, I passed up popular mainstays such as El Farolito and La Taqueria for this place that isn't even technically in Mission, situated on the "wrong" side of Market, aka the north side. 

My carne asada super burrito was the weight of a small newborn, and jam-packed with deliciousness. I will overlook the absence of the guacamole that is supposed to come with the super burrito. In this case, unlike so many Chipotle burritos before it, guac was not a necessity. The gratuitous chips that came with the burrito were also welcome, warm and crisp, and the selection of condiments for your burrito and chips were also a huge plus. 

If there's one reason to persuade me to move from the East Coast to San Francisco it's a Mission burrito, and my El Castillito burrito was all the convincing I needed.
author: Arthur C.

description: I have been coming for like 15 years -- it's my favorite burrito in the city I normally get carne asada El Pastor is good too. I love this place.
author: Him S.

description:
BEST. BURRITOS. EVER.

Get the green sauce for tortilla chips!
author: Dohee K.

description:
GREAT prices, good hours, you can watch your food get made, has an ATM inside(or a Safeway for cashbacks & Wells Fargo ATM across the street) since it's cash only. I would try the aqua fresca and I loved the gigantic veggie burrito I got with mushrooms and zucchini. 
My only thought for an improved experience was that the veggie burrito(a "special" shown taped to the wall and NOT on the menu) was somewhat bare minimum, having little to no seasoning with just veggies. I would recommend someone add cheese, guacamole, or meat to it.
author: Mary C.

description: Bland and flavorless with low quality meat. I ordered a carnitas burrito, and watched as the most unappetizing, grey meat was cooked for my burrito. Cashier made sure to give me my change with an oddly unnecessary amount of $1 bills, ostensibly for the tip jar. I put them right into my wallet, where they belonged.  Not going to return. WAY too much good Mexican food in this city. This might be the worst of the worst. Would rather eat Taco Bell.
author: Richard V.

description: This is the best Al Pastor burrito in SF- delicious salsa bar - not usually busy- very skilled cooks. It's the only place I go out of my way to get a burrito- no lines, and the best al pastor ive had. Good vibe too- everyone is very friendly
author: Brendan M.

description: Absolutely amazing food. The service in there also amazing. My friend and I had a good time in there. The best part is that the amount of food they gave us is ridicules huge. Would totally go back again. The food is made from heart.
author: Edward M.

description:
I was running on pure adrenaline all day, so busy that I skipped breakfast, lunch and dinner. Then I went to the gym on empty, so that by the time I ended my day at around 10, I was actually ready to throw up I was so hungry.  I was on Ashbury and Frederick when I pulled over, threw on the emergency lights (it was a food emergency, the most serious of them all, actually), and searched yelp for burrito, filter "open now," filter "nearby." Indeed.

My search brought up El Castillito, and so I drove like a bat out of hell to Duboce Triangle. I walked in and there was a line of sk8ers (their boards were propped against the wall), which I took as a good sign. EC is a bit of a dump, which is also a good sign with respect to Mexican food. The inside is small, a little messy, and disorganized. There's a huge window where you can watch the cooks put your order together. There's a big spindle of meat next to the grill. All good. 

I shouted my order over a bunch of guys waiting for their orders. I was all business, given that I was almost going to die of hunger, and ordered a pretty safe burrito: super chicken burrito, light pinto beans, light guacamole. They called my order lightening quick - and I paid lightening quick too (CASH ONLY - but note there's an ATM in the burger joint next door). Then I flew home so I could eat the hell out of my burrito in private. 

Oh my goodness, that burrito hit the spot. It was huge - I could only eat half - but it was 7 shades of delicious. The quality ingredients were combined in perfect proportion to one another, such that every bite was yummy. I appreciate assembly when it comes to burritos. I usually don't get guac on a burrito because it always takes me 2 days to eat it and I don't particularly like brown guac - but the guac stayed perfectly green the next day.  The burrito also tasted delicious cold. 

The only criticism I have of EC is that their salsa bar is not the greatest. But the burrito is so good, you don't really need salsa. Skip it. 

Cheap, open late, and tasty. Recommend.
author: Sunny S.

description:
This is probably my go-to burrito place in the city! The burrito portions are MASSIVE and it comes with complementary tortilla chips! 

You can choose from a variety of tortilla such as spinach, sun-dried tomato, whole wheat, or flour. (I liked the spinach tortilla)

There are also options for meats as well: carne asada, chicken, carnitas, al pastor. The al pastor was on the sweet side for me and so I probably wouldn't order it a second time unless I'm really craving it. If you've had Chinese BBQ pork (cha siu), it tastes like the Mexican version of that. However, I did enjoy the carnitas. 

There are regular burritos and super burritos--the main difference is that the super has sour cream, cheese, and guac. 

Their salsa/condiments bar is pretty great. They have spicy pico and regular pico de gallo, however their pico tastes more herby than the traditional ones I'm used to--as if there were Italian spices mixed in...? They had this green sauce which was absolutely AMAZING. I was totally in love with this one. There was also a fire roasted tomato salsa and some spicer orange-colored sauce. The latter two didn't really faze me. The grilled jalapeños on the side were awesome--perfectly cooked and salted! 

Monday-Thursday 3-5pm is their burrito happy hour! 4.99 for regular burritos 

Tip: this place is cash only and kind of small
author: Victoria C.

description:
Cash Only 
Happy Hour Regular burritos from 3pm to 5pm for 5.99

Otherwise it is 6.99

Consistently good, I have been a handful of times. The salsa and flavors are pretty bomb.
author: Nathan A.

description: Seriously delicious meat stand. There's an upright rotisserie of lamb that made it one of the most delicious burritos I've had in the city. If you're in the neighborhood, I can not recommend this place enough.
author: Nicholas S.

description:
If this were any other town, this place would have 5 stars easy. But the Mission being such a hyper-competitive burrito haven, I have to go win 4 just because the meats I had were not quite as superlative as a couple other places in the area (like Farilito). 

This place is still an excellent option! You get a massssssive portion for a pretty cheap price. Have to recommend the wet super burrito with pastor, which comes smothered in an enchilada sauce that makes he burrito feel like 5 pounds and last at least two meals.

The staff is friendly and the topping bar is excellent (be cautious with the peppers - they're hot).
author: Ben S.

description:
I'm in castillito on church, eating. Some lady with a big belly walks in, orders chicken burrito, says "I'm gettin chicken because I'm on a diet." The guy taking her order who is snarky AF takes one look at her belly and says "May be like 3 babies, when they coming?" ... & the place went silent. I turned around to look at him from across the whole place & then the fucker said it AGAIN! Poor lady stood there very uncomfortably, not knowing what to say.

Before that happened the lady was in a great mood about to eat some quality mexican food with her two friends. That cook is a real ass hole & having a dude like that front your business will hurt your bottom line.

The food is actually satisfactory. its a good deal, not great but you can get that quality of food in a hundred other places in sf for just as cheap. In fact there is another taquerilla 4 doors down church street.
author: Willy G.

description:
El Castillito is the holy red-and-yellow burrito shrine where Chipotle cultists fear to tread.

The Good: Their breakfast burritos are a gut-bomb of minced pink chorizo and fluffy scrambled eggs, wrapped up with salsa, onions, and freshly-diced jalapenos. The chorizo here has a flavor and appearance subtly reminiscent of corned beef. If that isn't spicy enough for you, you can pick up yummy grilled jalapenos from their salsa bar on the side.

Castillito's pico de gallo is super fresh, the establishment is clean, and their staff is very friendly. You can even order fresh carrot and orange juice squeezed for you on the spot. What more could you ask for? As a bonus, parking is plentiful if you visit the Safeway across the street.

The Bad: The Mexican music here is simply ear-splitting. But hey, you probably wanted to avoid that awkward post-hangover morning conversation anyways. Their front door is always open as well, so plan to bring a jacket in the wintertime.

If you're looking for a Mission-style burrito away from the Mission, this is the spot.
author: Alex L.

description: This is a great spot to pick up a burrito when you're in the Duboce Area. Just as good as many mission burrito places and I love that they have spinach tortillas!
author: Michael S.

description:
I've been coming here for years.  The food is great.  My rating is not for the food, but for the service.  I will not go back there.

I can't eat wheat, so I always order a corn quesadilla with added meat.  I always pay extra for the meat, of course.  They never had any problem with my order.

Tonight, I went in and ordered from someone who has made this order for me before.  He glared at me, and told me corn quesadillas only had cheese.  And this was a *serious* glare.  (If you go here, you know that the guys who make the food can sometimes be in bad moods.)  It was such a serious glare, I didn't try to talk to him about it.  

I was going to just walk out, it was so rude.  Instead, I went to the woman at the cash register.  She was cleaning tables at the time, and I was walking by her, or I might not have.  I explained what I tried to order, and she even finished my sentence for me, saying "Yes, you order that all the time."  I said "he won't make it for me tonight!"  She went back and spoke to him, but they both just stared at me, the guy still glaring.  So I left.

I won't go back.
author: Bruce S.

description: I have been coming here for years and have not been disappointed yet. The staff is friendly and they move quick. The BEST green sauce I have ever had STILL to this day. I always order steak burritos or quesadillas. The HORCHATA? AMAZING...... oh and the food is made right before your eyes so at least you know their hands are clean and they aren't doing anything creepy to your food.
author: Tamu V.

description: I love this place. Vegetarian nachos are my favorite. Staff is kind, the service is great. It's a small hall in the wall kind of place but the food is great. Highly recommend
author: B B.

description:
Plans to explore the city and one of our last places to cross off our list was clarion alley. We didn't plan on what to eat (so out of character of me I know) so we walked a few stores from clarion alley to find ourselves in front of this little taqueria. It looks smaller on the outside. It goes in pretty deep and has a lot of seating. The bathroom here didn't need a key and I mean, hey how many places do you ever see now (esp in SF) that'll let you use a bathroom without requiring you buy something!? I was kind of surprised. 

The plan was to get "something small to share." So a quesadilla is usually a safe bet for something small, right? Compared to a burrito that'll be too big for our appetite at the time, a quesadilla sounded perfect!

Boy were we wrong. But it wasn't a bad thing. There was nothing small about that quesadilla. It was basically a burrito. We actually had to ask if the order was ours because if you see in photos, it looks like a burrito!! It was just so STUFFFED with all the goodness that it ended up having a round-ish shape like it's loved cousin the burrito. The difference is that instead of the soft, almost falling apart because it's so soft, texture a burrito has, this tortilla was soft but crispy on the outside-like a quesadilla should be. It's definitely worth the money for what you get. Although size stood out, the taste of the quesadilla wasn't the most memorable. Flavors weren't all there and the thing that distinguishes a quesadilla from a burrito is that one of them should have way more cheese.. At least that's how I've always known and what I look forward to in a quesadilla! There was so much other stuff in there that cheese seemed to be little to almost none. Honestly, I would come back anyway to try some of their other items like the carne asada super burrito or ceviche tostado!
author: Maleah M.

description: This place is a savior to San Francisco residents. I have been searching for good authentic Mexican in the area and finally found this. It was about $10 for the burrito and a can of coke. Got a super burrito and it's MASSIVE and delicious. It has almost too much grease though. Cash only.
author: Shawn T.

description:
Alright kids, lets say you're in the area and you want a taqueria but don't want to trek into the Mission. Then this is where you should go. By far the best taqueria in the area.

Here's a hint - get the quesadilla instead of the burrito. It's the same size but without the filler of the beans and rice. The al pastor is great and the carne asada is bomb as well. I usually get avocado instead of quacamole on mine. 

It's massive, it's tasty, it's filling and you don't even have to walk down to the Mission. BOOM.
author: Evan L.

description: This place was such a great find! It's just a little hole in the wall but all the ingredients are fresh, food is cheap, and everything's delicious. Their veggie burrito has actual veggies in it instead of just rice and beans. It seems like a small family run business. It was just as good, probably even better than Farolito. Oh, and it's cash only btw.
author: Jenine G.

description: Food is very good but I've received horrible attitude from Juan during my last two visits. Each visit he was very grumpy and short with me. I tried to clearly articulate my order but he got frustrated and blamed any miscommunication on me-I was ordering three to four entries each visit. If he's working the next time I walk in, I'll be walking out.  The cashier and the other cook were super nice.
author: chris a.

description:
This place rocks!  One of the best burrito joints in the City.  And there are few places that provide such bang for the buck.

Salsa bar is a real plus, too.  And the place is right off several Muni lines and near a bunch of other great stores like Safeway, Whole Foods and a small produce market ore on the same block.
author: Jane D.

description: I didn't know there were burritos this good outside the mission, but apparently there are.  Great spot to grab lunch in the middle of the city, and if you get the al pastor super burrito, prepare to be amazed.
author: Briggs M.

description: The burrito debate never ends in SF.... I have been going here for years.  I have tried many, many others, and I still think this one is the best!  They don't take meat(any of them) from a vat and put it into your burrito.  They actually take it out, put it on the grill, crisp it up a bit, then put it in.  Their ingredients are always fresh.  Their steak does not have lots of "chewy fat bits" which is frequently the case with other places.   The men who make the food are great to talk to too!  Love the place.
author: Maureen O.

description: Great, no-frills Mexican nosh for great prices and friendly environment, you will certainly not leave hungry! Cash only though.
author: Andy L.

description:
Decent tacos at a decent price. I ordered carne Asada Tacos. The meat was a bit dry however I loved the fresh onion and cilantro. All that was missing was a lime.

My partner ordered chicken enchiladas, this is where we were disappointed. The enchilada sauce came out of a plastic bottle that was under the stove. They placed a slice of cheese on the beens and 2 slices on the enchiladas and then into the microwave. The cheese did not even fully melt.

It was okay overall. However, I would not go out of my way to go back.
author: Rudy S.

description: Al Pastor burrito. That's all you need here. It's juicy, flavorful and the salsa at the salsa bar packs a kick. The service? I don't come here for that, I come here for the awesome al pastor burrito. Thank you, goodnight.
author: N M.

description: A great place to eat. I had a flavorful taco salad with bbq chicken and refried beans. Fast friendly service. Yes try this place. Authentic Mexican food. Yummy.
author: David A.

description: Cheap burritos but not that great. I had the pastor super burrito and the meat was marinated well but overcooked. I also got hot salsa and I didn't taste any spice at all. My hubby got the carne asada burrito and the meat again was overcooked and had no flavor. I found it strange they used sliced white american cheese; not very authentic for mexican food. Definitely prefer El Farolito and La Taqueria over this place. FYI, it's cash only and there's no bathrooms there. Location is good off of market and church.
author: Lisa D.

description:
I cant eat onion due to an allergy.  I told them that.  Ordered a quesadilla with no onion and no salsa.  Very indignantly they said no problem.  Of course comes with onion. When I point out they first try to deny it.  But theu are right there.   They then blame it on me saying the tomatoes and onion are already mixed so my fault.  What morons.  Fail. 
Also the. Heese they use looks like velveeta.
author: Trecker J.

description:
This is the only place i go to for my burritos, quesadillas, fajitas...

Other spots CAN'T compare to El Castillito.

Their quesadillas are NOT flat. It's the size of a burrito! And they're delicious.
Burritos.

Fajitas are amazing. You get a lot for what you pay, like $9 something.

My husband usually gets a chicken super burrito and i get fajitas or a quesadilla. Our total is usually around $20.

Love that their chips ARE FREE.
I love their pico de gallo and that other thing that has carrots, jalapenos, and onions

Cons:
-Sometimes I feel i annoy the workers if i ask for extra sour cream or extra cheese.
-the register lady is not that friendly. But NOT mean. Whenever i tip, no thank yous or smiles, just a  str8 face.
-i feel rushed at times, even when there's no line.

Promise this is the BEST spot for Mexican food. Swear.

Customer Service is everything, otherwise I'd give 5 stars. But the food makes up for it.
author: Monica S.

description:
Incredibly over rated place. Who did they screw for these reviews.
No bathroom. 
No smiles.
No music.
No buzz.

-Sloppy Tacos. 
-Soggy Burrito.
author: David L.

description:
Definitely adding this to one of my favorite burrito places here! 

Step 1: Go to the first window to place my carne asada super burrito where they make the food right in front of you. **You get to choose what kind of tortilla you want aside from flour, which is def a plus for me! 
Step 2: Grab my food right there & pay at the cashier
Step 3: Get the delicious green & red salsas, take a seat, & finally feast on the super burrito that you've been waiting for
Enjoy!!! 

Overall, really great burrito w/ tons of flavor  & a huge burrito that lived up to its "super" name. Def recommend!
author: Trina N.

description: The front cashier ladies need to go back to school and learn BASIC MATH!  Every time my elderly mother in law goes they short change her. That is theft!!!!  Charge people based on your MENU PRICES!!!  Stop overcharging because you as a front cashier are poor and steal money from your customer. This  review is being left on behalf of elderly Latina who eats there with the baby. Two tacos with rice and beans is $5 based on your menu. Learn to read or get another job!!!!
author: Carlos Q.

description: Authentic Mexican street tacos with no frills just damn good tacos and salsa. Went with two friends late one night after having some drinks. We all ordered either al pastor or asada tacos. The meat was tender and juicy and was topped with fresh onion and cilantro! I'm from San Antonio, Texas and these tacos can hold their own with some of the better options in San Antonio.
author: Nicholas H.

description: REGULAR BURRITO! Yum. This place isn't the cleanest, but the food sure tastes authentic. You order first, pay later, and eat last. SO GOOD! The meats are pretty juicy too-- carne asada all the way. The "wet burrito" also looks delicious, but thats a little too much sour cream for me. It's the best when the food is cheap and you come out more full than you normally would at an expensive restaurant. The chefs were also pretty nice when I asked them to re-cook my burrito because they forgot to take out the cheese. Plus, we bought their fresh juice (oranges, beets, celery) to complement the "heavy" burrito. It FELT like we were cleaning our palate after the heavy goodness, which I couldn't even finish... yay for leftovers!
author: Connie L.

description:
We've returned a couple of times already and we're definitely returning.

So far we've had the wet burritos twice and eventually we'll move on to something else, but if you're nuts about wet burritos (a burrito that has been covered with sauce) this is the place.  For less than 10 bucks you get at least a meal's worth of food that improves in the fridge so you've got a treat the next day.  Everything tastes fresh and although the food takes a moment or two longer than you'd probably expect, it's worth ever second.

One word of warning: the disposable plastic ware they provide will do nothing for you.  Ask for stainless (?) table ware so you can actually eat normally.  Otherwise it's an uphill battle as the plastic ware they supply is really flimsy.

One star off for cleanliness and lack of seating.  They need to spread out onto the sidewalk or something; it's really cramped inside so be prepared to rub shoulders with fellow diners.

I also had a burrito al pastor (marinated and roasted pork loin, but you know this, already, gentle reader....) and it was what brought me back.  I think we may have seen this place on teevee or youtube or something which is why we tried the wet burritos.  I'm also curious about the quesadilla suiza so maybe that will be for next time.

Also, bring cash to save on ATM fees and time.  There's what I think is a MUNI terminal on the street but I don't take Muni so I really don't know what it is.  UFOs could drop by and whisk people away for all I know.  There's a Safeway across the street with a huge parking lot.  But not for UFOs.  You can derive whatever meaning from that as your conscience permits.  Good luck.  Bring some napkins.  Live long and prosper.  I hope that that phrase isn't trademarked or whatever.....
author: E G.

description:
Actually a 3.75 stars.

Sitting in bed last night reading yelp reviews on a relatively empty stomach I came across El Castillito and its 4 stars and many reviews.

I like el castillito, although the super burrito is now $8.20 and the health grade is an 90...like that makes a difference.

Their el pastor is good but not great....the pork should be succulent yet crunchy on the outside...and their's is not.

The tortilla is grilled to a wonderful flakiness, the cheese and the sour cream are nice additions...although it all gets somewhat mixed up and the flavors are not really layers.

Their salsas are very good except the green creamy one...whatever that thing is and I love the jalapeno slices with carrots and onions.

If you are starving check out the super burrito and you will leave completely and totally satiated.
author: David G.

description:
Just left feeling sick.
Seriously disappointed.
My husband has been raving about this place. 
He loves it, eats here all the time.
Today was my first time and my last I think.
We both ordered Vegetarian Super burrito. 
I ate a little less than half of mine and had my husband throw it away. 
It was nothing but a tiny bit of rice, with lettuce and sour cream. All the beans were at one end I guess, and not the end I ate. It was really nauseating. No guacamole. 
Eh.
At least the salsa was good.
I wish I had just ordered a plain bean and cheese burrito.
author: Shauna M.

description:
You certainly get your money's worth when you're referring to the portion. However the burrito tasted very average and just wasn't put together correctly. The end I started with (the top) was all sour cream, cilantro and a bit of cheese; all the cold ingredients. Where were the beans...the rice? This is an SF burrito. And after a few more bites of cold, I had to look inside to make sure there were other ingredients in there. When I finally reached the warmer ingredients I was already tired of it. To make things worse the flavor wasn't great. It wasn't terrible, it just didn't do it for me. 

This is not a good sign. I left about 1/4 to 1/3 untouched. This is rare for me. I consider burritos to be a staple to my diet and I could probably count with one hand the times I didn't finish one.
author: Esther A.

description: This place was average but defiantly worth it because there is no other good burrito place around in Union square.
author: Vincent G.

description:
Big fan of this hole in the wall taqueria! Late night eats a must! Fresh burritos made in front of you to specifications and wrapped to perfection. Leave it to these professionals. They do it right. Cash only people! They do not stutter! Be sure to be ready before you get in line or suffer the judgement of your fellow San Franciscans. $7 for a regular chicken burrito...yes please!

Located on Church St in the Duboce Triangle and a stones throw away from Mission Dolores it is nice to have a good Mexican spot on the way home. It may not be your favorite taqueria or even your second favorite but who cares when the food is this good! I recommend stuffing your face.
author: Nick C.

description: Love this spot! There are a few other locations around the city, which are all great, today I happened to stop into this one... Usually order super burrito, the there are many offerings that I'm sure are delicious! Friendly staff, and good prices... Does get pretty crowded in here depending on when you go, so seating seems kind of smooshed... They have recently added shrimp cocktail to their menu, and may I say it is DIVINE!!!! $5.99 for a big serving of the coktel de camaron! Served w crackers but really good w chips and tapatio! Great place for superb and authentic Mexican food! Hard to find sometimes in the city! Will be returning!
author: Christiana C.

description:
Food is mediocre at best. No flavor in their meats and you can tell that they use low quality ingredients. I've had much better tacos at the taco truck on Harrison St. 

Rude service and overall bad attitude from workers. One of the cooks was giving the women in front of me attitude over not ordering correctly. He proceeded to talk poorly about her when she left not knowing I spoke Spanish. I would pass on this place since there are so many amazing taquerias in this town.
author: Moon G.

description:
There are so many "Best Burrito in SF" lists out there, and I am *really* surprised El Castillito is not on any of them - at least none that I have seen. El Castillito is my neighborhood taqueria, and I discovered it when I moved into my new apartment a year ago. After sharing this "find" with friends, at least a couple were like, "Oh, yeah, I go there all the time. It's my favorite." 

This is the quintessential hole-in-the-wall taqueria. It looks a little grimy - 85 out of 100 on health inspection, but I can live with that. There is always a line after work, but they're super efficient in getting you through.

I am a creature of habit, so I have only sampled the steak-n-shrimp super burrito and the shrimp quesadilla. Both are near perfection for a neighborhood taqueria - tender steak and clearly fresh shrimp. They're not skimpy with accompaniments, so expect a fat burrito - usually two meals for me. After reading a few of the reviews on here, I see I need to up my game and try the pork carnitas or al pastor - perhaps in tacos. Next time!

Great selection of salsas and sides. Oh yeah, this place is cheap.

~~~~~~~~
UPDATE: Oh wait! It is on a 'Best Of' list: sfist's 'The 12 Best Burritos In San Francisco: A Definitive List' (http://bit.ly/1gRSd3r)
author: Corey M.

description: A good but not great burrito by SF standards. The style is very similar to Taqueria Cancun but not quite as good. Won't kick you out if you sit there for 3 hours. No visible restroom; there might be one in the back.
author: Karl K.

description:
This place used to be my fave go to spot, especially whenever I had east coast visitors wanting to try local Mexican. However, the last few times I've gone the kitchen staff has been different, the flavors and meats mediocre or bland, and attitudes glaring.

Not sure if the "usual" guys from the past several years are still there, but I miss their happy-go-lucky and fun demeanor. The ones I've had during my last couple visits have given unwarranted lip, attitude, and eye-rolling. I may give it another shot, but so far it's been two strikes in a row.
author: Matt K.

description:
Having just moved from Texas, I was skeptical about the type of Mexican food I'd come across in San Francisco. Sure, I'd heard that I'd be equally impressed with the state's "Baja Mexican" style of cuisine vs. the Lone Star State's "Tex-Mex" fare, but it was hard to tell if it those comments were based on mouth-watering facts, or simply Bay Area civic pride. Well, needless to say that spots like El Castillito are making sure that it's the former, and not the latter.

I found myself at El Castillito because the Warriors had just won their first championship in 40 years, because it was late, and because dammit, I needed a burrito! Yes, a late-night victory burrito was in order.

To date, this is the best burrito I've had in San Francisco. I did my research going in, and quickly selected the Al Pastor Super Burrito, hearing that was the go-to on the menu. This succulent pork burrito was definitely the way to go, but it was the little things that set it apart. First, none of the other extra fixin's were overpowering the others, a common issue across most burritos. In addition to the heavenly meat itself, the onions, guac, black bean, rice, sour cream, and mild sauce were all in perfect harmony, in the perfect amounts, and staying within the confines of the tortilla. 

Speaking of the tortilla, while the meat is being prepared on the grill, so is the tortilla! This gives the burritos floury shell a subtle but noticeable "crunch," a trait seriously lacking in most burritos. In addition to the tortilla prep, three slices of cheese are laid across the surface while it heats up on the grill, providing a perfect distribution of cheesy goodness across the soon-to-be burrito.

While Duboce Triangle may not be The Mission, it's close enough, and I'd put El Castillito toe-to-toe with some of the biggest names in the SF burrito scene. As one of the busiest crossroads in the city, it's a relief to know that there's a delicious burrito right nearby.
author: Chris L.

description:
Henceforth, ALL other burritos are FALSE burritos!

A lady friend and I had read somewhere that this was one of the best Taquerias in SF, and the best one in the Castro, but we passed by it several dozen times without ever going in.  Unfortunately, we stopped hanging out, so I decided to do all the things we only ever talked about doing together and decided giving this place a try was a good place to start crossing things off that checklist.

From the very first bite, I knew what I'd heard was true!  All their ingredients were on point, the tortilla was juuuusssstttt the right amount of crunchy (I'm a texture whore, sue me!) and it actually impressed me how well bro working the grill kept his station clean even as he was working and filling multiple orders... I always assume when I go to grab a burrito that its going to touch SOMETHING unsanitary, and accepted that was just a hazard that comes with the territory so it was reassuring to see somebody taking care of their work space well.

I tried to save the other half of the burrito for later... it didn't make it home :-P
I'm also afraid that all the other taquerias I frequent on the peninsula will all be disappointing in comparison from now on
author: Stephen L.

description: The cook is seriously is such a biznatch. The reviews are real. Get that guy to shape up dude. Donald trump will send the ICF in there and we'll see how much he'll roll eyes his eyes when that happens. People just ordering their food seems to really bother him! He will literally make fun of you while you order your food. Lost another customer
author: Rouz E.

description:
Burritos are always good, no matter what. But I can definitely say that burritos taste even better when you haven't had them in months and you're off to a board game convention, so El Castillito was here at the right place and the right time for me. I am definitely coming back the next time someone suggests getting burritos when I'm in this area.

This massive burrito was everything I could have asked for, and it was prepared quickly and right in front of me, and they even let me substitute salsa for red sauce. I don't even know what red sauce is. All I know is that I love it and require it in all things within a tortilla, and I am grateful to them for letting me substitute for it...though I will say it was quite spicy. In a good way.

Next time, I want to get a quesadilla, because it looked massive and all kinds of amazing. This place is cash only, and you get a lot of burrito for your money. I was full by about 1/4 of the burrito, but pride egged me on to go at least to half the burrito. By then I'm sure I was already lost in a food coma. My best friend likes to think of prices in comparison to burritos; this place would definitely one of those where they'd say, "Kids? Why would I have kids? They're expensive. That's like, at least 50,000 burritos right there."
author: Robbin A.

description:
At some point, the owners of this restaurant had this conversation:

"Hey, you know how a burrito is a blend of meat, rice, beans, lettuce, tomatoes, onions, salsa, cheese, and sour cream wrapped in a tortilla?"

"Yeah.  We run a Mexican restaurant.  I'm pretty familiar with what a burrito is, asshole."

"Well you know how most of the things that go into a burrito aren't meat?"

"Again, familiar with the concept of a burrito."

"How about we take all that bullshit out and replace it with meat instead?"

"What?"

"Yeah, like instead of rice, we'll put in meat.  And instead of beans, we'll also put in meat.  And shit, while we're at it, let's replace the lettuce, tomatoes, and onions with meat."

"You're fucking crazy."

"And we can call it the All Meat Burrito."

"I don't want any part of this."

And then I got that burrito like 4 times a week
author: Kevin C.

description:
Stopped in here for a quick bite after a day of imbibing.  Great place to fill up on burritos, nachos, or quesadillas.  I got a vegetarian quesadilla that was delicious.  Pro tip - ask for avocado instead of guacamole.

The prices are very reasonable and the portions are large (my quesadilla was $5.50 and too much for a single meal).  I have yet to try the burrito, but I know it's made several "best of" lists so I'll definitely be back.
author: Michelle K.

description:
The best taqueria in Lower Haight/Duboce Triangle. Ideal for the basics: tacos & burritos. 

You can keep your yuppie taqueria (Little Chihuahua on Diviz-- overbusy, overpriced), this place has better prices, portions, and burritos. Punt the chihuahua, go to this place instead. Or don't and keep the lines short, I think it's here to stay regardless.
author: Rob G.

description: Some past happy visits, but got food poisoning following the most recent.  Health score of 87 not sufficient, apparently.
author: Todd G.

description:
I still think El Castillito makes the best fully loaded quesadilla in town. The eponymous Quesadilla Castillito offers any meat, cheese, avocado, sour cream, tomatoes and jalapenos, all stuffed in a generous-size grilled flour tortilla for $7.49 (see photo). It's a huge portion for a fair market price, and the quality of the food really hasn't diminished in the five and a half years since my last review of this Church Street hole-in-the-wall.

But I am also five and a half years older and becoming the dreaded old man I was afraid I would turn into. "Get off my lawn, you rotten kids!" How else do I explain my utter disdain at the slackers who come in and leave their slop on not only the tables but on the floor. Who raised them? Ted Kaczynski? It's frustrating to come here and wait for a table where a loser couple with pierced eyebrows have dropped the remains of their avocado and salsa on the floor for the rest of us to slide our feet over to near-certain injury. Who raised them? Sid and Nancy?

By the time Jamie W. and I got out orders and scooped out our cups of salsa, we couldn't find a clean table even though three were empty of the hoodlums who just gorged their burritos there. I tried to wipe what I could with a skimpy napkin until I waved at the cashier to help clean the table. She did without hesitation which I appreciated. It didn't hinder our enjoyment of the food, but c'mon, what gives people the right to act like pigs when they're in this place? Who raised them? Snooki and the Situation?

FOOD - 4 stars...still good stuff, no complaints
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...still a dive but no excuse for the mess some diners leave behind
SERVICE - 4 stars...a top-notch crew in here
TOTAL - 4 stars...we keep coming back, but I'm bringing some 409 and a sponge next time
author: Ed U.

description:
No. Just no. Just no. I've been a huge fan of El Farolito and Mexico Tipico since moving to the Bay Area. On my commute back to the Easy Bay, I was in Hayes Valley and wanted some tacos. This place was such a no. Castillito was what I thought I wanted, not some SF $5 a taco in hipster central bullshit. The service was not friendly but I was like okay that's not not so bad. Despite the hurried and annoyed employees, it seemed right up my alley. But upon entering, prices were way higher than expected. And upon trying the food, i quickly figured out this shit was way overpriced. In my opinion El Farolito has the highest quality ingredients as for taste, and their prices aren't has high and they're way more popular. It wasn't even just the prices, the food was bad. The al pastor tacos were all fat. The carne asada tasted like shitty meat. The carnitas were okay at best. I could have gotten better ones almost anywhere. 

AND THE WORST PART, the fucking refried beans. Imagine taking a can of uncooked Goya pinto beans, put them in a blender, then sloppily spoon it into a to go plate. Those are their beans. Salt was nowhere in the picture. Even if was, the beans couldn't be saved. I tried putting some of their salsas in the beans, and the salsas were sub par too. Not fresh or that tasty.
 
If you're around these parts in SF, I guess Castillito is an okay choice. But if you can wait it out, the 20 minute drive to the excelsior is way worth it.

Mexico Tipico's refried beans are everything. Taste them. Feel them. Know them.
author: Claudia M.

description: Best wet burrito I've ever had. Green sauce is soooo hot and spicy but good! It was huge. Enough for two people. Cheap and delicious.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
Why I love this place. 
They cook the tortillas they're not Steamed   
They have the best Carnitas they throw it on the griddle so it gets nice and crispy. 
Everyone is always nice and friendly
And you can park across the street in the Safeway lot just don't get caught.
author: Simon The Cat -.

description:
(THIS PLACE HAS INCREASED THEIR PRICES FOR THE SUPER NACHOS AND SUPER BURRITOS FROM WHAT I SAW, IT WAS $8.50 A COUPLE OF MONTHS BACK,BUT NOW  IT'S AROUND 9.50 AND WITH TAX IT COMES OUT TO AROUND $10.12, JUST A HEADS UP) Although I would personally consider this to be one of my late night Taqueria go to's they have stuff that you should get at other places instead.One of that being anything with Al Pastor as they make it with hella vinegar or at least that's what it seems like, their carnitas is also dry so I would prefer if you wanted a taco go for al pastor or any other meat choices but not carnitas. Another and my last complaint that I have about this place is their prices on tacos, I mean cmon they are like $3.50 while El Farolito in the Mission stays open till 3am and their tacos are like $2.50 and are way more flavorful especially their Al Pastor and their Carnitas I think, so yeah, El Castillito's prices on the tacos are a bit harsh on your money; so i would say buy other meal options their and avoid Carnitas and Al Pastor if you don't want either blandness or the taste of obsessive vinegar.
I would still rate this place a 8.9/10
author: Food F.

description: The food is great (the reason for the 1 star), but the service is horrible. I asked for a plate with NO hot sauce or jalapeños and I get nothing, but cerranos and jalapeños in the order. I tried talking to the help, but they were too busy on the phone. I will never go there again. $10 down the drain.
author: Anthony B.

description:
(***CASH ONLY***) 

No-nonsense Mexican food with a breakfast menu and dinner plates. My rice/bean burrito is the size of my forearm, and was around $5. Chips included, and fresh squeezed juice available for $3-4. Cheery atmosphere with murals on the ceiling. Small seating area, no outdoor seating. You can park across the street at Safeway, but don't let the "parking lot nazis" see you crossing the street or you could get towed! Duck into Safeway first to cover your behind.
author: Cortney K.

description:
Excellent value for money, the wraps here are very cheap and huge! The super burritos are definitely very tasty and the ingredients used were fresh. I'm not a huge fan of burritos myself, but I'd definitely visit again.

I'd definitely hop by for a cheap (less than $8) meal again.
author: Spencer T.

description: Steak quesadilla is fantastic. The steak is well cooked and the flavour is great! It's not a thin quesadilla, it's like a burrito but thinner and more held together. Highly recommend!
author: David S.

description:
This is actually where I had dinner on my 21st birthday and it's still a solid option. Just got a carnitas super burrito there for my flight to the east coast and it was a perfect plane dinner.

I could see the other passengers near me lustily eyeng my delicious cylinder of tasty pork wishing their airport food or expensive and non-complimentary plane food could compare.
author: Misha T.

description:
Solid Mexican food at affordable prices. I had the vegetarian quesadilla and it was a delicious beast. Chips and salsa were also great. The salsa has a great flavor at first and good heat at the end.

Fast friendly service from the chefs and cashier.
author: Nathan C.

description: Do not EVER eat at this crappy place. Terrible food (it sticks like mold), surly staff, NO BATHROOMS?, non-English speakers, they only take cash and you have to an extra $3.00 at their ATM rip off. They must have paid a click farm to review them or changed hands because there is no way they should be highly rated. Do yourself a favor and just walk on by this filthy dump of a restaurant.
author: Mike E.

description: Great steak super burrito. Classic SF taqueria look and feel.
author: Pete B.

description: Slamming basic taqueria.  Nice open salsa bar good verity.   I enjoy the burrito half carne asada and half El pastor..  lagit spot enjoy..
author: Josh S.

description:
We aimed for a hole in the wall taqueria - and we won! My partner and I shared a super pollo asado burrito, no rice, no cilantro, black beans and picante. It was absolutely delicious. The gentlemen that made the burrito, made sure he made it correctly as he prepared it by checking in with us, which was awesome since I absolutely despise cilantro. A burrito with cilantro will ruin my day. The gentlemen who took our money was also very friendly.

A++ for delicious burritos and amazing staff. 

They have bean and tortilla options too!
author: Courtney T.

description: Awesome place. I work right by here and come here about twice a week. Best burrito hands down in SF. It's just the way they put it together. For anyone who says farolitto or some other place has the best burrito, let me know who you are so I can disregard all your reviews. You can't go wrong with any of the meats here. I always go with either their pastor or chorizo. Their huevos rancheros and huevos con chorizo plates are top notch. Loaded with everything including guac and sour cream. Best part, this place doesn't charge ridiculous prices for their food. Oh another thing, it's cash only.
author: Young C.

description:
Writing reviews for Mexican food is sort of like writing reviews for dive bars...

"Yep. It's good, it's authentic" is just about all I can say. 

El Castellito is your best bet for Mexican food in this part of the city. If you want a quality super burrito-- like a good, slutty burrito-- then El Castellito is a good place to go if you're in Duboce Triangle. 

You order at the grill and get to watch them cook your al pastor. They also offer fresh squeezed juices, which is a nice touch. Have a carrot juice, you'll feel better about eating something larger than your face.

Super reasonable prices and the occasional group of drunkards in here, as to be expected. 

They take cards and are way better than the place a few doors down, which also looks exactly like El Castellito. Ten cuidado.
author: K M.

description: They changed their cooks and crew and now this place sucks. The front lady who takes payment is as rude as it gets. My mom used to eat here everyday because she works in the Castro and would bring food back for the daycare. Last time she went my mom asked for a box to go and a small empty cup so she could give some of her fresh juice she bought at the Taqueria for the baby and was told it would be $2. Yea!!!! $1 for an empty box, and $1 for an empty cup! What a little crook that front lady worker is!! Anyways, this place used to have good cooks and decent food but looks like the owner replaced their staff with stupid idiotic workers. Oh well, time to find a new taqueria!
author: Joanna G.

description: This is our favorite spot is the Bay Area. We make many day trips to the city just so we can come get burritos.
author: Paul F.

description:
What a stumbled upon gem. I walked into El Castillito needing just a quick snack, I'll return in the future to stuff myself. 

Needing just a little something something to tide myself over between pints, I walked in El Castillito - a quaint little taqueria that somehow escaped my eye this whole time. There is a process here which I obviously got wrong. You order up at the window and then pay once you got your food. I did the reverse and it took me 5-10 minutes to realize that they weren't going to make my taco unless I ordered it with the kitchen. That's tip #1 for you. 

Tip #2 ... the carnitas! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1ULAxKR5_7RWzQ4CRJD1hg?select=4qlXIaSL5W_7ypQtQ8LiIg) So moist and juicy, so flavorful, so good. It's a really simple taco but all the ingredients are fresh. The bright salsas counterpoint the fat from the pork for very well-balanced bites. It's totally worth the extra steps from the bars to stop in for a good and cheap bite. 

While my carnitas taco totally hit the right spots, I noticed the star here are super burritos that are huge. Just another reason, besides delicious carnitas, to make a return trip back to El Castillito when I'm having a few pints this side of Church Street.
author: Jon L.

description:
This place is small, quaint, and cash only. The food was decent. The super burrito left me full but I'm a little disappointed in the carne asada. It reminded me too much of the meat out of a Philly cheese steak. It didn't have that signature char and flavor that good carne asada has. 

On the plus side, the pineapple agua dress was kick ass
author: Evan P.

description:
It's unfortunate that I work near this place because I can feel my waste line expanding when my lunch break is over. 
The food is fresh and they make it right there in front of you. And if the line looks long, don't worry. These guys are pros, and you'll be in and out in less than seven minutes.
I'm a traditionalist, so I usually go for the carne asada burrito. It holds me down for the rest of the day.
The building isn't much to look at but you can't walk by that alarming yellow paint job. It pulls you in like a delicious tractor beam.
author: Joel G.

description: The wet burrito here sucks ass and the customer service here sucks almost as bad! They need to do something about this because I don't want to ever return! Also it's a lot of bums hanging around it and inside of it!
author: Anthony A.

description: Got a bean, cheese, and rice burrito. Pretty poor. Won't be going back when there's so many other places to try in San Francisco.
author: Dunstan O.

description:
Am I missing something? Is it because I don't order a fully-loaded anything, ever? Is that also why I don't think Farolito is all-that either, because I don't order the Super Suiza Quesadilla at 2 am? But, still, I shouldn't need to order all-out to have it be pretty darn tasty. 

The chicken is drained from a vat of orange grease and I start to wish I'd ordered carnitas as they look more flavorful and an order of magnitude lower on the grease scale. Love that I have a choice for my tortilla (regular, whole wheat and I think, spinach).

The service is really solid though, always friendly and fast. The burritos seem to be a pretty good deal, too. I mean, I get two meals out of six bucks!?! Hard to beat that. Chips are *not* included with your burrito and for that I am thankful! It's all too tempting. Salsa ranging from negative-spice, positive-salt pico de gallo to deceptively spicy, creamy green tomatillo salsa.

Convenience of this spot is key and I know I'll be back. It's a good deal for dinner and I'm pretty set on trying something off the extensive seafood menu next time. Maybe even their fresh squeezed juices. Carrot, anyone?
author: Alissa A.

description: Unfortunately, the food was not a savory delight. The  lack of flavor left the four of us, in our party, reaching for the horchata and a potent mint gum.
author: Jaz S.

description: This is my favorite taqueria in SF. I've been coming here for 7 years and I always get friendly service. I usually get the super veggie burrito, but the meats here are very good. Love this place!
author: Jessica K.

description: Went in for nachos, got some good nachos, left satisfied :)
author: Otso R.

description:
In the gastronomic mecca we call San Francisco there are so many choices in different types of food for us to enjoy each day.  The cultural diversity that exist not only in the people but in the food, makes this city a special place. 

One food that is a staple in my life, which some may consider "lowbrow" for whatever reason is the burrito. Why do some feel this way I'll never know. However i do know that when I'm out of the country I miss it. 

The combination of meat, cheese, rice, beans, sour cream, guacamole, and salsa all wrapped up in a tortilla is no less than genius. No fork necessary for this meal big boy! It's hands on baby! All you need is your appetite. 

El Castillo is one of the best in this burrito making art. This taqueria is clean, fresh, and has some of the best tasting al pastor and carne asada burritos you will ever experience. 

Even though I'm a burrito whore. Because of the high calorie count unfortunately my love for burritos has to be controlled to once or twice a week. In the words of Rihanna and Neyo: "I hate that I love you".
author: Michael L.

description:
The breakfast burritos are excellent. I'm not usually a chorizo fan, but their chorizo is great - add in 3 eggs, cheese, onions, cilantro, and salsa - it's fantastic.

I usually get a regular burrito with guacamole - their regular burritos are a bit dry, but with guacamole they're fantastic. The chicken is far and away better than chicken at most other taquerias.
author: Matt L.

description:
Been coming here since I was 10 years old. Get the breakfast burrito with chicken. So legit!!!  How cassa Mexicana down the road stays in business beats me.. 
In two completely different world's...
author: Amit D.

description: A few years ago this place was much better. Now the food quality and taste has seriously gone down. Still a good place, just was much better before.
author: M C.

description:
El Castillito goes in the "authentic" column of SF Mexican joints. It's among the best Ive tried. This is not a sit-down ambience environment, but it's lively and the guys at the grill have a sense of humor. 

Burritos: large, lots of meat
Meat: fairly fat-trimmed, well seasoned
Tortillas: wheat, corn, spinach options
Chips: a bit greasy
Guac: watery, not great
author: Tim P.

description:
