I've been here several times now. It's my favorite Mexican restaurant near Castro. There's nothing particularly unique about the menu (they have your typical tacos, burritos, nachos, quesadillas, and fajita/seafood plates), but the quality of the food is really good.

All of the meat is grilled after you order it and you have the choice of mild or spicy salsa and refried or black beans. I highly recommend the super wet burrito. No, it's not super wet, it's a super burrito (add avocado and sour cream) that's smothered in avocado tomatillo or red chile sauce. They then melt cheese over this and pile on some more salsa for good measure. Definitely the most bang for your buck on the menu. 

Which reminds me... just about everything on their menu is below $10!
author: Bryce A.

description: I got a carne asada burrito and it was so good honestly I give it that. BUT. I have this little habit of looking at my food when I want to take a bite and I see a fucking leg. I inspect it more and it's a fucking cockroach. A COCKROACH IN MY BURRITO. THEY DIDNT EVEN REFUND ME THEY GAVE ME A TACO AND THATS IT. It was my first time there and I'm so fucking disappointed and disgusted. I threw up my food when I left and gave the taco to the homeless.
author: V C.

description:
I don't write a lot of five-star reviews these days, but I have to give it up for El Castillito. There's something magical about this little hole-in-the-wall Mexican joint on Church. Maybe it's the comedy duo behind the grill or the friendly cashier lady. Maybe it's the giant and incredibly tasty burritos and free chips. I'm not sure it matters - this is one of my favorite spots to get a burrito.

I usually go for the carnitas burrito; it's delicious and huge. The porkiness is really undeniable. Recently I had a burrito al pastor, which was also good, but slightly less fantastic than the carnitas. My friend always gets the mega-quesadilla (note: may not be actual name), which looks fantastic, but a little too cheese-laden for my taste.
author: Andrew M.

description: This is tough. Most of the bad reviews have been based on the staff and I agree. My best friend lives around the corner from this place so it's frequented enough to write a review, finally. I think the food is great and worth the price. I do have to say that the main guy that takes orders (probably 90% anytime) is either a drunk, homophobic, perv or just a terrible person. He is extremely rude to anyone who isn't a women, but it may be worst if you're a women because he is kind of a perv. I've seen this behavior many, many times. People shouldn't get away with being awful. Don't let them.
author: Zack V.

description: Excelentes Burritos! Deliciosos! Definitely one of the best options while visiting the Castro or the Upper Market. Place is clean and Burritos are delicious!
author: Fernando H.

description: Quick and Delicious!   Veggie quesadilla and Super Burrito con carne asada--can't go wrong.  Lively and friendly staff.  Perfect neighborhood stop!
author: Melissa G.

description:
Went to this place for the first time on Friday per a recommendation from a friend.

Honestly, the food was really good.  I was so pleased.

And then I went and used their restroom.  The lady at the counter told me where it was and I headed right back.  It didn't seem like any of the locks worked so I was focusing on keeping the door from opening. This distraction kept me from noticing employee that was watching me pee from outside the window above the sink. I didn't notice until after I was in the process of pulling up my pants.  I stared at him in disbelief of what was happening, and he paused and then slowly creeped out of view.  Couldn't see his face because it was dark, but I could easily recognize the uniform that all of the cooks were wearing.  Basically he saw me go in and then headed around for the free (non-consensual) show.  I was super mortified so I left without saying anything, except to the next girl that was headed in there after me.

So yeah, not cool.  Don't provide a restroom if you can't guarantee the privacy of your patrons.  Especially from getting creeped on by your own employees.
author: Hallie R.

description: I'm gonna keep it short and sweet here, if you're ever in SF make it a point to come eat here.  A small Taqueria that focuses on the food and they deliver.
author: Dan S.

description:
I love their burritos and tacos!! 
I wish they would have accepted cash tho!!!
author: Bimarsh S.

description: Came here for a dinner and was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the burritos and salsas. Have had this place book marked for some time and finally decided to give it a try. I got the carnitas super burrito. It was a perfect size, matching those on mission (el foralito/taqueria cancun) and the meat was savory and juicy. The salsas were great, a creamy avocado was a great touch and the grilled jalapeños were also a good addition. I liked that they put pico de gallo, onions and cilantro in the burrito as well, most places don't these days. Overall really content with my experience, would come back again.
author: Josue V.

description: Yummy yummy in my tummy. I don't usually write yelp reviews but that was the best burrito I've ever had (got the super vegetarian one with the spicy salsa).  Only $6. Make sure to bring cash and you definitely won't be disappointed if you come here.
author: Andie R.

description:
I'm originally from Southern California and have been disappointed in my quest to find a cheap, delicious burrito in SF that can match what we have down south. UNTIL NOW.

I have not tried anything on their menu except for the Al Postor burrito and I will never order anything other than that. It's divine. Perhaps the greatest thing I've ever tasted. It's so good, that I once got down on one knee in the middle of the restaurant and professed my love to this bundle of meat, vegetables and rice wrapped in a tortilla and tin foil. I came to my senses and sat down realizing that I could not betroth this inanimate food item, but once I took my first bite, I began to experience these feelings all over again.

If you want to know what it's like to be in love, eat this burrito.

Only bummer is that the place is cash only, but as Shakespeare once said, "there is no rose without it's thorns". This is a small thorn to bear and we all must bear it to taste the sweetness of the Al Pastor burrito.
author: Matthew G.

description: I have been on an endless hunt around the city for the perfect burrito and this place comes pretty close. It's not over-hyped like other places in the city so if you're looking for amazing Mexican food, I would recommend coming here. Generally not too busy, and I think I come here often enough where the guy who's always cooking recognizes me. My favorite thing about their burritos is that in addition to adding pico de gallo, they also toss in a handful of chopped onions and cilantro into your super burrito, which I don't see in very many other taquerias. What can I say? It's my go-to burrito spot.
author: Jennifer K.

description: Good, basic burritos and tacos.  If it were a bit more clean I would eat here more often.
author: Phoebe M.

description: This place never disappoints. I found it years ago walking down Church; it looks sketchy but the line often goes out to the sidewalk for a good reason! My go-to is the al pastor super burrito. The al pastor is so so good, they do it right!! My girlfriend had a veggie super burrito and was very impressed as well. The salsa is on point. I didn't get the horchata but it looked really good and people were coming in to get that to go. I was just here last night and fell in love with this spot all over again, and I have always claimed this as the best burrito in the city!!
author: Jessica E.

description: WOW!! If you like spicy, this is the place to go. I came here late one night with a friend and got two of the carne asada tacos. The salsa was WAY hotter than I expected (but maybe I'm just weak) so I used some of the other salsas available to cool down my mouth. It wasn't too busy so that was a plus. The workers are very generous with ingredients and prepare your food right in front of you, so it's cool to watch. Another good Mexican place I would turn to if I want to satisfy my craving.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
OMG, how the mighty have FALLEN...what happened?! 

As a Fillmore vet/native, this used to be my go-to, "I'm needing a burrito, let me take a stroll over the hill" spot. The grilled chicken used to be ON POINT...well-seasoned & flavorful, with just the right kick from the salsa. Tonite?! WTH?! NO TASTE WHATSOEVER...& I do mean NONE.  HOW do you make flavorless pico de gallo?! Please, please, PUHLEEEEEEEEEZE ungentrify & get back to what you all used to do oh-so-well...I can't with this BS y'all are dishing out at the moment!!
author: Amoura B.

description: I think this must be the best burrito  in town. I always end up having the super burrito with spicy chicken and it's so so good! The staff is always smiling and it seems like they have a good time at work witch I think reflects in the food.
author: Lisbeth H.

description:
MEAT eaters rejoice!  beyond the language barrier and family of flies you will find a place that will do you a solid if you in love with your favorite cooked meats.  I did have 1 piece that had some gristle.  Those that choose a SUPER will get proper dosing of meat unlike many places that load up heavy on rice and beans.

CASH only

Pro tip
park in the safeway lot and walk across.  salsa is just ok.  :(
will be coming back
author: Stan L.

description: The quesadilla castillito is delicious.  -1 star for inconsistencies from visit to visit.
author: Kelly M.

description:
I love this place.
We go here at least once a week and never were disappointed! I always go with the spinach tortilla super veggie burrito and it's amazing! 
Even though I am not a bug meat eater and really picky with chicken i even like the meat burritos here!! 
Cash only, parking at Safeway
author: Caroline K.

description: I picked this place instead of the other Mexican joint down the street because this one looked more divey, a little dirtier, more legit/authentic. Burritos were had, but they were really dry. How did I find the one disappointing Mexican place in SF?!
author: Vivian H.

description:
Went here yesterday. My friend has been coming here for years. They have a variety of DELICIOUS vegetarian options. 
My friend Carlos told me that the guy making our burrito's was new. He was extremely skilled with much experience, friendly, and made me the perfectly wrapped burrito. It was so easy to keep it neat while eating it I was surprised. Not only that it was perfectly delicious. He put the perfect amount of everything and the ingredients were fresh.
There are many varieties (maybe like 6) salsa that you can have as much as you want of. 
They also have grilled jalapeños next to the salsa's.

I was planning on eating half, but that didn't happen.
They also have the option of spinach wraps.

I didn't expect to find something healthy and delicious here. I was pleasantly surprised. It is a cool location, and a nice area. Lots of places to sit. 
Right across from safeway.

Try it out, I heard this spot has won best burrito spot in SF a few times. 
What do you think?
author: Karina G.

description:
If you live in San Francisco, chances are you've eaten at a dozen different taquerias. Our family has been going to El Farolito for over 20 years...until we discovered this gem AND it's right by our house. This place is hands down at least 1000% better. My favorite filling is El Pastor and OMG they make the best. As minor as it is, this is the ONLY place that I have ever found that will grill the (white) onions to put inside my burrito. Their red & green hot sauce is the bomb, they don't charge extra for chips and they even cost less. 

I had a craving for one of these yummy burritos and drove down there at midnight to find them closed. How sad! So I drove to 24th street to our old spot and I can tell you know after 20 years, I am never going back. There was no comparison. Sadly that was suppose to be my last burrito (for awhile anyway) before the big "D" today. 

If you've never been here, come! Pay attention to the hours b/c I didn't, use to the late hours in the Mission but it's probably a bad idea to eat late anyway. cheers
author: May G.

description:
Im from Mexico City and this place is like eating from my mom's kitchen =) 
Best Taqueria in SF.
author: Carlos O.

description:
If el farolito is my committed beautiful wife, el Castillito is my mediocre side piece.

I walk by el Castillo all the time when I jump off the "N" line and I have always been intrigued; taqueria-looking yet clean, simple menu and always a full house... all good signs right!? Plus the "people on yelp love us" sign (though faded) doesnt lie. Although my interest has been sparked, I never found a reason to pop in until recently after a fun-filled day of laughter, coffee and Dolores park with Mrs. Angie N./L.

Imagine this: sitting in Dolores park, slightly hungover... stomach rumbling. You know el farolito is a few blocks down but el castillito's bright yellow sexy self keeps popping up in your head as an alternative. Seeing as it's on the way back to the train, we opted for something exciting and new and trekked on over en-route home. 

Coming in, youll strut down a few steps and down a runway to Mexican goodness. Menu is similar to its counterparts in the neighborhood: tacos, dinner plates, burritos, quesadillas, nachos. Simple, just the way we like it.

I opted for the quesadilla castillito: any meat, cheese, avocado, sour cream, tomatoes & jalapenos. I went with carnitas but I do applaud that they offer a bbq pork option as well (which is what i shouldve gotten). The meat was seasoned well, large portion, not stingy on the sour cream nor guac and dripping with grease; just the way the mexican food gods intended. 

Angie N went the safe(r) route with the enchilada plate: two enchiladas with your choice of meat, cheese, and sour cream. Like her food idol & hero (me), she went with the carnitas as well. When it comes to taste/quality, see above. The saving grace was the portion: enough to feel her, the Army of the Czech Republic (Armáda České Republiky for those historians) with enough to take home and eat the next day (as I ate microwavable peasant Safeway). Tis life my friends, tis life.

What it comes down to is El Castillito is solid mexican food, healthy servings at a low price point while in the area. Do I beg you to go out of your way leaving you singing its praises from the rooftops? Nah. but the fact that we spent +/- $17 for a food coma and leftovers speaks volumes.

Stay faithful to your wife (insert: taqueria of your choice) but definitely get a taste of El Castillito (that cute little receptionist after a drunken happy hour) while in the neighborhood. Itll be good, not great, and will leave you remembering why your heart is where it is. 

Arriba!
author: Ryan L.

description:
CARNITAS SUPER BURRITO REVIEW

Flavor: excellent. 
Quality: I'm sorry to say I have become a burrito snob. I ordered the super burrito with carnitas and black beans. And while the flavoring was great, the meat REALLY bothered me. It was extremely fatty. I ended up picking most of it out. And then leaving the last couple bites of my burrito (I'm never one to leave food behind on my plate...). It was also so greasy that it was dripping down my hands into the plate. Way too greasy. I also want to say there was no guacamole! Which does come with the super burrito. So that was definitely a bummer. Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing bc this place was super busy. Lots of people coming in and out. 

I heard a lot of people order the veggie quesadilla. So if I ever happen to be in the area I will try that. However I won't go out of my way to go back. 

Good service. Friendly staff.
author: Elena R.

description:
This place is not SF's best Mexican restaurant, but it sets the standard for SF taquerias.  The burritos are excellent, and I think that this place is the place all other taquerias in SF should be compared to.

Clean, everything is cooked before your eyes.

Tasty,  Great salsas.
author: Joe S.

description: Everytime I come to San Francisco I make it a point to get a supreme carne asada burrito from here. I love it!!!!! It's delicious!!!! The employees are also very nice and it's like a welcome for me. It's cash only so make sure you're prepared. They have an atm machine but no one wants to pay fees. You can also go to Safeway across the street and buy a water or soda and choose cash back. Definitely check this place out, it's worth it!
author: Private I.

description: The $5.99 regular burrito happy hour is Mon-Thurs from 3pm-5pm which is $1 off the regular price of $6.99. Choose your meat and tortilla (I had the carnitas and whole wheat) which is then heated on the grill then choose your beans and salsa. The happy hour price does not come with chips. The service was fast and the burrito very tasty.
author: Bill B.

description:
My favorite burrito spot in all of SF. As someone who was born and raised in this city and pretty much tried most of the burritos out there to offer I would put castillito up against anyone

Been loyal to this place for a decade already and plan to for a whole next one. 

Honesty if you have been living in the church market area for at least longer than ten years I am sure you can remember how clutch this place was back in the day when the blockbuster was still open. I can def remember going to blockbuster grabbing a flick then stopping at el castillito on my way home for what would be a great night.
author: Julian S.

description:
Got the carne asada torta and couple tacos.

YUMYUMYUM. I love LOVE LOVE spicy food and their salsa was burning my tongue and I was in spicy heaven (or hell, however you look at it!).

Definitely coming back. Location is convenient as it is right off of the Church MUNI station.
author: Heather R.

description:
WOW. the Al Pastor super burrito is what dreams are made of. 
The flavors, my goodness, I can't remember a time where I have been more thankful for having a tongue that can taste every last molecule of flavor provided by the mix of amazing ingredients inside the al pastor super burrito. 
I will be loyally coming back here like a fish needs water.
author: Tuwie N.

description:
I live very close by so Castillito is my go-to whenever I'm craving a solid burrito.  I always go for the carne asada super burrito and I'm never disappointed.  There salsas are delicious as well, especially the green avocado-y one!  

I just wanted to make a quick warning in reference to a review that I noticed earlier.  I would try to stay away from parking at Safeway when visiting Castillito.  Ever since the new Whole Foods was finished, Safway has cracked down on people that are parking in their lot and not visiting their store.  Unfortunately I was the victim of this while away from my car for no more than five minutes to reload my clipper card at the Church and Market station.  Just be warned.  In my experience parking tickets have a negative effect on one's appetite and that's the last thing you want when you're heaving a massive Castillito super burrito home for dinner.
author: Matthew G.

description:
went here to eat on a business trip loved the food
seating was full but worth the waite
author: Joe P.

description: Omg so fabulous I thought I was back in East L.A.! We ordered dos tacos de carne asada, a Super Burrito and a Wet Burrito al pastor. Quality, flavorful ingredients thanks to dedicated, talented chefs. If I still lived in the City, I'd eat here every day! For now, I'll have to settle for taking the Duboce Avenue exit off the 101 whenever I'm in town. Gracias, amigos!
author: Valerie M.

description: I'm a sucker for salsa verde and this stuff is as good as it gets! Now I've tried 3 or 4 taquerias in the Mission District, but Castillito gave us sooooo much meat. My pastor and carnitas tacos were absolutely the best. I wish I could sit here and gaze upon tiny cuplets of their salsa verde for hours.
author: Roxy M.

description:
Meh. We were craving for some Mexican food and this was the closest joint we could find on Yelp. 

Service was ok. Nothing crazy, mainly self-service. The menu prices displayed online are NOT accurate. It's at least a dollar more.

We got the meat quesadilla and a super burrito. It was about $15. 

THEY CHARGED YOU FOR EVERYTHING. They charged for bags, foil, take away utensils, you name it. 

I won't be coming back here.
author: Sharon G.

description: All I got to say is I don't understand how this place has solid 4 stars I'm guessing people do not like flavor and enjoy bland burritos? Ugh disgusting got a carne asada super burrito and it was one of the worst burritos I've had in the city. Save time and money and go to the mission that's what I should've done. Couldn't finish the burrito ate half and thru out. Out of meat beans cilantro sour cream guacamole pico de Gallo that was supposedly "spicy" I tasted mild tomatoes. This place is authentic as taco bell minus the flavor and spice. Never again
author: Bryan P.

description:
Despite being pricey for $7.50, I get a NICE, FAT, JUICY & LUCIOUS piece of Carnitas meat in a Pesto Tortilla. 

I'm talking about my Super-Burrito, you "Degenerate Freaks"!
author: Matt G.

description: Best al pastor burrito in the city. Period. Make sure to get extra green salsa, also some of the best salsa in the city.
author: Teryll H.

description: Visiting SF and based on the reviews I decided to check this place out since it was one of the few open late. I have to say I was highly disappointed. The carne asada had no flavor and neither did the beans. Only thing I enjoyed was the red salsa. If your looking for a quick meal then this place might be for you. But if your looking for good Mexican food I recommend you get your money's worth somewhere else.
author: Fran R.

description:
I grew up in LA eating Mexican food, I'm not saying that makes me an expert, I'm saying I'm adddicted. This place is so perfect for me. Sooooooo perfect....Humble, consistent, great. 
I've lived in the city for a couple of years I eat here at about once a week, when I go to other places there is always something El Castillito has over them.
author: Andy B.

description:
Oh My Goodness!! This place is sooo amazing!!

Keep in mind this place is CASH ONLY!!

I fell in love with the Taco Bell wet burrito and only had it twice but never got the chance to get one from a "REAL" Mexican restaurant. I knew I had to get it once I seen it on the menu.

It was so delicious. I only ate a quarter of and because it was so humongous and took the rest to my boyfriend. He held up well and he loved the red sauce on top of the burrito.

I love the salsa hot sauce bar they have. All the sauces are tasty and good.
author: Cel Y.

description:
We came up here for lunch yesterday. It's hard to compare to the renowned taquerias in the Mission since I haven't really gone to enough to provide an accurate assessment, but looking at chains such as Chipotle and other small burrito shops around SOMA and North Beach, I'd have to say that this place is tops!

We ordered a chicken burrito and a veggie quesadilla. I was concerned when I saw a burrito shaped wrap on the grill, thinking they'd confused my order and I was getting a burrito instead, but apparently their definition of quesadilla is "burrito cooked on the grill, without tinfoil". Except to use a fork and knife to eat this thing, it's pretty much impossible to pick up.

When thinking of other quesadillas I've had, there's one place that stands above what I had at El Castillito, but in fairness, this was so vastly different from the mushroom quesadilla I've had elsewhere, I can't say one was better than the other. And really, this just wasn't what I was expecting. It was like a burrito, but it wasn't. It was supposed to be a quesadilla, but it wasn't. 

But there's one thing I can say definitively about it.

DELICIOUS.

Service was interesting, you order at a counter where you can actually see the cooks and food being prepared. It was a tad slow for some things to come out, but it's worth the wait for delicious Mexican food.

If you find yourself up in the Castro area and craving lunch, definitely check this place out. The prices are great and the food excellent.
author: Cassandra J.

description: My friends came in here drunk, and raved about the burritos, so we tried it this Sunday. I got "El Castillo" quesadilla, and it was daaank. Free chips and salsa too.
author: Will J.

description: Stopped in for lunch with co-workers. Got 2 super tacos which were messy but delicious. Not empty but not super crowded or overpriced like many other places in the area. Will be back!
author: Zack C.

description:
Had the Chicken Super Burrito. This was the The Best burrito I had in San Francisco! Plus not all the liquid that a lot of Mexican restaurants give you in their burritos.
Just finished the left overs, mmmmmm, delicious. 
Great price too with free chips and salsa!
I ate at El Farolito a couple months ago in the Mission because of all the positive Yelp reviews, I was underwhelmed.
author: Brad N.

description: Food is great (got super burritos), but chips are not good and lady cashier gives really bad service. Cooks are friendly and give good service though. Cashier lady got mad at me because she didn't hear me say I'm eating there. So she grabbed the two bag of chips back and angrily shoved a tray of chips at me.  Since she didn't like me, I sent my husband to ask for a bag for our leftovers, and the lady got mad at him for asking!  Good food but I'll consider other taquerias with better service before coming back.
author: Katharine P.

description: Made right in front of you. This is the real deal if you want a burrito. Had the super burrito and it could be cut I  half and enough for 2 people. Must go.
author: Robert B.

description:
Went there for dinner last night, I suppose it was pretty full.

There were only two people in line ahead of me, but the second person ordered 4 burritos, so it took a while for me to get to the front. They prepare ~2 burritos at a time, so you essentially order and wait for it. Once you're at the front, they have all the meats warm and ready, so they only need to be grilled for a minute or two before you have to eat it.

Make sure you ask for avocado. It's fresh, and they'll only put it on if you ask them to.

All in all, my meal (1 regular burrito) cost about $7, and was awesome. I'm probably going to go again, since it was that good.
author: Shale C.

description: had ah shrimp buritto here it was the bomb.com juicy spicy ..everything was good i shulda got 2
author: Joseph R.

description:
I crave this place about once a week on average, and for good reason. It's DELICIOUS.

My go-to is the super burrito al pastor. It's so different than burritos I've had in the past, with flavorful and well-cooked meats, swimming in delicious sauces. 

The line moves quick on busy nights and the dudes that cook up the food are pretty cool. I like how they never seem to be getting stressed out despite how constant the flow of customers seems to be.  

A few knocks: their chips aren't great (they taste a little flat and stale). Across their salsa bar, I've only found a couple really nice salsas, and they too don't always seem very fresh. Consistency is also a slight concern - I've found based on time of day, chef, and level of 'busyness,' quality can vary. I also wish they stayed open later!!!!

Definitely check this place out if you're looking for a cheap, gut-busting burrito -- especially if you're outside of the Mission (it's definitely better than other options in the Lower Haight and immediate vicinity).
author: Greg K.

description:
Absolutely the best in SF taqueria.  The meats are all in the steam tables ready to be quickly incinerated on the grill prior to going into your final taco/burrito destination. I have tried just about every item here and have never been let down.

All the empolyees are nice and they make the food one-at-a-time so it is quick and always 100% correct.
author: Thadd L.

description: Whenever I hear people say that such and such place has the worst mexican food, I always silently think "el castillito hasn't closed yet...has it?"
author: Kelvin B.

description:
Driving home out of the Hayes Valley i spotted this place to the right of me with a parking spot right in front of it, how could I not stop there!  Anyway what could have been a very messy drinko de hot mess celebration turned out to be not so bad,  El Castillito had a lot to do with that.  Nothing super fancy or out of price range from all the Taquerias scattered throughout San Francisco this place is just one of those right time right place need a meat fix right now dealios, and they do it pretty well.   Would love that they took atm/ debit payments because I rarely carry around cash anymore.

Thank you El Castillito, went from being a sloppy drunk to focused and centered after consuming one of your cane asada Suiza's and would be glad do it again and again.
author: B H.

description:
El Castillito...donde estas mi amor? Te necesito. Te extraño mucho!! 
This was the "go to" place when I lived in the city for myself and a handful of amigos. I have known plenty of great burrito places in my many years in California, but this lil sweet hole in the wall is mejor que todos. I tend to not consume carne asada very often but I cannot help myself when I am here. One may think San Diego would have better taquerias but that is not the case! San Francisco takes the top spot and El Castillito tops them all in the city. I made a point to stop in last year while in SF.....until we meet again!
author: Friitzy G.

description:
Definitely one of the best, if not the best, burritos I've had since coming to San Francisco. I had the carne asada super burrito and it was fantastic. Carne asada is tricky because chewy, fatty beef will ruin the entire thing, so unless you're positive it's good, it's a roll of the dice. The gamble paid off at this place, it was tender and delicious. great ratio of rice/beans/meat/etc. 

On top of the burrito, the tomatillo salsa was insanely good with the side of chips. 

Not much else to say about this place; really glad I went. It's cash only, so make sure you've got a $10 handy.
author: Steve B.

description: Nice little Mercian place. The people are nice and good paintings on the wall. All the menu look good. I just wish it just wasn't cash only.  The castillito quesadilla with chicken is bomb!
author: Aldo G.

description:
In short -- I frickin' love this place. 

I went to school just a block from their Civic Center location, and I ate there at least once a week for three years.  I've moved to southern California, and oh how I miss it.  There is no better burrito in the state.  No kidding.  Every time I visit SF, I stop by and grab a huge burrito, or the amazing "quesadilla castillito."  So yummy.  

Sadly, the Civic Center location is closed.  (Temporarily, I believe, due to a fire.)  The Castro location is almost (though not quite as) good.  Also, it's a bit cleaner.  

Next time -- and every time -- I'm back in SF, I will be enjoying a delicious meal at Castillito.
author: Sy N.

description:
Its...LUNCH TIME!!!

Lets hit up the cafeteria! Bleh...how about the cafe?...BLEH!

Coworker: ROS, how about the taqueria on Church St..

ME (Ros) : oooh OOOOKAY!!!

15 minutes later, drove to Church Street. Pulled up and parked right infront of El Castillito (PIMP PARKIN) and walk inside to no line...(VIP) hahah 

The place is clean, and the staff is friendly. My coworkers ordered super burittos while I on the other hand ordered a Chicken taco salad minus the rice. =) The coworkers said they enjoyed their burritos and it was scrumptious. My Chicken Taco Salad was very delightful! I totally recommend it and I for sure recommend this taqueria spot. 
PLUS, all orders get a bag of chips! yay! This place is definitley our near the work spot taqueria carry out place.  I'm most certain that you and your coworkers will enjoy it too!
author: Rosalyn T.

description: Burrito was good. Didn't think it didn't lived up to Mission standards. Salsa bar was great. Size are tortilla were also good. Ingredients and mix were ok.
author: Tom F.

description:
As a proud Arizonan, I take pride in the quality of our Mexican food, even to the point of ardent pride, such as when amateurs foolishly think that California is the only place one can get "legit" burritos. 

As a result, I ventured into the SF burrito scene with a bit of chip on my shoulder, especially in light of the travesty that is Nate Silver's voodoo burrito bracket shenanigans. Never trust a sour cream lovin Midwesterner to do the job of a born n' bred Southwesterner is all I'm saying. 

I tried El Farolito first. Pretty tasty, but not really any better than most places back home. It seemed like my assumptions of the false superiority of SF burritos were confirmed...that is until a friend also visiting SF at the time for a conference turned me on to El Castillito. He and his wife had gone there the day before and both swore by it. This got me excited, so I checked their hours. 30 minutes till closing time and I'm in downtown. Guess I'll have to wait until tomorrow. 

...But I couldn't take the wait. I ran out, hailed a cab, and explained to the bewildered driver that yes, I need to get this burrito before they close in a half hour, so step on it! The confused driver dropped me off well before the correct location telling me this is where I needed to be. I didn't argue. I had business. Dressed to the nines I old lady power-walked it up the road. 

The joint was just what it was supposed to be: small, non-pretentious, and straight ahead. After getting eye ball interrogated by the too-cool-for-school kiddies I made my way to the front. One pork al pastor taco for here, and a regular carne asada burrito to-go, please. 

Down to business. I inhaled the taco in record time. A large portion of perfectly seasoned pork al pastor with ample onions and cilantro on top, nice soft, fresh corn tortilla, and excellent tomatillo salsa, pico de gallo, and spicy red salsa. Should have order two, dang-it. 

In an exercise of supreme self control I somehow, someway, saved most of the burrito till the next day. Round two was just as good as the first. This was what I was looking for in a burrito. Expert balance of flavors and pro burrito rolling. 

I hated to admit it at first, but this was one fine burrito. I clearly stood corrected...but only to a degree! It was not significantly better than its AZ counterpart (and yes, this is a valid comparison as AZ and CA Mexican food is, by-and-large, not an apple/orange comparison); however, this was one superbly done burrito that I would wholeheartedly recommend to anyone.
author: Eric B.

description: Meet point for locals, mex and American taco lovers! Loved it. I had shrimp quesadilla and natural fresh carrot juice
author: Aline M.

description:
Fresh, from scratch food that is clean, simple, tasty and super filling for a very reasonable price. 

Lots of vegetarian options and every meat you can think of. Beer and agua fresca made in house, but no margaritas. Watermelon agua fresca was too sweet for my taste and they only had small or enormous for sizing.

Don't let the dinginess of the interior dissuade you. They put their effort into the quality of the food.
author: Zack F.

description: You've had better, but if you live in the area, you sure as shit ain't gonna walk further.
author: Concerned Parent ..

description:
IMHO I think El Castillito has the best burrito in SF... Blasphemy I know. But here's the deal - their burritos have the most moist, flavorful and delicious meat out of any place in the city. Plus, they give you a mammoth portion of meat in your burrito - they do not skimp and the carnivore inside of you will do back flips!

Get a half chicken/ half pastor super burrito and you'll be in burrito heaven! I promise you will enjoy every savory morsel, but I am warning you to be ready to waddle out of the place after you eat, because the burrito bomb here is one hell of a gut buster. A single burrito will keep you full for a long time. 

A tip for those who don't want to unbutton their pants to make room - ask them to cut the burrito in half to share w someone or to have a snack a few hours later.

It looks like a hole in the wall... and that's all the more reason to go check it out!
author: Justin O.

description:
Dear El Castillito, 

Sometimes I miss you so much it hurts. Your veggie burrito haunts my dreams. Your verde sauce is the stuff of legend. Please send someone to NYC so they can get a clue.

Love,
Me
author: Cerise G.

description:
Yom Kippur is a tough holiday. Not only are you asked to feel bad about yourself (which, if you've been raised Jewish, isn't that hard), but you're also supposed to abstain from food and drink for 25 hours. That truly sucks. 

If you've been raised right, you know that having to fast means that you can eat copious amounts of whatever the hell you want beforehand (gotta get those calories in somehow!), and if you've lived in San Francisco you know the proper choice is the Super Burrito: a foodstuff that is virtually a categorical imperative in any situation. The super burrito is the a priori choice for the mad hacker (fingers flying on keyboard to "stimulate the economy"), the homeless man with seven bucks and change in his pocket, the graduate student, the drunkard, the Jewish boy preparing for a fast (Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses). Google, Twitter and Facebook be damned, the Super Burrito is San Francisco's gift to the world. 

After a run of bad burritos in some of the Mission District's most vaunted slab-houses, I decided to return home to El Castillito, which has been producing consistent badassery in the form of Super Burritos for as long as I've been in The City. The al Pastor remains some of the best in the city: tender, well-spiced, saucy, with enough onions to provide a toothsome bite and a hint of sweetness. Thats not to say that I wouldn't say no to their cinnamon-touched chicken, or their tender steak, but to deny the brilliance of their Pastor is grounds for a Torquemada style inquisition, a 5150 hold, and/or immediate deportation to Nebraska. The day that Castillito's Pastor disappoints is the day the world ends: meteors will fall from the sky upon the Mountain View campuses, Larry Ellison will apologize for being a massive dick, I will go on a successful date (Fire and brimstone coming down from the skies! Rivers and seas boiling! Forty years of darkness! Earthquakes, volcanoes! The dead rising from the grave! Human sacrifice, dogs and cats living together... mass hysteria!).

At the best, the burritos here are earth-shattering, defined by marvelously griddled to flakey tortillas, totally melted cheese, fantastic guacamole, delicious rice and beans. The ingredient mix is often spotty, with a little too much sour cream, rice segregated at the bottom, etc. and I could ALWAYS use a little more spice, but the liberal application of some of their hell-raising chiles torreados usually fixes that right up. These are damn good burritos, comically sized, and easily able to take on their Mission District brethren in both flavor and value. 

Thanks to El Castillito, I made it through my 25 hour fast with nary a pang of hunger (Alright, thats a goddamned lie, it sucked. It always sucks. Its supposed to suck). 

Overall: 4.5 Stars, rounded up because of their succulent al Pastor.

Extras: 

While eating at the street-facing bar, take a moment to admire the totally awesome folk art on the ceilings (look for the aztec warrior done in the style of Da Vinci with a step pyramid covering up his junk).

Chips suck, salsas are marvelous. So it goes.

Horchata (and other augas fresca) available in up to 32 ounce containers.

CASH ONLY, GODDAMNIT (I swear, if I hear another tech bro complaining about that in line...)!
author: Casey U.

description:
For the past 7 years I've been getting the same thing - veggie burrito with wheat tortilla, no cheese, black beens, spicy salsa, extra onions, cilantro, and tomatoes...then drench it in the green salsa from the salsa bar...mmmmmmmm

And all for around $5 and counts as 1.5 - 2 meals for me
author: Just Chillin B.

description:
Breakfast Burrito review:  The breakfast burrito at El Castillito has just one meat option: chorizo, but it's big! 

The burrito is pretty tasty & not greasy which is a plus, but they do mix the chorizo into the egg so it's one single egg-meat mashup which I personally don't prefer as much.  I also wish they had bacon as an option but at least there were no potatoes - yay!

It was a decent breakfast burrito but just didn't have any sorta kick or wow to it.  I've been before for their regular burritos which are pretty good, but if you are looking just for a breakfast burrito it's good that they have it but I'm still on the hunt for the best in SF.
author: Gene X.

description:
Great al pastor.
Burrito after drinking nearby is amazing.

The torta bread as only so-so - get the al pastor burrito.
Great salsa bar too
author: Kent T.

description:
This the place where I ate the last burrito of my road trip before coming back to France. And it's actually the only one I didn't managed to finish (and believe me, it doesn't happens very often) !
So this place has become kind of a legend for me. I recommend it especially for foreigners that are hunting for THE californian burrito.
author: Lucas V.

description:
Best taqueria in the 'stro. Best tasting, best service, competitive hours and prices. I been going to this place off and on for over 3 years now, and I been to all the mexican joints in the whole district. This place takes the cake. 
They are WAY more friendlier than any other taqueria place period. It is cash only and I was short a dollar. I tell the lady I will be right back and she takes a dollar out the tip jar. I come back from the atm with $20 in hand and she wouldn't break it for me. 
They also have a big thing of meat constantly roasting that they carve for all you meat connoisseurs out there. 
The cooks are also nice, patient and they don't get irritated when you are indecisive. Every time I come in I never have a poor experience, they consistently succeed expectations.
author: Tim V.

description: So far, I've fallen in love with quite a few taquerias in SF.. but this place has THE BEST al pastor you've ever had. Carne asada tacos were amazing, too.  The line is long but well worth the wait.  They make your food right in front of you and their guacamole is die for.  I saw a hundred people eating their quesadillas so they must be legit.  Put the salsa verde on EVERYTHING.  Burritos are so spicy you'll be sweatin!!! Do eeit.
author: Kristine L.

description:
When I lived in SF (not that long ago), my apartment was up the hill from El Castillito, and I would often stop in on my bike ride home from work to pick up a burrito for dinner -- or, on the weekend, for a vegetarian burrito for lunch (the latter only half-eaten, because even without meat, it's really too much for a lighter meal).

No doubt, part of my fondness for the place was proximity to my home (though there were two closer burrito joints that weren't nearly as good), but I -loved- this place.

I spent some time checking out more famous burrito joints in the Mission, figuring if my local was this good, others must be -fantastic- -- and found some that I thought were comparable -- but none I thought were better.

I suppose it's odd that, when I lived in SF, the one thing I missed most was being able to get a decent deli sandwich; and now that I'm back in NY, the one thing I miss most is the ability to get a decent Mission-style burrito.

I've been back to SF on business trips twice since moving away, and both times, made a point of coming back for more.
author: Greg C.

description:
Best vegetarian burrito in the city.

No, that doesn't mean they just take the meat out and give you extra guac with your beans and rice. There are actual VEGETABLES in this burrito! Broccoli, carrots, mushrooms, zucchini, onions in a spinach tortilla. And it was roughly $4.60. Mind. Blown.
author: Emily H.

description:
El Castillito is my new favorite. Though lesser known than it's counterparts in the Mission, El Castillito offers up quality Mexican food at prices that those counterparts can't compete with. Tucked away at the last retail space on that side of Church street, the storefront is unassuming and certainly no-frills...but don't let that deter you. All the food is made to order--like, actually made to order--not like Chipotle, and served piping hot. The portions are generous and the staff is super friendly and attentive.

All that said, I always order the All-Meat burrito (sorry, veggies) with carne asada, which comes with cheese, salsa, sour cream, and guacamole...the perfect burrito, in my opinion. And if you ask nicely, they'll throw it back on the griddle for a minute to add some crisp crunch to your tortilla once your burrito is all rolled up. 

Do try the pastor as well. But do it in a taco over a burrito. The meat is very flavorful and seemed a bit overwhelming in a burrito. 

Go there. It's one of only a few hidden burrito gems in the city.
author: Brian K.

description:
I've mostly lived in places where burritos are things you buy at Chipotles and Qdobas. A filling, affordable, sort-of-balanced meal; reasonably tasty, but not memorable. The couple of burritos I've had at random Bay Area taquerias didn't really change my mind.

El Castillito has succeeded where the others failed. I got the carnitas super burrito. Nice, crispy chunks of meat instead of the mushy blob of pulled pork you often get. Combined with the rice, sour cream and onions, you end up with a mixture of flavors and textures surprisingly similar to biryani with raita. That's not something I expect a burrito to remind me of, but I'm not complaining. (It did need a bit of salsa for heat and tanginess, to complete the illusion.)

In addition to the above, the super burrito comes with beans (black/pinto/refried), cheese and guac, on a grilled tortilla. If you are wondering why burritos are kind of a big deal in San Francisco, this is one of the places that can clear that up for you.
author: Nath A.

description: Such such such a fan. I love my burritos here and the cook cracks me up every time. I always go for the al pastor, but the steak is bomb too.
author: Colleen F.

description: Haters are going to hate, but this is my favorite taqueria.  I usually get huevos rancheros, and this place nails it!  The flavor I'd say is a little better than average but where this place shines is portions and the cheap price!
author: josh m.

description:
I absolutely love this place.  Best hangover cure EVER, by far, is their breakfast burrito.

Not only was the cook friendly and very polite, he spoke to me in Spanish which was not just specific to me (which I thoroughly enjoyed since I speak Spanish) but I noticed he was teaching every customer a little but of Spanish - how adorable!

My friend and I also opted for the fresh squeezed orange juice and it was DIVINE.  There is literally a machine that looks a bit like Dr. Octavius from Spiderman and it funnels oranges into a machine and YUM! The results are absolutely fresh orange juice.

My favorite part even before I bit into my burrito was the fact that the cook wrote "Te amo" with an adorable heart smiley face - made my morning.

On to the burrito itself - the first bite said it all, it was absolutely heavenly.  A combination of eggs, chorizo, cheese, onions, salsa and cilantro grilled to perfection.  It was juicy and so good, I nearly ate the entire thing.  And this puppy was huge.

Everything about this place made me happy - I shall be returning soon!!!!!
author: Lauren B.

description: My friend and I both had pretty bad vegetarian burritos here. I enjoyed the spinach tortilla and appreciate them melting the cheese but there was nothing good about it unfortunately.
author: Katie B.

description:
Had a vegetarian burrito the first time I went here. It was great.

Had al pastor the second time. It was chewy and fatty.

Friendly place. I'll come back, but I'll stick with the veggies.
author: Chris M.

description:
Best carnitas burrito in the city. No muss, no fuss here. Good prices and huge portions.

Cash only though.
author: Chelsea S.

description: Fast and tasty.  Love the al pastor.  Portions are very generous and prices are fair.  Regular burrito is the same size as the super, just w/ out sour cream cheese and guac.  They don't seem to charge more of you ask them to add guac to a regular.
author: Aaron P.

description:
This little burrito joint was a great find. I stumbled across El Castillito during one of my long journeyed walks which happens all too often, I might add, with my lack of directional sense. Hey, I'm still learning my way around, alright?

Moving on.

Although tiny in size, this place was completely packed and full of grumbling bellies ready to feast. Always a good sign when good food can draw a crowd. I decided to order the ceviche tostada and a taco salad. The servings were pretty much on point. Perfect for anyone who loooves to feed their gut with nice sized portions.

My ceviche tostada was simple and had a generous amount of avocado. The taco salad was packed full of rice, cheese, veggies, and a nice slice of tomato right on top. The salsa bar is small, but has all the necessities. Love the fact that I can load up on the pico de gallo. Yum!

Service was quick. Food was good. Price was great. So far, I've found that El Castillito dishes out the most bang for your buck. I'm talking cheap ladies and gentlemen... and for SF, that's freakin' major! I've actually encountered some darn pricey burritos in this city. Well, you don't have to worry about that with this place, that's for sure!

This joint also offers fresh pressed fruit and vegetable juices.

I would definitely come back for another bite or two!
author: Ann S.

description:
Great food
Great people who work there
excellent salsas and chile's
Fresh drinks including fresh carrot juice
My pick for good burrito fare in this area!!!
author: John R.

description:
The Quesadilla Suiza is the best combination of fats and carbs that I had in 2012. 

80% cheese, 15% tortilla and 5% ambrosia. Pretty sure that's the ingredient list.

I also shared some carnitas nachos with a friend, and they were loaded to the brim with toppings and was enough for probably 3 people. I forgot that I don't like pork so I didn't really eat much, but my friend certainly got the bang for our bucks.

But back to this quesadilla suiza. It's not the normal folded tortilla filled with cheese and cut in triangles, it's more like a flattened burrito. It's hefty and cumbersome and just so delicious. If any tacqueria can sway me away from tacos into ordering something else off the menu, it's going to be damn good and I would never order anything but the quesadilla suiza from here.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Food is good. Ordered super burrito but got regular- should have checked or watched them make it. Also had to wait while they served the Spanish speaking customers, who came in after me, first. 
Not likely to come back!
author: Michael K.

description: I've eaten a good amount of burros & el castillito serves the best one I've ever had.
author: cory m.

description: This was my local taqueria for about a year and they consistently hit the mark. It's not haute cuisine, and they're not reimagining Mexican, but  they do make excellent tacos and burritos. There are a lot of options in this area, and further south towards the mission, but the staff is always good-humored and friendly, the service is quick, and the salsa is excellent.
author: Nick M.

description:
I love this place! I make it a point to stop by and get a burrito here at least once a week. They are always friendly and consistently make delicious food. I usually get the regular veggie burrito because it's amazing (the super veggie is excellent too). The spinach tortilla takes the burrito to the next level. 

Usually there's not much of a line, which is great! However, on weekend evenings be prepared to wait 10 minutes or so to order. It's totally worth it. They are super efficient and can manage rushes seamlessly, so don't be discouraged by a long line. 

Also, be hungry when you come here because the portions are generous. :)
author: Vanessa G.

description: So good! Fast, friendly, cheap. And oh yeah.... DELICIOUS. Super burrito with chicken. Every time. Anyone who lives in San Francisco knows these cheap burritos are a dime a dozen, but this is one of the best!
author: Denis M.

description: Great taqueria!  The vegetarian quesadilla is awesome!  Fresh ingredients and nice and crunchy off the grill.  I've never been to a taqueria that also has fresh juice.  Highly recommend!
author: Erin D.

description: Best mexican in the city... PLEASE don't tell your friends about it.
author: John T.

description:
This has been my favorite burrito spot in the city for the last 6+ years.

If you want a great burrito, check this place out. Delicious Mexican food and fast,, friendly service every time.
author: Natalie O.

description: I don't get why so many people love this place? I got a carnitas burrito with black beans and I ordered guac. They forgot the guac. So I got some on the side. Without the guac, this was the most mediocre, dry burrito I have ever had in my life. I was not that much of a fan of the carnitas meat as well. Was it okay? Sure. Would I go back? Probably not.
author: Ashley H.

description: A little hole in a wall place on Church St, but food is really good and service is very friendly.  We ordered pork burrito and beef quesadilla to go.  They weighted a lot and both were delicious.  The cooks are very efficient and you get your food very quickly.  They are also open late.
author: Keiko Y.

description: I came here because of all the stars it got. The carne asada was bland and so were the beans. There is absolutely no love put into this food. Why would you not season the food? I had to drown the food in salsa and guac to get some flavor. Why does this place have so many stars? Oh wait, there's a pot dispensary across the street.
author: William B.

description:
This place is outstanding and rock-steady.  You can eat here every day and it's all good.

It's possible to order badly -- don't get a "wet" burrito.  And by the time you get your fajitas, your friends will be halfway done with their burritos.  Stick with a queso or, better yet, a burrito, and you'll be good.

As other reviews say, the meat quality is good.  You're good to go on the carnitas and the carne asada.  Their pico de gallo is particularly good, so get your super burrito with everything.

Good ingredients + an efficient and serious staff means good, consistent food.  Don't forget to stock up on that green salsa~
author: Charles D.

description:
Awesome neighborhood taqueria. Its a very casual, order at the kitchen window kind of place, and everybody who works there is really friendly. They are always happy to throw some avocado on whatever you're getting (usually no extra cost), and their Al Pastor is killer. 

Big fan of their Quesadilla Castillito (you can add rice to it, its like a grilled burrito) and their burritos are great as well. If you like spicy salsa, go for their verde tomatillo/avocado salsa - its spicy and delicious.

One thing to note - if they ask you if you want Jalapenos, theirs are pickled, not fresh, so if you get them be ready for a vinegar element to your food.
author: Jake L.

description: Awesome cheap burritos and one of my go-to burrito places here in SF.  Fast and efficient.  Love the green salsa, probably the best green salsa I have found in SF.
author: David M.

description:
Woah what? Total accidental find. So happy we were starving and needed a 4pm taco. I just walked up to the window, pointed at some meat that looked good (apparently carnitas), got a taco with everything, and wished I had bought a whole burrito with the stuff. (The burritos looked AMAZING). $2.89 for a massive and ridiculously good taco is fine by me.

Still dreaming about the carnitas...
author: Jessie M.

description: Best al pastor burrito in SF. Order the pastor super burrito and forget everything else. Get carne, pollo, etc elsewhere.
author: Eric W.

description:
I don't know very much about taquerias, as I do not go to very many of them. Not that I don't enjoy this type of Mexican food, I've just never felt the need to go anywhere other that El Castillito. It is simply the best and most consistent taqueria in town. 

Walking down three steps is hardly a basement, get over it.  The pastor is about as good as you are going to get, the the burrito is the bomb. Leaving out the rice and beans might not be for everyone, but it's the best way to savor that pastor goodness, and I recommend giving it a try. Pastor tacos are 5 bite experiences of joy. 

The chicken is awesome too. And a generous serving of chips and sides finishes the meal. Want more salsa? Why, just walk over and get some, self-serve guarantees you'll ways get the exact amount you want. There's even a few carrots there for good measure. 

El Castillito rocks it.
author: Mark C.

description: Life in the city can be a little fast at times, sometimes you don't have time to sit and eat at a restaurant, or cook a meal.  When I'm on the go and want something, quick, good, and reasonably priced, this is the spot.  I'm usually in and out in 5 minutes.  Burrito is a no nonsense, delicious, well wrapped delight.  The cooks, are no nonsense, be on your toes because the questions will come fast.. "what type of tortilla?  Meat?  Beans?  Salsa? For here or to go?"  If you're dicking around on your phone it can be confusing and hectic.  But if you're alert, ready, and hungry, then your in for a smooth ride.  Their strawberry ague fresca is crazy good.  And they make many salsa, all of which are awesome.
author: Nick T.

description:
They don't hold back on the salt or the heat at this hole in the wall taqueria.  The tacos seem relatively expensive ($2.89 for meat tacos with cilantro & onion, $3.29 for fish tacos) but they do give you more meat than average.  There's a salsa bar (the whole roasted peppers aren't that spicy but they're really good; the green salsa is way too salty; the smoky looking red salsa is extremely spicy)!  The al pastor is cooked on a vertical spit and shaved off (drool).  In addition to tacos, they have burritos, quesadillas, seafood plates, tortas, fresh juices, breakfast items, etc.  Meat choices: carne asada, al pastor, pollo, chorizo, carnitas.  Where's the cabeza, lengua, etc.???

* Al pastor taco:  Finely chopped, fatty, tender marinated pork explodes with delicious flavor...but it's also very oily/greasy.  The meat is served on two chewy corn tortillas, with onions, cilantro and hot sauce (optional)
* Fish taco: Small pieces of mild, tender white fish, lightly coated, appear to be pan fried (yay, it's not deep fried).  The coating on the fish was too salty but the salsa and lettuce helped.  The fish taco features two corn tortillas, onions and cilantro.

I believe free chips are included. 

The ambiance is suitably dumpy/gritty with a jukebox, painted ceiling, their awards and ATM.  They even capture all the action on a security camera (bonus points).  

Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Nothing compares to the carnitas and al pastor here, but seriously, nobody has written about the WET BURRITO? 

On a cloudy, intermittently rainy day in SF, a wet burrito is akin to a chicken noodle soup for the belly, or a warm hug from mom.  Don't forget that underneath all that sauce, guac, salsa, sour cream and cheese is still a giant burrito that is akin to a hug from a large relative, somewhat suffocating and painful, but still warms your heart. 

My only complaint is that the cilantro still carried a bit of gritty dirt, which made for an unappetizing end to the meal. 

Needless to say, the price ($8) plus speedy service, and the perfect spiciness in the chili sauce justifies why everyone else loves them.
author: Sharon F.

description:
Best burritos in San Francisco, I've been eating here for about 10 years and it's consistently never let me down!  I used to live a few blocks away and would eat here several times a week, now that I'm not so close I still try and find ways to get down to Church and Market so I can get my fix (don't be fooled, the El Castillito here is better than the other locations!)

I've tried a lot of taquerias all across California over the years since I've discovered El Castillito and nothing comes close.  Still my favorite place for burritos after all these years!
author: John H.

description:
I will always come back to this place when I'm passing through the area. Service is fast, the food is overall very good, and portions are nice.

Some of their meats are better than the others, and it can depend on the day/time that you arrive. Symptomatic of any restaurant that precooks a ton of each meat, stores them in tubs on a steam table, and then reheats them to order, the meat quality can vary widely. I suggest that you LOOK at each option before making your choice, go with what is fresh.

My regular salsa review:
-Green: Nice and thick, tasty, and doesn't skimp on spice. This is my mainstay
-Red: Chunky, you can see the nice sear on the ingredients that went in, a bit watery. Great on chips but can flood a burrito if you pour it straight on.
-Jalapenos: In addition to the standard marinated version, they usually have whole jalapenos that they grill in-house, which are excellent.
author: Name R.

description:
$6 for the best burrito I've ever had. Plain and simple.

The burritos here are massive. I always get a regular burrito with al pastor as the meat, and it is amazing. The burritos are so big that I can't even finish an entire one, and I eat a lot of food!

Also, don't let the looks fool you. It might look like a dive, but the food and quality is top-tier.
author: Mike H.

description:
Favorite burrito in the entire world. Price is crazy for what you get. Notable mentions:

Al Pastor anything (amazing)
Fish Burrito (no one else gets this but i love it)
Nachos (massive!)
Chorizo Breakfast Burrito

All the burritos are good. What else can you say? Quesadillas too.
author: WeAreAllLamp L.

description:
GET THE AL PASTOR.

Not that I don't get it at every taqueria I go to...but it's really really good here. Incredibly juicy and flavorful. The al pastor super burrito is my second favorite burrito in the city. For 3 years I thought this place was absolutely unbeatable, but Guadalajara just barely edges it out. However, this is still my second favorite place to get mexican food in the city and the location is perfectly convenient. The burritos here taste like you are biting into a fluffy cloud of goodness. They're huge and filling but have an airy and pillow-like quality to them that is just amazing. 

On rare occasion, the al pastor has been a little off...sometimes it just doesn't taste as fresh as it should, or the fat will be the kind of fat that you would rather pick out than bite in to. But these alone are not reasons to avoid this place. Make sure to stop by if you're passing by. Don't let the fact that it is not in the mission sway you (in fact, the Mission location is much worse). 

You won't regret it.
author: Zachary S.

description: If u want tasteless food, dash here!!! This place will look for the cheapest ingredients to server u. Never again!!!
author: Humphrey M.

description:
TL:DR; It is what it is. There's no surprises. Whatever you're expecting, you'll likely get exactly that.

The PLUS
Food made right in front of you, it's far from pretentious

PRICE
Most dishes range from $6-$10. Fairly inexpensive. 

GUAC
not thick, not bright green, not sour(which is good)

CHEF MIKE
Cheese is melted onto beans using the microwave

FREE SALSA
Lots of free salsa, keep hitting the salsa bar, there's still salsa. eat it! there's a lot and it's free with your meal!

BURRITO LETHARGY
This is the kinda burrito that makes you slow down while eating it... because you're getting kinda sluggish, tired. It's heavy. non-energizing.
author: Shawn S.

description: A fun sitcom-like scene. A man who makes a taco - with some flair. (Order in Spanish.) Really good avocado salsa. Worth your patronage. Wish the grilled chicken were white meat and fresher.
author: Andrew K.

description: These guys are talking more with each other than to listen to the customer's order.I repeated myself 3 times and still dis not gey guacamole.The burrito was cold and tAsteless
author: Gilbert L.

description:
Little neighborhood tacqueria.  
Good, meaty, flavorful tacos.  
Goodness gracious, you must try their fish taco! It's incredimazing.  
Complimentary water.
Everything is priced right.
author: Elaine S.

description: I love this place. The fact that they toast the tortilla makes this the best burrito around. 5 stars!
author: S. M.

description:
I can't say anything bad about this place. I love the food and the people who work there. 

If you are going for a breakfast or to cure your hangover huevos rancheros and their juices will do the job.

PRO TIP: The only way you can make your experience better is bringing a real fork and knife with you.
author: JL B.

description:
I go to a lot of taquerias and I typically don't review them because they don't really stand apart from each other unless they are really fantastic or really bad. El Castillito on Church stands out as my go-to place in San Francisco for fast Mexican food and I find myself here almost every other week. There are many great things about this place that stand out.

-As many have stated, the al pastor is fantastic.
-They have one of the best carnitas burritos that I have had.
-The people working there are great.
-Good salsa bar and free chips.
-If you are grabbing something to go you can park in Safeway across the street for a few minutes, so parking is never an issue.
-My wife is a huge fan too.

Downside: Cash Only
author: Frank J.

description: I always either get a chicken burrito, chicken torta or a shrimp burrito with avocado and have always been satisfied!
author: Fallon P.

description: It's not a Mission taqueria, but if you don't want to walk to the Mission, you can come here. The food is decent, and the staff have always been polite. The food isn't memorable, but I always get a kick out of eating in the back room because it feels like I'm dining in a cave!
author: Denise B.

description:
For less than $5 you can get an amazing veggie burrito:  Zucchini, mushrooms, carrots, broccoli, onion, peppers than have been pre-cooked to an al-dente finish and finished on the grill. I get mine with all the other veggie fixings - lettuce, 2 kinds of beans, hot sauce, salsa onions, cilantro. The tortilla is heated to perfection and even after a ten minute walk home, the burrito's still hot. 

The chicken isn't breast and can be a little greasy at times - but it's good. The salsa bar has a nice creamy-thick guacamole/tomatillo type salsa. And vinegary (which I adore) style poco de gallo. 

I frequent the other El Castillito locations (which do have stewed chicken breast. The locations near Hastings) but this one is the only one with the cooked vegetables.  

If I am walking in this neighborhood I'd recommend this veggie burrito far over Estrella Taqueria off Haight. Estrella doesn't have a salsa bar. And although they can make you a mushroom or broccoli burrito to order, it's just the one veggie and often still somewhat raw even after cooking.
author: Josh O.

description: Best spot in the city to clog your arteries with. Pastor/carnitasl super burrito, it's love.
author: Drew W.

description:
My god.  One of the things I was looking forward to in moving back to California was good Mexican food.  Little did I know that I'd find such a great spot in a short amount of time.

Everything I've had here is good:  the carnitas, carne asada, and chicken are served in giant portions and extremely well seasoned.  Cilantro is packed into each burrito, along with a serving of chips and salsa.  The cooking staff is extremely patient and forgiving, which is a big plus considering all the characters that walk / saunter / fall into the restaurant.  Finally, the location's great -- right off the J and a stone's throw away from the N.

One thing I can't emphasize enough:  the portions are huge.  If you eat an entire super burrito, be sure that you can handle a busted gut for a few hours afterward. After I finished my carne asada quesadilla last week, I felt like I just received a late-term immaculate conception.
author: Bill H.

description: Taco salad was prepared using a microwave - yuck!  Decent prices, low quality bad tasting food, decent service, cash only.
author: Jason M.

description: They have wonderful food it's always fresh if your a meat and seafood lover is suggest that you try the camorones con asada which taste fantastic they always have a line but it goes by pretty quickly
author: Prince J.

description: I have to say that they don't make their own chips- that's a huge no-no. On top of this, their guacamole was highly disappointing. I had their shrimp burrito which also felt a little more like canned food versus fresh produce... go to Pancho Villa. Much better selection and better quality.
author: Carolina S.

description:
Best dive burrito in SF.   Nothing fancy.  But delicious.

Large portions on the burritos.  Cheaper prices.  
Staff is really friendly.

They also toast their tortillas on the grill, instead of steaming them.  Much tastier.

And their self-serve pica de gallo and salsa bar can't be beat!
author: Jag A.

description:
Eh nothing special, I certainly wouldn't go out of my way to come here. I ordered a regular vege burrito which wasn't great, had hard avocados in it, salsa in burrito wasn't so fresh. I ve had way better vege burritos for equal or less amounts of money. 

For someone who visits many different taquerias in the bay area I would not consider them top tier or even close.
author: Chris T.

description:
I am on a mission to spread the word that Castillito has the best burritos in SF. I've been everywhere, and years ago used to frequent various spots in the Mission that everyone insisted were the best. Yet this place tops them all. Huge, generous portions packed with just the right combinations and proportions of ingredients (we've all had those burritos where all the good stuff is awkwardly shoved to a corner, right?) I recommend the super burrito, breakfast burrito with chorizo, or the wet burrito. I would bet that the other food is amazing too but I am so obsessed with those that I've literally been unable to try anything else. I'll live.
The staff is super friendly, the ambiance is hole-in-the-wall festive. Compare these burritos to another place like Cancun that people worship and I think you'll see there's no choice.
author: Virginia W.

description:
No frills.
GREAT al pastor.
Ample seating.
Sit by the window for free entertainment :)
author: Ken B.

description:
The Quesadilla El Castillito is spectacular! Enormous as it is, it slips down the gullet quickly and easily due to the sheer wanton deliciousness contained within.

Fish burrito (special) pretty good too. Will be returning.
author: Tim H.

description: I have been hearing so many awesome things about El Castillito so I was glad when I finally made it over. Traditional Mexican taste is rarely a found in San Francisco so I have been dying for authentic Mex Food. My quesadilla was out in maybe a minute. Like an actual count of 60 to 90 seconds. Very quick. Though, I guess with a few available menu items that kind of stuff is quite common. My quesadilla was A +++, not only that it was perfectly delicious, but it was also crunchy and oily. El Castillito did not let me down. Great food for the price, I am glad I stumbled on this place!
author: Rosemarie R.

description:
AMAZING!!! 

I LOVE this place! I would go here every single day if 7 Jeans came in Sumo wrestler sizes, but since they don't I must restrain myself from pitching up a tent in the corner of this place and moving in.

The place is very, very clean, and the guys at the grill are so, so, so sweet!  The burritos and quesadillas are amazing: super fresh, loaded with cilantro, and the guacamole and meat are fantastic. The meat here is so incredible. The vegetarian quesadillas/burritos are amazing, too. 

Other pros: prices are great (La Taquiera on 25th and Mission has gotten a bit pricy). Also: they don't overload your burrito/quesadilla with rice filler like some places in the Mission do. They add an appropriate amount of rice, and then lots of meat, beans, etc. Awesome bang for your buck. Aguas frescas here rock.

Paradise!!!
author: Jessica L.

description: Very solid tacos without having to go all the way to the mission. Small, simple, clean. Great pastor and great chorizo tacos. If you're not too keen on super spicy, you may want to give the cook a heads up and tell him to take it easy on the salsa - it's delicious, but very hot.
author: Thorben S.

description:
One of the best burritos I've had in the city. All of the flavors are there, and it tastes authenthic--not that watered down wannabe Mexican food. The portions are huge and the cooks are always super friendly and generous with their servings. Especially when you become a regular. 

My favorite thing there is their quesadilla suiza with carne asada. Wow. For only 6 bucks, it's probably the best quesadilla I've had. With tender, flavorful beef and piles of cheese, and the option to add your salsa or sour cream, it is soo damn good.

And that salsa bar. I have friends who buy jugs of the spicy green salsa, with hints of cilantro in it. It is spicyyyyyyyyy. Just a heads up for all of you who prefer "mild" when asked a salsa choice.

The prices are all very reasonable in comparison to most other taqueria's, and theyre open late too. 

Always coming back here for my Mexican food fix when near the Castro/Duboce Triangle.
author: Ashley V.

description:
El Castillito's al pastor super burrito is worth getting on an F-car for.

Recommended? = Oh yeah.
author: Chris R.

description: I got a regular carnitas burrito when I first came to my local taqueria.  After admitting that Casa Mexicana was cheap, but bland, I decided to try her neighbor.  Boy, was I disappointed.  I decided to give Castillito another go and this time decided to splurge on the super burrito and on a whim, selected Al Pastor as my meat.  It made all the difference.  The juiciness from the marinated meat along with the cheese and guacamole made the burrito a perfect flavor bomb.  It's essentially the best burrito I have had in my history of burritos.  The only chink in their armor are their chips.  Really mediocre.  That said, they probably have the best tomatillo salsa in the city. It's thick with the perfect heat.  If I had the will power to only eat half a burrito and save the rest for later, then I would come here more often.
author: Jeremy G.

description: It's cheap and fast and the servings are large. It's a hole-in-the-wall for sure, but it didn't really hit the spot in the way one would expect a run-down Mexican restaurant with 1 $ to do.
author: Philihp B.

description:
My favorite burrito place in the area. The carne asada, carnitas, al pastor, and veggie burritos are all great. Plus, expert burrito wrapping.

Order directly from the guy doing the grilling, and he heats up your meat/veggies/tortilla in front of you. Make sure to stand by because he'll ask if you want cheese, lettuce/onion/tomatoe, spicy, etc. 

The chips are terrible. I always pass on them.
author: Carolyn F.

description:
Being a native Richmond District cat, GORDO was always my #1 SF choice. 
But EL CASTILLITO has won my heart AND stomach over!
author: DG K.

description:
El Castillito's super burrito is really good. Whether I get al pastor or chicken, it is always tasty, one of my favorite burritos in the city. I should note that their al pastor is awesome. 

While the super burrito is one of my favorites, I don't consider El Castillito to be a five-star Mexican joint because their tortas and super sauzas are just at par, certainly not bad items though. 

I also like this place because it gets hole in the wall status in my book. You walk down a few steps as you enter and there is nothing but four or five tables, counter eating space and a good salsa bar in the fairly small establishment - plus the register and kitchen in the back. The staff is cool too. 

Closing words: Get the super burrito and you'll be happy. It is immense and very tasty.
author: Mark B.

description:
When I lived in SF, this was absolutely one of my favorite spots. Living in between the Lower Haight and the Castro, it was definitely convenient and much closer than all of the more popular Mission burrito spots. It's right outside the subway tunnel/track switch, across the street from Safeway, so it's also easy to get to via Muni, if you don't feel like hassling with parking.

That said, it's not as though El Castillito was just a cheap substitute. Fat, just on the verge of exploding burritos is what they slang here. 

It was cheap to eat here 11+ years ago. And when I recently returned, I was pleased that although adjusted for the time, the burritos are still very affordable. And given the aforementioned size, a single burrito can easily feed two. 

It's cash-only here, so make sure to get cash back at the Safeway before you head in. No fountain drinks either (just canned sodas) if that's your thing too.

I can only dream of burritos such as these when I'm foraging for Mexican food where I am now.
author: Cee A.

description:
Great food and very reasonable prices. The salsa bar is kickin and the fried jalapenos are nice!

5 stars cause its cheap, portions are nice and the employees are swell. 

Deff goin back again soon.
author: Franky G.

description:
(standing ovation....)
(tears streaming down my face.....)

Brava, El Castillito.   Brava.

You make a damn fine burrito.  Damn fine.

During a recent discussion I came to the conclusion that if i die in a plane crash and had not eaten here at least once within the 3 weeks prior, i will most likely return in ghost-form to haunt this place.  

Unfinished business is such a bitch.

What a horrible way to die - never having satiated my mexican food desires.  Always longing and yearning for one last bite of carnitas smothered in salsa verde.  They would see my shadowy figure hovering above the grill and hear me crying softly into the pinto beans at night.    

And just to fuck with people I will probably speak to the customers in that warbling ghost voice "o0o0o0o - I aM thE GhOsT of EL CastilLiTo0o!!- O0o0oo0'  

I would most likely be a friendly ghost (unless you pissed me off), not opposed to donning a white sheet topped with a sombrero and a fake moustache - just to liven things up a bit.  I would hope to become some sort of a local legend ~ and El Castillito could earn a spot on one of those San Francisco Ghost Walk Tours.  Kirsten the Ghost of Mexican Cravings.
