And if you are nice to me i just might make extra avocado fly across the room into your burrito.  Ghosts can totally do that kind of shit, you know.

But seriously, folks.  This place is so bomb i  would die unhappy not having eaten here one last time.  Thats how much i love it.  Nuff said.

UPDATE - Walking past here the other day i couldnt help but notice the painted ghosts in the window!  Weiiird!!!
author: Kirsten S.

description:
The nachos are HUUUGE! Before you go out, get an order and put it in your fridge at home for the late night munchies! Trust me, you'll be back on yelp giving this place 5 stars Sunday morning. 

When you're sober, they're filling, and decent. 

Lotsa salsa varieties!
author: Em L.

description:
Good things about this taqueria:

1. Awesome avocado-based salsa: it's spicy and creamy and everything you want and it's just sitting there for you consume as much as you like.
2. Actual vegetable burrito with actual vegetables. I don't actually eat this ever but my vegetarian sister appreciated and haven't seen this option very many places.
3. spinach, tomato, whole wheat tortilla choice. OK it's small but the small things stand out, man

Full disclosure: This was my first neighborhood when I moved to SF, so of course I have a sweet spot...but it definitely wasn't the first burrito I ate, and since then I've had tens of thousands of burritos...and hey, come to think of it...I don't think I've ever eaten at El Castillito while drunk. Part of me says: that makes my review more valid and the other part says I need to remedy this immediately. Is 10:29AM too early for beers?)
author: Robert K.

description:
Went back. It is one of the better burritos I have had in SF but I still don't understand how not a single place in this city knows how to do Mexican food right. The meat is decent. The hot sauce isn't very spicy at all. The gauc is too watery. If I am craving a burrito there is a chance I will come here but it is just so hard to justify the unhealthiness because it just isn't that good. To say the least I miss my San Diego mexi joints.

I would recommend El Ranchero Grande as my #1 if I had to recommend a spot.
author: Pat W.

description: Cheap delicious Mexican food. I love their salsa bar, especially their green salsa. I've been going for years.
author: m m.

description: My wife and I have been coming here every few weeks for about 10 years. She is addicted to the veggie quesadilla, and I usually get that or the super veggie burrito. I also get the mixed juice (orange, carrot, celery, beets). We love this place.
author: David A.

description:
One word describes El Castillito:

B   urrito
I     s
G   inormous!!

I got chicken + added guac. Free chips with order. Will definitely come back to try their tacos, plates, and this reeeaaaallllyyy delicious-sounding veggie burrito! :)
author: Kei H.

description:
Everybody loves knowing about a great late-night grub spot - my go to favorite is El Farolito at 24th and Mission. 

But how about a middle of the day visit - when the El Farolito "urine smell and filth on the floor experience" just won't do? No need to worry - El Castillo on Church is just as good(!) as El Farolito - minus the scruffy - y'know - everything.

+ 2 stars for tasty food and very cool line cooks who can joke and kick it with you while they're making awesome grub. Hats off.

+2 stars for very friendly service and a very clean salsa and escabeche bar.  One of these stars is for the excellent green salsa.
author: Mark S. I.

description: Love their food. The employees/owners(?) are super nice too. The food makes me thirsty though!! But I LOVE it. Yum.
author: Maryam M.

description:
This little burrito castle located in my favorite neighborhood. I'm so thankful for. 

The super burrito is really just that -- SUPER.  Really.

Why. Are. You. Still. Reading. This. 

Just go already!
author: Janice C.

description: Very convenient as it is next to the muni stop. I love their agua frescas and salsas. I have ordered their nachos, shrimp queso and both were great. I love that I can see them making my order. They ask you along the way what you want on your order which I prefer because I usually forget an item or two when just ordering at the cashier. Never a let down at El Castillito.
author: Bri R.

description: Oh Castillito, you so sketch. Food is decent. Kitchen staff can be burly which makes sense, it's stressful and noisy, but still no fun dealing with.
author: Heather R.

description: Been going here my entire life, favorite burrito in the city. Granted, proximity factors in a bit but this is without a doubt the spot for me. Cheap and delicious, with an awesome special vegitable burrito (no need to ever order the super vegitarian) and really good pastor.
author: Gavin M.

description:
Consistently excellent food at a bargain price. I routinely eat the wraps they serve and 
I've never been disappointed. Always friendly and fast service. What seals it is the price. Why pay 15 dollars when you can pay 8 for better food. A gem.
author: David B.

description:
After trying most of the taquerias in the mission + church area, I decided that this would be my go-to spot. 

The torta al pastor is a killer. And the staff is always friendly and willing to exchange a few jokes.
author: Mark D.

description: Delicious - go for a quesadilla, it's like they fold up a whole burrito into a pouch and throw it back on the grill until it's golden, crispy, and melty, it's amazing.
author: M S.

description:
they are great , they are around for a long time .
always smile at you .
the super veg burrito is the best.
author: B H.

description: I dislike most of SF Mexican food because I've lived in San Diego and had the good stuff. BUT this place has super tasty and fresh meats. 'Nuff said.
author: Josephine C.

description: Hot damn. Kids were transformed into wolverines by bean/cheese burritos, wife's nachos will feed her for three days and my burrito al pastor was fucking spectacular. There's not a lot more to say.
author: Jack K.

description: Who wouldn't want a giant burrito late at night? I got a super carne asada burrito and the bf got a carne asada quesadilla. The burrito must have been 12" long and 2" in diameter. It was gigantic. I really liked the rice; it was seasoned perfectly. The beef a bit chewy and I think they left it too long on the griddle, but the other ingredients mask that flaw well enough. Their guacamole is super thin & watery, and they're pretty stingy with it. Their free tortilla chips are awful though, but that's okay. Overall, I'd come here again.
author: H. L.

description: I used to come here all the time when I lived nearby, and stopped in recently to see how the years had treated El Castillito.  I am happy to report it's delicious as ever.  Most recently, I tried a carnitas burrito with all the fixings.  The meat was juicy, savory, and there was fresh avocado slices in the place of guacamole.  So good.  We ate in the restaurant, but this is also a perfect take-out spot.
author: Heidi M.

description: I dont know how everyone likes this place? I am full Mexican and this was by far the nastiest mexican food ever! Their beans taste like can beans and they barely put any beans/cheese/meat etc in my burrito. Not to mention they only take cash and their atm machine charges $2 + to withdrawal. Never again for me.
author: Annie Q.

description: The only thing I like about this place is their chips and salsa. That's it! Unfortunately, their burrito is dry and they put very little meat. I want to say that I love it but I dont.
author: J C.

description: Best carnitas in the city in my opinion. Why go to the mission when it's right by the train stop? They put the carnitas directly on the grill to crispen it up while they do everything else. Chips are free. Cash only which is a bummer and it's more expensive than other mission burrito places in my opinion
author: Tommy W.

description:
Heads up--- CASH ONLY, they have an ATM inside, but theres a Wells Fargo across the street in Safeway.

I love this place! I've been coming here for at least 7 years. They know what i want, without me having to be specific. They have great steak burritos. Yummy! I always order a Steak Burrito with x-tra cheese, Pinto beans, salsa liquido, cilantro, avocado & sour cream! I just discovered their quesidillas and OMG they are sooo good too! The Super Quesidilla comes with the works!! DELICIOUS
The food is fresh, plates are huge, and the price is just right!
author: Sara C.

description: I don't like Mexican food but I came here because I didn't want to be a Debbie downer. I figured "since IM here I might as well go all out" so I got enchiladas with chicken and the spicy green sauce with rice and beans. IM dreaming about it as I write this review. It has almost been a week since this affair and this weekend we will meet again!        CONS: the place is small, I wish they had Margaritas, and the enchiladas take longer because they hear them up in the microwave so that the sauce and cheese is hot. But it was delicious!
author: Jazmyn W.

description:
Another solid burrito joint. After a couple hours of World Cup finals watching, we trekked up the hill to use a coupon we had for El Castillito, buy two burritos get the third one free. Score! 

I got the super burrito with chicken. All the ingredients tasted really fresh and the chicken (which can often taste bland) was uber flavorful. They also have whole wheat tortillas which is fantastic because it tastes and feels a lot healthier than just a doughy flour one. 

The only downer of the experience was that my super burrito included cheese and they conveniently left that out...that's the best part!
author: Julia N.

description: This is probably my favourite place in the city for a burrito. It's big, it's juicy, and it's delicious. And I like that you can explain how your burrito made like you would at Subway, for example.
author: Andrew D.

description:
El Castallito, I love you. When I moved out of the City to Los Angeles, I used to get requests from my then girlfriend to take a cooler along for the sole purpose of bringing back a vegetarian burrito from El Castallito. Seriously. They are that good.

The options are numerous - chicken, carne asada, carnitas, vegetarian - all of them are tasty. The burritos are large, available in standard flour, tomato, wheat or spinach tortillas. Pinto beans or black beans, tons of fresh veg, and oodles of gooey queso are standard. The salsa is also excellent, with a special shout out given to the avocado salsa (which most reviewers are referring to as salsa vere).

But hey there, Georgie Girl, there's more to EC than just burritos (even though they are consistently rated amongst the best in the City on BurritoEater.com - and I don't care what anyone says, they are BETTER than Papalote). The tortas are out of this world, the quesadillas are basically extra cheesy burritos sans beans (unless you go vegetarian) and the chillaquilles are top notch. I've yet to get something there that was disappointing.

EC has a few locations, but I find the Church St. joint to be the best option. Throw them an extra buck in the tip jar, get your huge bag of chips and the avocado salsa to go with your meal, and voila - you're in heaven.
author: Jonathan M.

description: Spot in burrito and authentic atmosphere. Cook is rude and coy when ordering, but I wouldn't have it any other way. Try to get a window seat. Great people watching while choking down a fatty.  Make sure to try the sauce bar. Small cups on top.
author: Tim L.

description: Great little place. Found it on accident via Yelp as I was scoping out potential spots for us to eat after checking out the murals in the Mission District. Service was really friendly. They had tons to choose from. I got the fish tacos and my husband got a burrito. I couldn't believe how massively large his burrito was! It was tons of food but very good and well prepared. They also had a number of different salsas available. This is definitely a popular spot. I wish I was able to finish my taco as I fell ill. Unsure what it was. But from the one taco I was able to eat, it was very good! We'll definitely keep this on our list the next time we're in town. And hopefully I won't come down with a strange bug so that I can fully enjoy and savor every bit!! Oh and this place is cash only. There is an ATM inside but be mindful if you don't want to pay those pesky fees.
author: JH P.

description: Solid, which is good in SF considering the number of sub-par mexican options around. Great veggie options, I like their taco salad
author: Mayur A.

description:
Ryry and I's go-to spot for Mexican!! We go at least once a week and Ryry goes about twice a week with his friends!

Their fish tacos are delicious! A super fish taco is less than $4. If you order "the plate", you get rice and beans at no extra charge and it's about as much food as a burrito.

I usually get my fish tacos regular style which comes with salsa (either chunky or not but I get them to put both chunky and non-chunky really spicy ones on my tacos), cilantro, onion and pay a little extra more for avocado. The fish is lightly floured and then grilled - so simple and delicious!

Fish burritos are pretty spot-on, too.

Their agua frescas are thirst-quenching. They have different flavors everytime: watermelon, strawberry, peach... yum.

The service is impeccable! The guys there are so nice! Marcos, Adrian and Juanito!

This is how Ryry and I are greeted when we go into El Castillito:

Marcos: Hola, primo! (to Ryry and a nod to me)
Us: Hello!! (drooling as we approach the grill)

When putting in our order:

Adrian: Para for here? or para to go? (with a smile)

When asking us what we want to top our tacos with:

Juanito: Quieres mas.... marijuana?? Heh, heh! (meaning, cilantro!!)

Those guys are great!! =)

Sometimes, we get here a little late... Say, 10:45pmish and they've run out of fish... =( But since we know the guys... and come here so often... every once in a while they'll cook up a new batch of fish just for us... how sweet! and delicious!
author: Christine C.

description: LOVE this place. Cheap, fast, delicious.  Everything is super fresh, huge and wonderful.  Absolutely recommend.
author: Julie B.

description:
The burritos were really good. Not overstuffed and lacking flavor like many places in the area. I wouldn't say they are good enough to come out of my way for, but if I'm walking up market I'll definitely come a little bit out of the way.

Oh, and the atmosphere is great. Watched a man get arrested outside while I consumed my food. =)
author: Colin O.

description: This is by far my favorite veggie burrito in the city. It's so good. You should just go alone so that you can enjoy your little piece of heaven at your own pace. Definitely don't bring your recent x boyfriend, because let me tell you, things will get real, and before you know it you will just be sweaty and confused, having just stress-binged that burrito in about 60 seconds flat.
author: Cassie B.

description: Huge, delicious, cheap and casual. Everything you can ask for in a taqueria. They do not skimp on the goods either and the guys making the burritos are ridiculously nice. CASH ONLY (but there's an ATM inside lol)
author: Jess C.

description: Great burritos.  Was visiting SF from NY and heard from friends that this place was good - they were right.  This place is pretty legit.  Thumbs up for the burrito al pastor + cerveza.  The quesadillas are also beautiful.
author: Michael R.

description:
This is the place that reintroduced me to tortas shortly after I moved to SF in 1998.  The Castillito version isn't really faithful to the type you find in D.F., but it's so good in its own right that it deserves strong consideration for the best torta in the city.

I've ordered enough tortas in this place over the past 8 years at this location that I know all of the guys at the counter, and they don't even ask what we want anymore (down to my wife's Al Pastor/Chorizo WITH tomatoes and my Carne Asada/Chorizo WITHOUT tomatoes).  This is one of the few place where I consider myself a regular, and it always feels great to get this sort of treatment.

Aside from the standout tortas, the tacos & quesadillas are excellent.  The salsa is awesome, actually amongst the best in the city.  I won't comment on the burritos since I don't think they should even be on the menu.  This location is easy to get to, at the crossroads of Church & Market.  Muni stops just up the hill, and parking is easy because there's a Safeway across the street.
author: Michael F.

description:
Possibly one of the best burrito joints in SF...definitely in the top 5.

Had a super burrito with Pastor meat....it was delicious. 

No complaints. Perfect SF burrito experience. This place is up there with all the rest
author: Mario W.

description: A taqueria is supposed to be a hole in the wall, and this is just a touch nicer than that.  So the sit down eating here is a good, comfortable experience, and the super burritos are excellent.  Al Pastor spiced pork, sliced up into small pieces, was fantastic, and there was no skimping inside the burrito.  The only issue was that it was slightly out of the immediate Mission area that most taqueria's seem to be located in so it was a little off the beaten path, but that was a good thing as the area was not dodgey.  And that's a really good thing when all you want is to fill your belly with pork, guac, cheese and salsa.
author: Dave N.

description:
I have no idea who wrote that first review back on 8/8/07. It couldn't have been me, as I think I just had one of the best veggie burritos ever. Packed with veggies, loaded with black beans in lieu of rice, wheat tortilla and lettuce at no charge, all under $5. Score.

So good in fact, that the first thing this yelping atheist thought of after a proper Easter Sunday burrito dinner was you know, if I'm wrong about this whole Jesus thing and he does come back, I hope he stops in for a Castillito burrito on his first trip to SF. He'd deserve it and would totally be worth the couple thousand year wait.

A burrito worthy of Jesus. If he exists. Which he doesn't. But just in case he does. That's five stars.
author: Jason B.

description: That place is out-of-control good.  In fact, it could be the best authentic fast casual Mexican restaurant in the city. The burritos and Quesadillas are outstanding and relatively inexpensive.   I don't consider myself a big pork eater but their el Pastor is a treat for the ages.  Do yourself a favor and come here.
author: David H.

description:
Skip the menu up top and look for the paper on the wall that says VEGETABLE BURRITO.  Order it.  (It's different from the Vegetarian Burrito, in that, it actually contains a pile of actual vegetables, including broccoli, etc)

Unbelievably good.
author: DH H.

description:
I seem to land here every now and then. The high-3 is because of it's location, the grilled ingredients, and the tortas. 

Generally, I cannot distinguish them from the other spots i go to so it will have to do, for now. But i can say, I go here for the tortas con carne asada...can't say that about any other place.
author: Michael G.

description: Called in an order here and it was ready promptly. The atmosphere was nice and not too packed so we decided to eat there. Great salsa, amazing carnitas burrito, and the chips are not your average tortilla chip. They like have spices on them to make them taste more like Doritos. This place combines good prices with great quality which is hard to find. I like Papalote but it's more expensive. If this place was closer to my apartment I'd go here much more often. I'll be back.
author: Marty J.

description:
So I knew when I came to San Francisco, I HAD to get Mexican at least once. 
After debating back and forth between certain places based on reviews I had read, I decided to go with El Castillito for a few reasons:
A. They supposedly serve veggie burritos (I'm not a vegetarian, but I don't really like meat...I know, I know, what's the point of a burrito?) 
B. they seemed a little bit healthier than some of the alternatives. 

I was quite happy with the outcome. I went with the super veggie burrito. Although, I have to say I was slightly disappointed because other reviews on here say they had all sorts of grilled veggies in their burrito. Mine was simply beans, rice, sour cream, guac, avocado (I asked for it, I'm a huge avocado fan), lettuce, tomato, onion, and spices. Now, I'm not complaining about this at all because in the end, my burrito was the size of a small baby for around $5, AND it was delicious, but I was expecting some sort of veggie in the burrito. Oh well, I guess that's what I get for not eating meat. 

Other pros, the service. SO FRIENDLY. The guy even drew a little face on my burrito foil. I know, it's small, but it makes a difference.

Also, the salsa bar. I'm from the east coast so this is totally uncommon to me. But OMG the salsa bar is probably what sold me on this place. The pico de gallo is AMAZINGLY fresh. (Get the one with fresh jalapenos in it, yum!). And the green salsa. OMG. So fresh, you can TASTE the avocados. And I got to fill up as many little containers as I wanted! I think I took an average of 6 altogether. AND free chips. Everything was fast, friendly, and yummy. I'd certainly go back.
author: Chantal G.

description:
Not only yes, but hell yes. This place appeared at the corner of my eye as I was hoofing it to the Cafe du Soliel. I was hungry for something more than café fare so I went in.

I got 2 tacos for less than $4.50 and they were killer. Those and a nice bottle of Mexican made cane sugar Coke and I was on my way. Hell yes.
author: Andrew L.

description: Used to go to this joint all the time but since I found Poncho Villa never been back but I had to go recently didn't feel like making the trip down to Valencia and looks like maybe new management but the same cooks were there so I felt that the food will be as usual okay but WOW was I wrong when I ordered a quesadilla the cook brought out a bucket full of looks like homemade cheese in chunks pieces and just unloaded it on the tortilla threw it on the grill for less then 10 seconds wrapped it up and gave it to me so the whole thing had may be a total count of three pieces of chicken A teaspoon of salsa and direct them to put more the cook gave me one of those looks like I was there to rob them of their salsa anyway he put another teaspoon in and nothing but chunky cheese that's not melted in this disgusting quesadilla I took a couple of bites and had to throw it away almost threw up it was that bad. I'm not the one to usually leave bad reviews but never going back to this place for sure!
author: Rupinder M.

description: Portions are huge so plan accordingly!  The food was on par along with the atmosphere.  If I had two others I would share the nachos!
author: Eric C.

description:
Still absolutely love this place.

The nicest guys work here.  And I have NEVER had a better quesadilla.

This is my absolutely favorite burrito place.
author: Andrea F.

description:
I like good cut, well-cooked meat in my burrito, so the first thing I look for is how good the meat looks in the steam table. EC was below average, the beef and chicken looked like it had been parboiled (no char, bland color), but then they finish it off on the grill for a bit of char. Not the same taste as real open flame grilled meat. The Al Pastor is a bit better, it's real spit-roasted, but what they give you is not freshly cut off the spit like other places, but has been sitting in broth for awhile. Presumably they cut fresh pork whenever they start to run out, but it could be hours of un-freshness. The cut of pork they use is also fatty and had gristly bits I had to spit out.

They give you a lot of meat for the money, but it's cheap cut and not well cooked, so that tradeoff you'll have to decide for yourself. The rest of the burrito was standard fare, OK but nothing special.

Also, as a side note about spinach tortillas. I suspect they are green because they have tons of food coloring in them, not because they have spinach. If you've ever made cream of spinach soup, it's mainly a white soup with flecks of green in it. Should be the same thing with tortillas. Recently I've been looking at the spinach tortillas I get and I've noticed some coloring inconsistencies, like areas of intense kelly green, obviously where some dye spilled and didn't get incorporated into the dough. Gross. This has nothing to do with El Castillito.
author: Rob C.

description:
I don't know if I can go back to regular burritos after trying El Castillito's wet burrito. It's a burrito on roids!

Their chicken is juicy, succulent and their carne asada is also tasty.
author: Lisa H.

description: Not good, I can't believe I went out of my way to try this place since reading good reviews.  I left feeling like I wasted a meal.  We had 1 super al pastor burrito and 3 tacos (carne asada, al pastor, and carnitas) for $18 even.  I've read that their al pastor is supposed to be better than Taqueria Guadalajara's version.  Trust me, it's the total opposite.  The burrito just didn't taste right.  The tortilla barely had any of that nice chew to it, the rice was wet and mushy with no flavor, and meat and everything else was just OK.  The tacos were pretty plain tasting and I had to add a lot of salsa and hot sauce to them.
author: Eric T.

description:
One of my favorite hole-in-the-wall Mexican eateries.  I found it by accident (I was looking for another El Castillito), but I'm happy for it.  It may not look like much (it got a great inspection score), but I love all of the food.  My favs are the steak torta and a chicken burrito.  Try the guacamole salsa.  As for drinks, the aqua fresca is worth it.  Sometimes I get the carrot juice mixed with orange juice.  
The staff is nice and pretty good about getting your order out quickly.
I have dragged several of my friends here and they have become fans (so you know its good).

The only tough part is parking.  If I can't find any, I park at the Blockbuster (now closing) or Safeway and run in and get my order.
author: Johnny K.

description:
Terrific Mexican food.

The tacos ($2.75ish) are not your small taco truck offerings, but rather piled high with authentic goodness. 

Green tomatillo/ guacamole sauce in the taco bar is legit.
author: Bruce P.

description:
When my friends and I want some FREAKING BOMB BURRITOS, we always come here, and I always order the super carne asada burrito.  It is SO DAMN GOOD. Hooray for free chips too! And don't forget to look at the cool mural on the ceiling. 

I love this place so much. Make sure you're going to the right one, there is another taqueria down the street - this one has the plain yellow "TAQUERIA" sign! 

(And check out the Yelp photos ... there's one of the carne asada burrito just begging you to take another bite.. ooooo food porn)
author: Corrie H.

description:
So, best Mexican food I've had in Northern California in a loooong time. Hole in the wall little place, small menu but amazing ingredients - everything's simple and oh so tasty... plus it's super cheap and super filling.

The refried beans should be patented and studied, they're that magical. And they do the cheese on the tortilla quesadilla style while they warm up the tortilla on the stove. 

The salsa is great, the great one especially (really fresh) and they chips are great and FREE!

So good, so good, so good, nothing more needs to be said. Except that they're tortillas are also, somehow, better than other tortillas.

Highly recommended and the guys who work there are really really friendly.
author: Aviya M.

description: The prices are great here and the staff is lively and very friendly. They are also open late for those late night cravings. Will surely visit again!
author: Jonathan A.

description: awesome tacos al pastor. decent price and slightly larger than most tacos. the pork was really tender and juicy. salsa could have been hotter, but was still good
author: M. G.

description:
in my opinion, for the price, you cannot get a better burrito north of the mission.

my standard order is a carnitas super burrito, extra crispy on the carnitas, with avocado instead of guacamole. (beans and extras varies on mood.)

oh, and get it on a green tortilla.

if you're a meat eater, do yourself a favor, grab yourself one of those and thank me with a healthy bowel movement.

i love this place.. perfect to stop in on your way back from Safeway.

they do a good horchata too, which is always a good sign a great mexican restaurant.
author: Sam H.

description: I am a fan of their vegetable burrito for under five bucks! They toss in a ridiculous amount of mixed veggies! broccoli, zucchini, mushrooms, and I forget what else. I also like their chicken burrito, yummy, cheap and fast!
author: Chris H.

description: Really flavorful super carne asada burritos and their super quesadilla is massive. The horchata is really flavorful and cinnamony compared to other places. They also have fresh melon juice (if you're a fan). The large drink size is also really big, and the hole in the cap, is not actually for the straw... but be creative.
author: Adrienne L.

description: I moved to SF from Europe couple years ago and never actually had a Burrito before. My wife was a huge fan of this place, and even though she was getting food from there quite often, it took me about a year to actually jump on the El Castillito band wagon. Since then it's my favorite taqueria in the city.
author: Miralem S.

description:
Had a craving so bad for some awesome Mexican food it almost made me cry. El Castillito has saved me from myself!

I ordered the super burrito with the al pastor meats and it was on point! Just a tip though...don't be a sissy like me and cut the burrito in half, things just get all over the place. Man up and dig in! 

Adding to the ambiance was a crazy man playing Ricky Martin on the juke box my whole visit, I only hope he is there for your dining experience to enlighten your day.
author: Ruby P.

description:
This is my favorite burrito place of all time!!! I always get the steak burrito. Two times have ever tried anything else here, a chicken burrito and breakfast chorizo and egg burrito. They were both good, but they just couldn't live up to my steak burrito!!! Yum yum yum yummm.... 

FOOD: 
*Always get my steak burrito like this; wheat tortllia, steak, rice, black beans, mild pico de gllo salsa (which has a little kick of spice to it already so I don't need spicy salsa), onion, and cilantro! There's also free chips and salsa if you like. 

There's so much flavor with everything stuff together in this package you don't need all those other stuff. Nothing you can say that will make me add sour cream or cheese to my burrito here. 

Service: 
Everyone is so friendly and they remember repeating customers. You order, get your food, pay, then sit down or take out and you're set! 

I LURV it here! Go see for yourself. 

Another thing, notice Yelp say's EC closes at 5pm??? I seen this place open until 11pm... hmmmm
author: Fried Rice B.

description:
When I am in the city, I have only eaten at Gordos.  I never deviated from my regiment because sometimes, routine is all a man has.  However, starving in the Castro, awaiting a friend to come for dinner from the East Bay, I needed a tidbit to sustain myself 'till then.  There were two Mexican places a block apart, however, my girlfriend I chose this because it looked more grimy.  Walking in, I could easily imagine this place on Haight Street.  It is small yet  bursting with character.  There is a jukebox in the corner where you can drop in a quarter and complement your dining experience with a personal soundtrack.  There are a couple tables and a bar that overlooks the streets so you can gawk and people watch.  Because we were eating Japanese in a couple hours, we decided to split.  In addition, due to lent, my girlfriend was going 40+ days without meat...I had to take this into consideration.  I did something I thought I would never do...I ordered a vegetarian quasidilla so we could share.  It would be a lie if I said I was not ashamed when I ordered it.  Simply put, men don't order Mexican food without meat.  However, the burrito maker did not scrutinize nor patronize me, just went about his business.  We got a quasidilla with extra sour cream and no beans and it was very big.  Taking my first bite, the quasidilla is literally a burrito except a little smaller with the tortilla placed on the grill for a couple minutes to toast it.  To be quite honest, it's taste was reminiscent of Gordos and i deduced that it was because of the salsa.  It tasted exactly the same.  I recommend the Gordos quasidilla if you want an unique spin...they fry the tortilla.  

The quasidilla was good however I cannot give a complete review until I have tried it with meat.  The chips were horrible however...tasted like they were straight from Costco.
author: Brian V.

description:
spicy pork all day
portion is HUGE
alot of salsa choices
really small place but they work effficiently
two cooks, 1 person taking orders and one first for drink and cashier

tucked in a little but is worth finding
favorite burrito place in sf
author: Andi I.

description:
Best el pastor burritos in San Francisco!  Burritos are custom made so you get exactly what you want.  Friendly staff, clean restaurant.  The chips could be much better (cheap, store bought) and the same with the refried beans that are just ok.  But I mostly go for the fabulous, real el pastor (shaved off the spit) burritos.  The tacos are big and plentiful (and they'll even give you a little scoop of beans on the side if you ask, free!), but I prefer the el pastor tacos at La Altena.  Nonethless, El Castillito's burritos beat La Altena's hands down.  
I haven't even tried anything else on the menu.
author: Erin M.

description:
Super veggie burrito was really good and like $5.50 or something.  Under $10 with a beer.  It was a little small of a burrito, I could have taken down another half of one, but it is easy to get to from the Church Muni stop.  The lady at the cash register is sweet.  Seating was aplenty.

I find the way you order here strange though.  You order from one guy, then tell the lady what you ordered.  Then the guy asks you from more details on your order, what kind of beans, tortilla, and spiciness.  Whatever, its good food.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
I learned the other day that they use all organic free-range meats, which is why they taste different. That's certainly admirable on their part, but it's no excuse for the meat tasting tough. Don't use certain products unless you know how to use them to get the most taste out of them.

The Little Chihuahua on Divis. gets this right.
author: Mark A.

description: Best super vegetarian burrito I've ever eaten.  Friend had a super chicken burrito and said it was excellent.  Fast, friendly, competent service, too.
author: Phil H.

description: I start my Sunday with coffee and a laptop, then stroll down to El Castillito for breakfast.  10:30 rush time for breakfast around the city, and I get a abundant, beautiful, (gluten-free), vegetable-accompanied plate of Huevos a la Mexicana.  I'm working on my laptop, with the wide window in front of me enjoying the light of day.  And there's no wait or people to annoy with laptop working on a Sunday morning.  Ahhhhh, I've found my Sunday routine.
author: Stuart C.

description:
mmmmmmhmmmmmm......

this place is pretty much perfect for me.  it's right around the corner, is cheap as it gets, and has a good variety of things that are delicious.
Before I was traumatized by the movie "Forks over Knives" I enjoyed their El Pastor, which is like Shoarma but porkier and more delicious, can't put it in the wrong place either, tacos, burritos, etc.

But now that I try to abstain from meat, normally a tragedy with mexican fare, I still find that I have many solid options here that are actually *gasp* priced properly as being 'cheaper' than other meat options, thereby you get rewarded for your vegetarian efforts. 

Primarily, the vegetarian taco cannot be beat, as of this date, it is $2.40 including high-california sales tax, and includes, two delicious corn tortillas on the bottom (with cheese in the middle if you'd like) topped with black or refried beans, lettuce, tomatoes, onions/cilantro, sour cream, and then ask for avocado (you get at least a third of one) instead of guacamole.
If this doesn't sound like much, IT IS, it usually weighs well over a pound, and the kicker is they have a delicious (and free) chips and salsa bar, so you crunch up some tortilla chips over it and add copious amounts of fresh salsas until you get the largest and most tasty super nachosish meal you have ever had!!  

I couldn't make it myself for cheaper than $2.40, although, I hope that now I have written this review it doesn't jack up interest and thus jack up that delicious price.......
author: William L.

description:
Solid Mexican food for little dinero. I wouldn't say I was blown away, but suffice it to say that if I could eat like this every night I would be pretty happy (if unhealthy).

I had the super vegetarian: definitely do that if you're of the non-meat-eating persuasion. Also, they have Negro Modelo for under 4 dollars a bottle, which is pretty alright.
author: Ben S.

description:
If you've ever tried to substitute a grilled cheese sandwich for a tortilla when making a burrito you know that it can end in disastrous results. You may have even given up on the idea of the grilled cheese burrito entirely! 

Thank goodness the mad geniuses at El Castillito found a way to make the grilled cheese burrito. Eureka! It's a true marvel of modern science!

Their secret is slapping the flour tortilla on the grill and then putting squares of cheese on the tortilla before they fill it up with more fat and carbs! What you get is a nice toasty tortilla with a ring of cheese hugging the rice, beans, and meat. Delicious does not even begin to cover the way it feels to bite into this thing. 

A word of warning: Stay away from the vegetable burrito. The frozen veggie mix they seem to use is unappealing at best and burrito ruining at worst. 

The carnitas and the carne asada are both really good and for the love of the vengeful burrito gods be sure to go super and treat yourself to some sour cream and guacamole. 

Thanks to the grilled cheese burrito I have to wear draw string pants.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Huge yummy burritos. Glass bottle coke! 

When I went without my boyfriend, the cook drew pictures on the tin foil of my burrito. Very cute.
author: Halley B.

description: The tall cook with the goattee is pretty good natured. The other cook looked like he had and attitude. When he made the burritto it tasted funny. I took two bites and dumped it. Everyone says how great this place is, but I'm not sure. I have reservations about it. I won't be returning.
author: Erik V.

description: This is one of my favorite taquerias in SF. Not much to look at from the outside, but they have delectable burritos! The al pastor super burrito is the best in the city as far as I'm concerned. The quesadilla castillito and breakfast burritos are also great. Also open late to remedy your drunken stumbles home!
author: Chris H.

description: This place is AMAZING.  Their quesadilla castillito is amazing.  They grill the burrito so the outside is crispy and the cheese is melted.  Their salsas are awesome especially the green one and you get chips for free.  They have beer which always goes well with some spicy mexican food.  I have lived in LA and San Diego and this place is BOMB!  Also, the carnitas is delicious.
author: Julie B.

description:
Given the concentration of bars, Lower Haight desperately needs more good cheap late-night food.  (Good as they are, one can't eat Rosamund's sausages every night of the week !)  Until the neighborhood gets its act together, make the 10-15 minute walk down past Duboce and hit this place on your way to or from your bar of choice.

Granted, it is slightly strange location for a taqueria, with not much walkby traffic, but they seem to be doing OK for themselves, and I'm glad to have it (sort of) in my neighborhood.  I find that most taquerias are much of a much, but this place is better than most and compares favorably to Cancun and Farolito, though because of its location it is a little more laid back.  Good salsa verde, always plenty of pickled carrots, pretty friendly service, guys working the kitchen are quick at taking orders.  You'll be pleasantly surprised, and glad that they decided not to cram themselves into the rows of taquerias lining Valencia and Mission.
author: Tee Jay R.

description: its pretty delicious but I am traumatized by the amount of butter the cook used to sautee the prawns. he used about 1/2 a stick of butter for 10 prawns.  :(
author: Wakako U.

description: Best Burrito in town, period.  If you haven't tried this place and you like burritos (who doesn't?), you have to try.
author: Blake P.

description:
For some good pain, this place has everything you need.  Now I don't know about the rest of you, but when I order a burrito I expect each ingredient to spice my tongue into a state of torturous bliss. 

It all starts with the foundation...  

The super burritos are killer here, but you don't even have to go that expensive, get a regular. It's still the shit.  There chicken has great flavor, and their spicy pico, cilantro & onion combo give the burrito an impressive above average spice all on its own.  I often dump globs of there hottest salsa on each bite I take, just to make sure I get a nice sweat started.   

If you're hungry enough for a super burrito, by all means go ahead. This place is really cheap and delivers some damn good food that will leave your tongue and tummy glad you went, even though they may beg your brain for a glass of water.
author: Collin S.

description:
Sometimes it feels redundant rating some places in SF because they have been written about so many times, but I'm not sure this place deserves 4 stars...3 might be a bit more fitting.

I had a Carne Asada Torta...the meat really wasn't good.  Lots of gristle and I could taste cinnamon in the marinade way too much.  The chips probably came from Costco.  BUT!  They salsa verde with avocado saved this place.  That stuff was great!  

All and all, a decent taco joint.  Not a place to go way out of your way for though.
author: Matt R.

description:
Walking into the Little Castle you shall meet with a huddled mass patiently awaiting the benevolent services of two brave knights stabbing at basins of rice and beans with shining, long-handled spoons. 

These paladins of pulled pork move the rabble along yet remain sympathetic to the commoner's plight. Whether it be a quesadilla suiza, all-meat carne asada burrito or the wet al-Pastor burrito, El Castillito outshines its inferior neighbors.

And fear the great green dragon awaiting you among the bar of salsa. Its bite is mighty and its breath is ferocious.

For those who dwell in the shadow of Mount Safeway, it is a comfort to know this tacqueria's noble reputation remains unstained.
author: Brent B.

description: One of my absolute favorite taquerias in the city. Hands down, the best pastor in San Francisco. It's a great little spot to get a couple tacos and a beer or two.
author: Joe J.

description:
Best vegetarian burrito around: Veggie QUESADILLA on whole wheat, black beans, with everything on it (yes to jalapeños). $5.35 after tax.

Grab a few salsas (don't miss the green one) and you're good to go.  Awm nom, amazing!
author: Karl N.

description:
Known around my homies as "The Spot" it doesn't get such a name for nothing. 

The service there is great. The duo that works the line churns out food faster then any other taq hands down. They take custom orders and serve generous helpings with good vibes. Good salsa selection. Not all is excellent however, their chips are your average pre-bagged but so are most places. 

Recommend the super pork burrito can easily split it for two. The fish taco special for 4.25 is a good sized meal that includes beans and rice, one of the cheapest filling items in the city. 

Overall, vibe, cost, taste included, its better than Papalote, La Taq, Pancho anything, Cancun, El Faro. It is "The Spot"
author: Daren G.

description: My first time here and I am glad to make it my last. I had better. Got the carne asada super burrito. They ripped me off by missing my guacamole! I did say super burrito. Did I stutter? No. These guys need to be more attentive! You pick up your order and you take it to the cashier, who has no idea what you ordered so you tell them. Then got home and half way through bam*, no guacamole. Paid 8 bucks for a bland and dried burrito and don't forget, no guac. Hard to swallow folks. I pretty much paid what I didn't ask for. !@#!$@#%@#$ If you're thinking about coming here, yell your order out to them even if you may sound rude because you wouldn't like to end up like me. Disappointed. The 2 stars are for the snuggled wrapping. Good job. Yay.
author: Michelle D.

description:
BEST BURRITO IVE HAD IN SF!

Ps, I only get veggies+beans. Not a meat burrito fan.
author: Courtney S.

description:
I knew I should have walked farther and gone to Taqueria Cancun or Pancho Villa instead, but I was encouraged by the fact this place has a 4 star average and is so close to my place.  Ah well, lesson learned.

Got the super burrito al pastor.  The meat was greasy and the rice and guacamole were not very good.  They also use cheese slices instead of shredded cheese - wtf?  Everything was just way too salty.  No acidity at all, not even in any of the salsas.  Just salt and more salt.

Also kind of expensive at over $8 for a burrito.  I'll stick to going to the taquerias in the Mission from now on.
author: Leslie L.

description:
So if any one has read my previous reviews, they know how much I hate The Mint. With a passion. So when my friend called me up, saying she was going to see some of her friends there and wanted to drag me along, I rolled my eyes. She didn't see it because it was over the phone, but I think she knew I was rolling my eyes anyway. Long story short, I told her that with her boyfriend, I'd at least go drop her off and hang out with her for a while before her friends showed up... and I figured I could update my Mint review with even more funny rantings.

So we walked by The Mint. It looked all ready packed with drunk-as-fuck thirty-somethings who can't carry a tune, trying to relive their youth through a horrible rendition of Madonna's "Celebrate" while driving around in a huge stretch Hummer limo with the words "I'm getting married. Buy me a shot" spraypainted on the side. All ready, my friend looked at me and her boyfriend and said, "Let's not go in yet... let's get something to eat." And I couldn't agree with her more.

We were thinking about going to the Japanese place next door, but their sushi was over priced. We remembered there was a Burgermeister a couple of blocks away near Safeway. So we trek up that way, going through the empty, yet shady alley way behind Safeway. We noticed El Castillito and were like... maybe we should get burritos instead. We looked inside Burgermeister and noticed it was pretty packed... of course there was one dude taking up three seats but I won't go any further into that guy. So, burritos it was.

I got the super chicken burrito, my friend the... I actually forgot what he got... whatever. Anyways, the wait in line wasn't bad... about three to five minutes. The people taking the order and making the food were cool... and quick making the burrito as well. I got some chips and some free water... the water was cool, the chips were a little stale, but totally edible. And the burrito... great. I've had better burritos (living in the Mission for almost twenty years makes it understandable) but not as of late. So I definitely appreciated the burrito I had. It might be better than La Fonda by a level... maybe.

The place looks like a hole-in-the-wall. It's not super fancy with in-style decor and furniture. And that's how I LIKE my burrito places. It was pretty cheap and pretty good, and that's all any one should ask for. Sure, there was a couple of douchebags with their $1200 fixee bicycles chained to a tree outside, but they're spreading like bacteria, and that area (along with the Mission) is the petrie dish, promoting the growth of such bact... I mean hipsters. I digress.

Long story short (too late,) my friend decided not to go. Mainly because they were still getting ready (they're the stereotypical girls that take two hours to get ready to go to a crappy karaoke bar) and because she just didn't want to go to The Mint. So, leaving the Sunset for a night plus great burritos plus not having to go to The Mint minus dirty neighborhood equals 4.4 stars... rounded down to four. The math is right... I always double check my proof ;D
author: Chris S.

description: I've tried other burritos around the city and this is by far my favorite! The vegi burrito comes with guac and sour cream and their carne asada is flavorful and delicious. I rarely go elsewhere now.
author: Bianca E.

description: It's mainly the same workers everyday so that's a plus for me because when I go there, the guys know my usual order.  I've ordered the super burrito on tomato wrap.. LOVE IT!! Also you can't go wrong with the taco salad.  I love the shell, its always so crispy and flaky.  The salsa is always fresh and taste great.  The ceviche is a new item that they put on the menu and I wan't disappointed with that one either. My favorite here is also the fresh squeezed juice.  Only $2-$3 for a LARGE and when I say LARGE, I'm not talking about a regular large cup from a fast food joint.
author: E F.

description:
Whenever I eat at this little castle, I always get something with the beans and rice. I don't know what it is, but if it doesn't have beans (refried) and rice, it isn't really Mexican, you know? I like to stir a half-fork of rice into the beans, and chew them up together. Then do it again. 

I will get the meal just for the beans and rice. Mmmm. You got to try the quesedillas too. They are awesome. Get yourself some Al Pastor Tacos on your next trip amigo.
author: Fuji F.

description: Burritos aren't bad but certainly aren't as good as I remember. Lacks the spark you find in a Cancun, Los Coyotes, or Le Cumbre bite. That said, as for as a taqueria outside of the mission Castillito offers a solid burrito option for those craving a Tex-mex taste for an affordable price. Regular meat burritos are $6 and Super are $7.
author: Quentin J.

description:
The quality and selection here leave much to be desired. The meet tastes over cooked, the salsa looks old, and the tortillas are nothing special. It is authentic style, but just because something is authentic doesn't necessarily mean the execution provides a pleasant meal.

They exist in prime real-estate, and perhaps they are resting a bit on their laurels.
author: Andrew H.

description: The super burrito (without cilantro) was good, very taste. Just a little disapointed when i asked for carne asada it looked similar to ground meat. Seems like the steak went into a food processor it was in "balls". Overall the burrito was good.
author: Melissa B.

description: Best taqueria out there. Cheap and amazing, good music and really nice staff.
author: Lacey O.

description:
Tried it again... and it really dropped off on quality.  Chips were no good, neither were the salsas.  Meats were totally dry and overcooked.  And the beans tasted bland and old.

I won't be going back.
author: Calvin N.

description: The cooks look really professional and the food was prepared in front of me in less than 2 minutes. Free chips come with your meal if you ask for them.
author: Johann R.

description: regular vegetarian burrito here errry day for $5 with a shitty tip. they do it right every time and the ingredients are always fresh(albeit low quality. not exactly organic, locally grown produce but what do you expect for 5 bones?). the place it kind of a dump(watched the cook smash a cockroach here.) but the service is fast and friendly. also some of the best salsa in town. try the roasted pepper salsa and the green salsa. no cockroaches... trust me.
author: zachary p.

description:
Very confusing and altogether disheartening to see nearly 400 reviews for a place that gets an average rating of 4 stars yet turns out to be pretty mediocre?

Folks, ya gotta get out more for actually decent mexican food...At any price!

No self respecting Mexican tacqueria can ever be dishing up canned items but Castillito apparently has no self respect...You can actually taste the canned tomato sauce on their shrimp dishes which boggles the mind really....How can you even screw up guacamole?...It didn't nearly resemble/taste like it wasn't premade...Fresh amigos, fresh...Say no to canned goods!

I like the fact that they have this sorta central american looking interior, complete with the sort of fly traps you'd find...I know peeps also seem to be impressed that they grill things but that appears to only be a substitute for a microwave.

I don't want to see piled up meat that had been cooked at some unknown timepoint to simply stick on the grill and give the impression it's 'fresh'...I wasn't expecting Niman Ranch cuts of meat but the gristle being marketed as Carne Asada is pretty scary...I'm still wondering when the ill feelings are going to set in from what I ate

I'm not a Tacqueria snob either because all you have to do is see how well Pancho Villa or Farolito...Tlaloc or even Cactus are also terrific with fresh ingredients.

I wouldn't set foot in this place again.
author: Barca F.

description: This is my favorite taqueria in a city full of taquerias. It's got a small dining room but people move pretty quickly so I've never had a hard time getting a table. The vegetarian quesadilla is my favorite thing on the menu. The cooks and employees are helpful and very nice.
author: John C.

description:
Probably my favorite Mexican food in the city.

1. Excellent salsa bar. Great pico, good green sauce, spicy. And roasted jalepenos. Free chips!

2. Relatively cheap. I think a regular burrito (of a decent size) is $6.01?

3. Interesting layout. You order from the guys prepping the food in a faced paced know your stuff and don't be picky back-and-forth.

There might be better tasting food out there but for the value and the no frills atmosphere, you can't beat this place. If you like polished metal tables and dry bland burritos find a Chipotle.
author: Glen P.

description: The best veggie burrito in town! I come here at least once a week and it is amazing. Highly recommended.
author: Paul H.

description:
still the jam. Quesa de Castillito with steak will shock you like an electric eel. Perfect for me when I take the evil J home cause it stops basically in front of the spot.

El Castillito is to mexican fare, what seeing Fugazi for free in Dolores Park when I was like 19 or 20 was to me =epicness personified
author: Lauren V.

description:
Best Super Chicken nachos in the city!!!
I love their salsa's and they also have fresh juice too. 
Super cheap and equally yummy!
author: Laura B.

description: You're trying to fatten me up. But it's only because you want me to be less attractive to the other taquerias out there vying for my attention. Don't worry, you'll always be my number one. And no matter how fat you make me, I'll be back again and again to beg for more.
author: Chelsea T.

description:
I get it. It's tasty. But I have this rule. 

Look, it's just the way I am.

No. No. It's not like that. It's not you. It's me.

Look, do you want to hear the rule, or what? Are you going to let me talk?

Ok.

If your chorizo makes me shit magma within a half hour, there's something wrong.

No. It wasn't just the once.
author: Maple Q.

description:
My favorite place for a refried bean burrito and at a dirt cheap price.

Conveniently located and never extra crowded, this taqueria has some of the tastiest salsa in their bar as well as fresh ingredients, friendly servers and tasty horchata.
author: Mike J.

description:
Love the burritos here. It's no Farolito, but it's much closer to home now that I'm not in the mission anymore :(. Definitely the best burrito in the area.

I like that they warm the tortilla and meat, and they definitely know how to fill a burrito until it's about to burst.
author: Evan B.

description: I prefer casa mexicana just a few feet away.  But I'm not a big meat person, and that seems to be what others who gave this place higher reviews tend to like.
author: Bob L.

description:
In the El Castillito v. Casa Mexicana Yelp face-off, I go with Casa Mexicana most of the time.  

El Castillito has a friendly staff, and avocado lovers will like this joint for obvious reasons (they will substitute their terrible gauc for half an avocado for no extra charge).  

But really! Not good. All of their meats are so fatty and greasy, I never order them.  Their rice and bean burritos are pretty bland, and they have in my opinion the worst salsa of any other taco joints in the surrounding area.  Their mole is also...just not good. 

It's a good stand-by for a super veggie under 5 dollars. But Casa Mexicana is better.
author: Luke M.

description:
I've tried many taquerias around SF including Gordos and La Taqueria but none have come close to giving me the big flavor explosions in my mouth like El Castillito. I love this place.

Try the Super Burrito and Quesdilla El Castillito.
author: Moaan A.

description:
I was not blown away.
I really wanted to jump on board too cos I'd heard such good things but El Castillito just don't make the cut. Salsa was boring and that's a big indicator for good Mexican food right? (That's what my Momma says!) I'm bummed out about it still..... :(
author: J C.

description: Hands down the best burritos in San Francisco.  Period.  And they're right across the street from Safeway (which is handy for parking when grabbing one to go!)
author: Kasey K.

description:
I was ravenous, so when my friend first suggested the quesadilla, I ignored him.  Aren't quesadillas just skinny little tortillas with cheese? He insisted I'd like it, so I gave it a try.

Turns out the quesadilla here is actually a huge San Francisco-style stuffed burrito (packed with cheese, rice, beans, the works), but grilled on oil so that the tortilla is crispy and somewhat browned.  It's substantial.  And it's great.
author: angela n.

description:
If I were to invite you on a trip to Puebla, Mexico, and we were on a mission to search for a tasty delicious burrito one evening in between eating a tasty tamale for lunch and creamy flan for dessert, we would probably walk into a place not unlike El Castillito. This has to be one of the best, cheapest places in the city to get a REAL GOOD BURRITO. This place is sort of evil because it's on my way home from work and has definitely contributed to an additional 30 minutes of cardio at the gym. I took my family of 6 here to give them a "taste of San Francisco", and we all ate for $30.

The guys behind the counter are really nice (don't be intimidated if you can't fire off your order in Spanish, or even in English -- I've seen plenty people point and grunt with great results). They have a great selection of tortillas (tomato, spinach, wheat, reg), salsas (SUPER good tomatillo), and meats (spicy chicken anyone?). 

Don't be fooled by the also-good-but-not-as-great Casa Mexicano next door. Just keep walking up Church to the alluring yellow sign of El Castillito.
author: Matthew S.

description:
i eat here at least once a week, usually the super burrito.  I was a huge fan of El Farrolito for years but have converted, El Castillito is now my favorite burrito place.  I think that the difference is their meat, its so flavorful.  
I prefer the one on Church but I know there is another on Mission and 17th.  
Cash only.
author: Nicole A.

description:
I had a chicken super burrito here 4 days ago.  I was so full afterwards I had to take a nap.  
I just woke up.  

Davids bottom line- Forget roofies.  Just give your date one of these LEGAL burritos and wait 20 minutes.
(No you ass I do not condone date rape)
author: David L.

description:
"In regione caecorum rex est luscus."
Translation-

"In The Land of the Steamed, The One True Grilled Tortilla Is King" - Jesus Christ, Revolutions 41:40.

"Behold, It is coming with clouds, and every eye will see It, even those that steamed It!" a drunken gin-sot screamed from outside. "And all the tribes of the earth will wonder why we ever steamed It", he continued, yelling at the blackened sky. 

It was then that I realized, that I was in fact, seeing Jesus Christ drunk for the second time in my life. 

And I saw in the right hand of Him who sat on the throne a Burrito sealed with seven ingredients, as He tried to pour salsa on top of the burrito, spilling it on a fresh pair of white Chuck Taylors.   

Then I saw a strong angel proclaiming with a loud voice, "Who is worthy, and sober enough, to pour salsa on His Burrito?"

And no one in heaven or on the earth or under the earth or in the Mission was able to pour the salsa, or to look at it. 

"I shall!" I screamed, before I even knew what I was doing. "I'm from San Diego, I know burritos!" I continued yelling, a total loss of self control.  "This is the best you're gonna get up here" I weeped, falling to my knees. "The best."

Then He came and took the Burrito out of the right hand of Him who sat on the throne. 

"Goddammit, Jesus" He spoke, and the mountains shook and oceans rang. "It's fucking Monday, are you serious?" God asked, stuffing as many bites in as He could before Jesus noticed.

So, the moral of this story, that should be taken very literal, is that this place is amazing. Hands down and up my favorite place in this city.

*********
Because I don't mind the Useful votes...
Best tortas I've found so far in the city.
Awesome staff.
And one of my Top Secret ummm...secrets?
On slower nights you can get a burrito, and if you ask nice enough, get half al pastor and half carnitas, making for one of the most amazing things that you probably don't even deserve you goddamn agnostic. Amen.
author: Dave G.

description:
Hmmm, perhaps I ordered wrong here, but I can't say I was doing cartwheels over the burrito I ordered a few weeks ago. For starters, I ordered it wet and all I got was a dry burrito. This wouldn't have been a big deal, but the rest of it wasn't all that mind blowing to start. 

After now reading the reviews, it looks like the quesadillers are the way to go, so i will give them another try because the guys that work here were super sweet and friendly and they didn't even look at me funny when I pronounced Negro Modelo like a gringa! Thanks guys!
author: Stephy S.

description:
Very tasty pastor here.  They have the meat on the spit and everything just as it should be.  The tacos very much remind me of the ones I used to eat in TJ or Chula Vista, which brings a little warmth to my heart.  I hear they grill their tortillas here too.  None of the steam crap.  This is also a huge plus in my book.  The chips that they used for the nachos didn't seem to be able to hold up to all the product on them so take note.

The spot where you order and pick up your food is different than where you pay for it.  They aren't far away from each other but it can be awkward.  I was so excited to get my tacos al pastor that I totally blew by the cashier dude and went to enjoy my tacos with my friends.  Thankfully I remembered when I was finishing up and went back to pay for them.  They didn't even come try to kick my ass or anything.
---------------------------
05/31/2007 update

Came here for lunch today and remembered that I have to add a note about the quesadilla suizas.  These things are really just a big burrito filled with nothing but cheese and meat wrapped in a toasted flour tortilla.  So damn good!

The jukebox makes me feel like I'm hanging out with my hoodlum Norteno listening primos.
author: Luis M.

description: Did anybody else get the carnitas?   I'm sorry, I see that all the little Yelpers love love love this place, but this was just butt ass.  Thinking of the huge surprise fat globs I found in my burrito is making me shiver and gag right now. That is just totally unacceptable.  And its pricey too.  This is not ideal.
author: Rick H.

description: Yummy Mexican food at a low price.  I like their mushroom quesadilla.  Flan is only $1.95.  Employees work hard to serve a lot of customers.  The quality combined with the price gives me no choice but to give them 5 stars.  Very close to Safeway and Church St MUNI station.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Best place to watch cracked out homeless people eat burritos and slam hot salsa like a shot of 151. Oh and they make good, large burritos that will leave you incapacitated on the N. 

El Castillito actually grills the tortilla. Call it a simple wish or a want, but more places need to actually grill the tortilla. It adds to the complete burrito experience. Do not steam it with one big piece of cheese, do it El Castillito style. Few pieces over a big grill. Than ask the customer what amount of onions, pico de gallo, cilantro, beans, rice and meat. Presto!  What a great symbiotic relationship between the customer and burrito technician. And make sure to order some Watermelon aqua fresca. 

And if you can not finish your tinfoil wrapped love cylinder give it to the woman twitching outside.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Home to the mountainous two-dollar veggie taco, superb & friendly employees, & the best salsa I can find for miles.  It's all about the green salsa.  All the food I've tried here is really good, but in a way, I think I just use it all as various vehicles for the green salsa.  I usually take home multiple buckets of the stuff so that I can enjoy it in the privacy of my own home & not make disgusting slurping sounds as I practically drink it down.
mmmmmmm. . . green salsa. . . .
author: Ravena F.

description:
Best burrito place! Everything tastes delicious and fresh. I always get the super veggie quesadilla with avocado instead of guacamole...mmmm....
Cash only!
author: S F.

description:
They have to have some of the best burritos in SF. I lean to the carnitas but even the veggie versions are fantastic. Yummy, fast, fresh, inexpensive, flavorful. A great neighborhood treat. Dine-in is fine, but super fast for take out. Closest to home-cooked I've tasted in a long time. 

Great for sharing...
author: Tanya P.

description:
One word: CHICKEN.

Okay so usually I'm the Carrrrrne Asada type of girl BUT here I get the chicken. Something about it is addicting. that sauce?? just delicious. I've also had the torta which is one of the best ive had in the city.

Yum yum yum. Oh yeah and the cook flirts with me like allll the time. So girls beware. he's harmless tho
author: Sarina I.

description:
where is the taco truck?....how does a taco truck have an address?....oh snaps~!...it's a restaurant~!....

castilito....pretty cool burrito joint...a typical dive tacqueria....mini salsa bar....tasty pickled jalepeno and carrots....cool staff...the burrito?...eyes fixed on the "all meat"....could this be?...a socal style burrito?....sadly...not.....why is it called "all meat" jose?...what's up with the sour cream, lettuce, cheese and tomato salad filler inside....nope..definitely not a socal style burrito...

bbyob....mickey forty in a brown bag.....guzzle...gulp....chug.....drink....sip.....oh man...i'm getting full.....toss the burrito to the side.....guzzle....chug...sip....ummm.....must finish forty.....guzzle....yes~!...i'm done.....now what?.....oh snaps...castilito sells coronas and pacifico beru...2 more jose...gulp..gulp..ahh....

rockin' castilito...forties...tall boys.....sangria...gulpin' down beers....eating tacos, nachos and burritos....our gang was screaming...yelling....and just loud....what does castilito do?..nothing.... just gives a big smile as they were entertained...
author: Hen A.

description:
Well just know that I even double-checked the location to make sure I had the right joint..

I am a  somewhat snotty but not unpleasant person and I am in the serenest of moods as I inform you that for me this dump was a miserable and claustrophobic descent into culinary mexiocrity served on paper plates with plastic cutlery and scuzzy clientele.

The chefe, albeit a cheerful and on the ball bloke, made less than bleh heading towards blech scallop or pollock tacos with no discernible guacamole, masticated and sent to the stomach in about ninety seconds with the intended purpose of leaving as quickly as possible, in part to avoid the white trash wench who changed her order because "...that's too much tax. That's way too much tax." 

Dare I ever return to assess the validity of the majority sentiment? The impression I got was that if you were homesick for Hayward or the central valley then this place is your destination. Ok, I am a swine. But their tacos blew.

Natural Light: Poor
author: Mark G.

description:
My brothermang introduced me to this place and a year+ later, having tried tons of Taquerias in the Bay Area, El Castillito is still one of my favourites.  Why?

The Super Burritos are just my size, huge! and can feed a small family, all for about $6.  Ask for avocado, they'll cut one open and add it right in front of you.  I regularly take triple the amount of Salsa verde I need, so I can just eat it on other stuff later on .. *ahem*.  The carnitas and al pastor are a little bit of heaven. The two guys behind the counter run a tight burrito ship, and I'm in-n-out in 5 minutes flat!  5 Solid stars!!
author: I. O.

description:
I've been aching for meat.  
Not just ANY meat mind you.  

Thick, juicy, protein heavy meat.  

I must have a deficiency.  Yeah...that's probably it.  I have a protein deficiency.  I've had meat here and there but I guess it just wasn't enough for what my body really is needing.  

The need comes stronger when I drink, too.  Who knows why?  

After a few drinks at Transfer I was wanting that shit like mad.  

I NEED MEAT!!  

Carne Asada Quesadilla Suiza...spicy.  Mmmmm.....

Hot juicy meat in my mouth!
author: Jay H.

description:
Whenever I'm hangin' out in the area and someone whines, "I'm hungry", someone is always apt to yell back,

"Let's go to THE CASTLE!!!"

And The Castle it is :)

For $1.99, I can get the most filling veggie taco!  For a taco, it's GIGANTIC and most definitely very hearty.  It's way more than just a snack.  One time when I was feeling greedy and gluttonous, I went all out and ordered their veggie burrito with the works.  For around $4, I got an UNGODLY sized burrito.  Never again, never again.  I'm sticking with their gigantic tacos

I love their horchata as well.  A huge cup for less than $2?  You can't beat that!  And they have a salsa bar.  A SALSA BAR!

I hate to give 'em anything but five stars, but I'm knockin' off one star for their flavor, or rather, lack thereof.  I mean, yeah, it's salty and I can taste all of their ingredients' natural flavors, but something's still off about it, and I can't quite put my finger on it...  But The Castle is still a good deal and'll hit the spot if you're starving.
author: Debbie L.

description:
The regular fish taco which was about $3.50 was pretty good size and filled with fish chunks. It was delish.  

It's a relaxed atmosphere and cheerful workers. It's awesome for our late night light snack post-vball games.
author: Hebert J.

description:
I came to this place with a friend, who had seen it many times but had never eaten here.  First things first, it's really busy.  You wouldn't expect it to be because of its location, but it just is.  You have to deal with that. Second, the food is just OK.  I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here, but if I were hungry, I wouldn't avoid it either.

UPDATE:  3/29/10
==============

When I walked by El Castillito today, I noticed it's wheelchair inaccessible.  You have to go down stairs to enter, and there's no ramp.  Boo.
author: John S.

description:
Oh El Castillito, the oh so fresh and yummy El Castillito.
I have lived by you for almost a year now, and shame on me for never coming inside. The food is cheap. But the cheap price does not mean cheap food. It's delicious, it's fresh, they are so willing and nice about customizing stuff- and you can watch them make it. Which I find comforting. (Bad experiences do haunt you). Prepare to be stuffed. You get your money's worth- and then some. Perfect drunk food, perfect-I-just-went-to-yoga-and-now-I-feel-like-getting-fat food, perfect food anytime of the day. Great hours too.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Yuck.  They use cheese singles in their burritos.

I don't like the burritos here, they feel as non-authentic as could be.

They do have a juice bar, which is cool.  2 stars for having a juice bar.  If only their burritos were better.

Better burritos can be found south on Church at Azteca or Casa Mexicana.
author: Joshua E.

description:
Perfect drunk food!  Cheap, quick, cheesy, a little greasy and oh so good.  

Word to the wise:  The nachos are delicious but they're also bigger than your head, if you order them recruit a few friends to share.
author: Renae H.

description: had a veg burrito here that was pretty good.  Large enough that i only had half and saved the rest for lunch the next day.  Would definitely come back.
author: Phil J.

description:
El Castillito is my favorite Taqueria. In this city, or in any other.

They load your burrito with tons of fresh tomatoes, avocados, lettuce.... MY LORD! These gentleman do not skimp on the good ingredients! Every burrito is a party. 

And don't get me started on their tacos. Two bucks for a heaping pile of rice, beans, veggies... enough to call it "dinner" for a lady like myself. TWO DOLLARS DINNER. I'm going nutz here. 

And I couldn't ask for a friendlier, more charming staff. These people are artists, but they don't let it go to their heads!

Remember, cash only. In a pinch, go to the Wells Fargo in the Safeway across the street. And then go get your burrito -- you deserve it!
author: Beah B.

description:
Ah, burrito heaven. El Castillito, you complete me. The chicken burrito is the best  EVER CONSUMED. That's right people. And you know I love me my burrito. El Castillito delivers. They will melt the cheese on the meat while it is on the grill for you. And no more worries about what might end up in the burrito (aww man, i wanted refried not pinto, feck) because you are the master.  The resulting masterpiece is orgasmic. One bite in you get this wondeful mixture of creamy sour cream mixing with the guacamole over the chicken. *drool*  The goodness continues until the last bite with no cold spots to be found. 
I bring them a cup of the spicy red salsa and I like to get the spicy salsa for that extra crunch. A tip- you also have a choice of guac or fresh avocado.
author: Mango D.

description:
David L's review was like buttah!

You definitely get bang for your buck at El Castillito.  The most authentic taqueria of the 3 located by the Church/Market intersection.

Made to order and each time the grub was fresh.  Watch out what you ask for if you want it picoso.  

One thing I love and what the other 2 taquerias on Church don't do...grilled tortilla instead of steamed.  I just don't like soggy tortilla.  Did one influential person say they loooved steamed tortilla and then that idea spread like lice at summer camp?  Gawd!
author: Diego S.

description:
Castillito has my vote for best burrito in SF, for sure.

The Al Pastor is a MUST.
Wet burritos are a close second.
Worth the VERY out of the way trip on the way home when I get a hankering.
author: Sean W.

description:
Best taqueria I've EVER had. Reasonable prices for delicious and huge portions. Chicken super burrito - my favorite. They also have a veggie burrito with Lots of different vegetables. Nachos come in mountains here for ~$3. You tell the cook exactly what you want in/on your food as he's making it, so that's convenient. 
They also sell beer here.

I think this place is good for late nights - before or after going out for a night on the town. Scary bums yelling at you through the window is never pleasant though.
author: Crystal K.

description:
11/12/07

Sometimes it's the little things that make a burrito.  I could write about the meat, the salsas, the guacamole.  We all know how good those things are (don't forget melty cheese).  But today I'm going to write about rice and beans.

Fluffy rice and softened pinto beans.  The flavors married so well.  And last night, in warm tortilla sheets, the two consummated their union and issued a flavor that just held everything together.  What I tasted was passion.

---------------
previous review (at 4 stars)

Their burritos are excellent.  Get one and you will understand.  I was skeptical of the grilled tortilla concept, but it works.  Got to get it with cheese though.  Too dry otherwise (I learned this the hard way).  I usually opt for carnitas + pinto beans.  

Their burritos are HUGE (much bigger than Casa Mexicana's for example).  I get the super burrito without sour cream and it's usually a struggle to finish.  

Docking one star because their tacos are kind of lackluster, and because of the huge window.  Having the world walk by and gawk at me as I pig out makes me feel a little uncomfortable.  I guess I like to stuff my face in private.
author: indojin i.

description:
OMFG BURRITO.

This place has been my favorite for a really long time. I get the Super Chicken, with avocado. It's the bee's knees. The meat is tender and flavorful, and I have never bitten into a piece of gristle. 

Never! 

Do you know how amazing that is? I mean, I hate gristle. I'm not a vegetarian in any sense of the word, but I will often order the veggie thing to avoid gristle. No need for that here, baby. I feel a sense of freedom. It's like sex without a condom! But without the whole worrying whether or not you're pregnant. Or, uh. If you do manage to kill the whole burrito in one sitting, I guess you kinda do have to 'give birth' afterwards. Hahahaha. I like poop jokes.

But seriously, this is the best Taqueria in the city. However, Do Not Come Here in the morning. The morning staff is different, they don't make the food as good.

One little nitpick: I don't like that they microwave the nachos to melt the cheese. I mean, it doesn't end up tasting bad or anything, I just prefer the little toaster thingy that some of the other places have got.
author: Rachel H.

description: Best burritos in SF hands down. Whenever I'm in the area I stop regardless of whether or not I'm hungry.
author: MATTHEW O.

description:
This place is close to my house, otherwise I don't know if I would have ever picked it, since it appears on the outside to be a basic taqueria with nothing superfantastic to offer.  
I have only had the burritos here, so I cannot honestly speak for anything else, but the burritos are numma numma.  The employees are super nice, and you can call your order in which is easy and awesome.
While I prefer Pancho Villa, El Castillito is a good go-to for a quick but yummy burrito.
author: Lacy T.

description:
