It's easy to miss El Castillito because, like Laverne and Shirley's house it is strangely located half below ground level.  You do not want to miss this doorway to burrito heaven.

Every taqueria has their forte.  And I know the secret to burrito nirvana at El Castillito.  Order the Super El Pastor burrito (or the Super Fish Burrito, or the Breakfast Burrito).  Then fill up one of their little plastic cups with the magic green sauce at the counter.  Now fill up another.  Bite into burrito and pour in some green sauce.  Now bite again.  Ooooh.  Ahhhh.  Mmmmm.  Repeat until full or finished or out of green sauce.

Their green sauce is unmatched.  Put it on anything and everything you get.  Put it on things you didn't get from here.  Give it to your friends and relatives.  Give it to heads of state.  Give it to strangers on the street.  They will all thank you.
author: Eli B.

description:
Made to order Super Burrito starts with a grilled tortilla (with sliced, not shredded, cheese, if you've asked for it), and then layers of beans, rice, sour cream, tons of freshly (re)heated meat (as opposed to the kind that's just scooped out of the vat), and flavorful pico de gallo.
Don't mind if I do.
Cash only.

And no, I don't "blend" here (particularly on a recent, post-work visit whilst still in a pencil skirt and high heels), but I'm okay with that. Frankly, having taken a look outside the door, I'm TOTALLY fine with my not blending.  As is my mother.
author: Auburn D.

description: Lovely veggie burrito! If you're a fan of spicy foods - add a lot of hot sauce as the burrito itself was quite mild.
author: Nora G.

description:
El Castillito was the latest stop in my quest to find the perfect San Francisco burrito.  The menu looked pretty standard, but I could tell there was something special about the place while watching the burrista assembling oblong wraps of deliciousness.  As he put the foil on my regular carnitas burrito, he - just barely - folded the end of the tortilla over the foil.  Happy with nothing less than perfection, he removed the original foil and started over.  How many places would do that??

The burrito was good.  Very good.  Good bean/rice/meat mix, not too many onions and flavorful, fresh tomato salsa and cilantro.  I didn't care for the salsa verde I got on the side, but that was the only major weak spot.  

And while I still feel like there is a better burrito out there somewhere, I'll definitely add El Castillito to my top-contender list.
author: Eric S.

description: I love this place. Good food and very cheap. The people who work there are very friendly too.
author: Melissa M.

description:
YUM!

i have lived about 3 blocks away from el castillito for over 1.5 years, and finally visited it for the first time last week. i had a veggie burrito which was absolutely delicious. they put the cheese on the tortilla and melt it on the griddle before making the burrito. it keeps the whole burrito all hot, yummy, and delicious :) great chips and excellent tomatillo salsa.

my mouth is watering just thinking about it! the atmosphere isn't high in the aesthetics department, so i recommend getting your burrito to go!
author: Jill M.

description:
You can get a good dinner at El Castillito for $2.16. No kidding. That's how much their veggie tacos cost, including tax. I've been going to this place for over 5 years, and I don't think they've raised their prices. The only place I've ever had cheaper Mexican food was in Mexico.

Everything's always very fresh and tastes great. They are very generous with their portion sizes, and ingredients. They'll substitute fresh avocado instead of guacamole, give you extra beans/salsa/etc., for no additional charge. Chips are also free.

There's often a long line, but it moves fast. It's loud and crowded around dinnertime, but definitely worth it -- in terms of price and quality, I think this is the best Mexican restaurant in SF. They're much better than the more expensive Mexican places around 16th & Mission.

The guys who work for have a great (if slightly twisted) sense of humor -- sometimes they'll ask if you want "marijuana" (ie, cilantro) on your burrito... and occasionally you'll hear a cat meowing when somebody's chopping up ingredients... they get a kick out of making fake cat noises, and then looking around, surprised.

They offer fresh-squeezed juice too, now: orange, carrot, celery & beet. And their horchata is great.

Check it out -- you won't be disappointed.
author: Aidan D.

description:
This was the biggest, juiciest quesidilla of my LIFE!!!!  It had delicious steak, was so nicely grilled in a perfectly crispy flour tortilla - and they let you put whatever you want in it - mmmm!  No extra charge for guacamole, salsa, cheese - this was so much more than I've ever expected from a quesidilla (they usually have some greasy shredded meat and then cheese and cillantro, bleh!)

I've passed by this Taqueria every day on my way to school, and I can't believe I've never tried it until now.  It'll be my new favorite place next time I'm hungry late at night after class!
author: Laura W.

description:
BEST PASTOR IN THE CITY.
My god, I love this place's pastor.  They have the vertical gyro spit with the pork rotating by the heat...and dammmmmmmnnn.....
i usually get a pastor all meat burrito (you know... the whole atkins thing ;)), but one time we saw this girl, a native SFan visiting from NYC, get this torta de pastor that was a SIGHT to behold.  So me and my friends had to get some.  it was LOADED with avocado/guacamole, and pastor... and just torta perfection. 

Did I mention the clean, well lit dining area, and the efficient service?  And yes, they have a full salsa bar now, complete with sneeze-guard.  ;)  hahaha
author: Fong L.

description: Good burritos. Friendly staff. I was told to stick to carne asada, and it was quite good. The wet burrito seemed huge, even relative to the super burrito. It also took more time for them to make it since they put cheese on top of the burrito and throw it in the microwave for a few minutes.
author: Jeff L.

description: So, I really have to sing the praises of this place once more. It is an unassuming hole in the wall, but they really do their job right. Burrito tortillas are grilled, not steamed. Meat choices are quality (they claim organic). Prices are great. Plus, their chorizo breakfast plate is the best breakfast deal in the 'hood, and they are typically less crowded than other spots nearby at brunch time, too. This is a real taqueria, and a invaluable addition to the neighborhood.
author: Tom H.

description:
Back when I was a young'n and didn't care that I ate burritos and fallafels every night I frequented the Castillito. Yes, it first started off because it was close to my house but I soon discovered, even after my many burrito adventures in the mission, that this was one of my favorites. I can't speak for those who like meat in their burritos. (I am not a vegetarian p.s.) But the vegie burrito is fabulous! The reasons being 1) They grill their tortillas 2) They will give you whole avacado slices. And 3) their ingrediants are as fresh as any in the mission
So you might have your favortie taqueria and I'm not challenging you on that. But if you find yourself in the Church and Market area you must go for El Castillto... and ask for whole avocado.
author: Erin W.

description:
My bad... this is the actual place I wanted to review...

I was in search of something meaty and salty after my MCAT class, so I disembarked the J train at Church/Duboce to try out this small joint.  Lately I've been in search of very good Mexican food that resembles what they serve in those bomb diggity taco trucks.

I walk in and notice the vintage-y like red chairs that are characteristic of diners, several round tables, and a juke box on the left.  I go straight to the back to place my order:  carne asada taco (which I thought was still a bit pricey at $2.29)... then I wanted to try something new, and the tall cook told me the different meats they had: pollo, carnitas, chorizo, and barbecue pork.  "Barbecue pork?" I wondered... so I said, yeah give me one of those too.

I couldn't believe the amount of meat he scooped out and placed on the grill to reheat.  HELLA MEAT.  That's all that was in my mind.  HELLA MEAT.  The $2.29 pricetag per taco became unbelievably cheap for the amount of meat they give you.  I asked to eat in.  The tacos are 2 taco tortillas (I believe they were corn tortillas, which I love) plus the meats, then topped with onions (which I did not have), cilantro, and salsa (you have a choice of spicy and mild-aka-pico-de-gallo, but I asked for a little bit of both). 

I was extremely surprised that they have HORCHATA, so i ordered a small.  My meal came out to be $6.33.  Then the cashier asked, "Do you want chips?"  I said, "Is it free?".  He nodded.  "SURE!".  He scooped up corn tortilla chips and placed it on ANOTHER plastic tray lined with paper.  To the left of the cashier is a wonderful assortment of salsas, one resembling the kind they put in the taco.  There are 5 different types, and a bowl of sliced jalapenos.  It was a nice small salsa bar.

I got settled to my table.... then I took a bite outta the MEATY carne asada taco.  I was speechless, but I had to say it after I finished masticating the first bite:  OH MY GOD, THIS IS SOOO GOOD.  BETTER THAN TACO TRUCKS.  

I was thoroughly happy with the carne asada taco... I sipped on my Horchata and it was damn good too.  

There was this chick who ordered a special vegetarian burrito to go.  She was asked if she wanted chips as well, so I'm assuming the chips are free and you can take out your choice of salsa too.

Then I proceeded to attack the 'barbecue pork' taco... which I found was actually the "PASTOR" (marinated pork).  DAMN it was hella good too.  

I'm so happy about this experience that I give this place an all out 5 stars.  I need to take y'all out here for mah birfday!
author: Grace M.

description:
If you have 5 bucks and you want the best vegetarian quesadilla you can find in the city go to El Castillitio.  Full of all your favorite burrito fixins then grilled till the cheese gets nice and melty.  

If it's some dude who looks like a backstreet boy making your food, you're struck gold -- that guy is amazing.

Also, the salsa verde is excellent too.
author: jack p.

description:
I thought this place was awful. Not sure where all the positive comes from, but I've had some of the worst Mexican food of my life here. Furthermore, the prices are much higher than their other locations.


The only one that I like is at 17th/Mission. Word to the wise though, I've seen numerous altercations there, police chase people down in there and I once had to beat some meth freak to the ground when he tried to steal my friends backpack.
author: Hank S.

description:
Holy farking shite! I fell in love with their carnitas the second our eyes met across the crowded room. I tried to act all cool as I sauntered over to introduce myself. Before I could offer said carnitas a drink or introduction, it had already jumped in my mouth, forcing me to chew and swallow. 'Yeah,' I thought to myself, 'Mission accomplished'. 

Jesus, what the Hell am I talking about? Just go and enjoy. The staff is one of nicest in town, you can't go wrong.
author: Big W.

description: I absolutely love this place. Every time I'm in the city I make it a point to eat here. Prices are good and service also.
author: Rico R.

description: What's not to love.  Quick, cheap, delicious mexican food.  I had the quesadilla vegetariana and it was really good.  Not greasy, not overly cheesy, and the portion was huge.  The man who took my order was friendly and didn't look disgusted when I butchered the pronunciation of the word in the most gringa way possible.
author: Chelsey B.

description:
D for Damn good salsa
I for Inexpensive grub
R for Roach Infested (no, really)
T for Tasty tortas &
Y for Yikes this place is a fucking dump!

 DIRTY!!!! THIS PLACE IS D I R T Y !!!! It makes me sick just thinking about how I used to eat here!

The chicken is good, but so freaking greasy! ahhh! Adrien is nice, though.  Buy him some Stella from Burgermeister - he'll draw  you flowers on your burrito.
author: haley d.

description:
For what it is ..basically a to-go down home burrito place ..El Castillito is fantastic.
Portions: Large
Taste: fresh and flavorful
Unique items: try the Tomato Tortilla and the El Pastor - better yet try them together!
Carnitas lovely, Carne Asada - yummy.  Tortillas are warmed on the grill - not steamed to goo... ( yes!)
Staff : Friendly service and hella funny on occasion and if you speak a few Spanish words - even better.
The frijoles - refried beans are delicious here and I recommend them on the side or in your burrito.
Aqua Frescas, nice and nice portions - selection is small but good.
Much better than the other place down the street next to the market. or on the other side of Church.
 Good for a family outing.
I can rarely eat the whole burritos here - so it great to be able to take the remaining portion home and have it for a snack later on- or back to work for that pre-happy hour stomach balming snack   
The Kitchen is visible and spartan which is a nice quality in a Taqueria.
I've been coming to this place for 10 years ; its still good and my Sister and Her Husband from Nebraska are hooked and makes this a must stop on every visit.
author: Kenya P.

description:
Holy Smokes---this place will knock your socks off. It is a hole in the wall, but this hole in the wall feeds me and my roommates at least twice a week. 

Everything is amazing...but I beg you to try the #19 Quesadilla de Castillito. This is the motherload of quesadillas. In fact...it looks like a burrito. Get it and you will never forget it...or think of quesadillas the same way. 

The staff is also so endearing and nice. They roll those burritos like no other. They roll so fast and so well, you really need to know what you are ordering when you go in. 

When I walk in...I just think HOLLER, SHOT CALLER, 20 inch blades on the impala....then I order the #19
author: Jennifer W.

description: Once you learn now to order in this place, it is the jam.  My go-to is the camarones (shrimp) super burrito.  It's amazing. You just need to know what you want, and be ready to tell the burrito makers at the window as they go through all the options pretty quickly.  Al pastor is pretty delicious too.
author: Kari J.

description:
Holy hot damn.  I thought I was ready, but when I got a 12in, 2 lb burrito I began to doubt myself.  The I sat down to attack this thing with a mission in mind, I would not stop until it was fully consumed.  The burrito was great.  Chicken Super Burrito to be exact.  Delicious chicken, rice, sour cream, salsa, guacamole and hot peppers.  Well, it took me a while, and I had to take two digestion breaks, but I still finished this thing.  Then, once I had reached my goal I realized I was about to slip into a burrito coma.  I'll let you know how I feel once I come out of my carb-induced coma... 

Totally worth the scurried lunchtime commute.  I don't think I'll need to eat until tomorrow...
author: Maryam S.

description:
Two words, chorizo burrito.

It may be (literally) heart-stopping but they do it right here.

If your timing is good you can get off one N-Judah, run and grab a burrito here - then catch the next train a few minutes later.  And make everyone else on the train jealous as the smell wafts through the air.

Staff is friendly and accommodating. If you want to give detailed instructions, they'll follow.  Or else they'll make their "usual" without complaining.

If you like avocado, make sure you ask for it sliced so you don't get that green avocado sauce they put on otherwise.

Props to the orange juice machine - it's mesmerizing.
author: Rick C.

description:
This place is the best mexican food in San Francisco. I have been going here since I was a Freshmen in High School. If your not a veggie, I would suggest getting the barbecue pork regular burrito with a little sour cream. Man...this was the hang out spot for me and my friends when I was younger. It rules!!1

Its funny when pretty girls walk in and the cooks go "MEOW!!!". I know its degrading but you have to admit it makes for a funny eating experience at least.
author: Devin R.

description:
When I walk into a taqueria and I see one of those al pastor rotisserie things, my brain shuts off and my stomach takes over. My mind is helpless as my stomach directs my mouth to order a super burrito full of that delicious marinated pork.

Tonight was no exception. Only this night is different than all other nights.* Until tonight I thought I knew a good al pastor burrito but El Castillito has raised the bar. The al pastor is spicy and slightly sour; this is GOOD. I had to stop mid burrito and just savor it for a minute or two. It also came with chips & various salsa options, and apparently fresh squeezed juice is available as well. And I was in and out in minutes! I really can't ask for more.

* Is this appropriate in a review about pork? It seems disrespectful.
author: matthew r.

description:
My roommates and I have an ongoing debate over which Church-Street-between-Market-and-Duboce taqueria is better, this place or Casa Mexicana. Guy Roommate and I agree it's this place. They grill the tortilla. The super veggie is under a 5 spot. And it's about 40 steps closer than Casa Mexicana.

It's not super- particularly customer service-wise, and sometimes the lettuce and sour cream get a bit, shall we say, damp- but it's a darned sight better than the alternative.
author: Alyssa R.

description: Another Mexican joint in the mission. Wasn't the best place I have ever ate at but it wasn't bad. The place had huge portions and it wasn't too expensive so all in all if you are hungry and wanted Mexican food and were close by all means give it a try. I didn't walk out disappointed by any means.
author: Kate D.

description:
Definitely the best burrito place in the lower Haight.  I mean that not really saying much, but still, it is.  If you're coming from up the hill, like me, then just coast on down past Dolores park and follow those J-line tracks into Mexico.  Or if you're slogging up from Market, beware that you don't get confused and accidentally go into the crap Mexican place near the corner.

First of all, ordering here is a real treat.  They ask you what you want and then you get to see 'em make if for you, RIGHT THERE.  You don't even have to move down the line. 
 
Next up is paying, which is also great cause its cheap (I mean it IS a burrito. Duh)

Then comes eating.  Now, personally, I can't finish a whole burrito anymore, but these guys can sorely tempt you sometimes.  When me and Kat and Nick used to have Horror movie Sundays, this was our jam 110% cause its sooo good and pretty close.  Also their chips are not bad and their green salsa is pretty delicious. 


Everybody says you have to go to the Mission, but screw those people, cause its like when people tell you you gotta go to the Southern California.  I mean, what, did Mexicans forget how to cook during their arduous 5 hour trek North / 5 min trek from the Miss???  I didn't think so.  And neither does my mouth!
author: Bill P.

description: BEST Al Pastor and salsa verde in the CITY!!!
author: N. L.

description:
These guys are on top of their game.  Always fast, and they will add fresh Avocado to anything anytime you ask!!  The burritos are HUGE and probably weigh 2-3lbs...  super good with a cold cup of Horchata.

Ridiculous and tasty for $3-5.  Their Vegee Burrito is fantastical  and really cheap.   Oh yeah, the Salsa Fresca & Salsa Verde is the best when mixed together!!
author: Jake B.

description:
They are always friendly and their kitchen is clean! 

I LOVE their fish burrito, and they make the BEST salsa verde in San Francisco! 

I only go there for fish burritos and I have NEVER been disappointed! 

I hate sitting in and smelling every tweaker in the city! but it is a good place for take-out!
author: Maddy S.

description:
These are the hugest, hottest, tastiest, most amazingest burritos in San Francisco.  First of all, there is NO REASON to go to Casa Mexicana, located a few doors down.  When I first moved to the neighborhood, I tried that place first, and the burritos there are a joke compared to the masterpieces turned out by Castillito.  I still regret the fact that I could have had one more Castillito burrito had I just avoided Casa Mexicana.   Why visit a mere casa when you can instead dine at a castle?   

Anyhow,  if need be, park your car in the rear lot of Blockbuster if you want to immerse yourself into a Castillito burrito and don't want to waste time hunting for a spot.  No one ever parks in the ridiculously huge and under-utilized-suburban-anachhronistic Blockbuster lot, so take advantage.   

Castillito burrito tortillas are always freshly grilled (not steamed) and the meat is also grilled, right in front of your own two eyes.  The tortillas are massive, and bear the brunt of the huge selection of toppings. The guacamole is of superior quality, as are the salsas.  The two late evening shift burrito makers, (including the always funny backwards hat and glasses guy), are basically the Simon and Garfunkel of burritomaking.  Two harmonious geniuses who have joined forces to craft the most exquisite burritos on God's Earth.
author: Dan L.

description:
I personally love the Chorizo burrito.  I always add eggs, beans and cheese like you get in So. Cal. The Green sauce at the salsa bar is off the hook. I usually take home 6 or 7 containers for the chips.  

I am a fan
author: Robert M.

description:
When I start having dreams of Al Pastor, that's when I know I've been away from "the little castle" for too long. Their Al Pastor Super Burrito is perfection. Every other burrito I have had in S.F. pales in comparison. Get it with avocado. And try thier agua frescas, the watermelon was super-delicious. 

   I only dock them a star because I wish they were open later. Many times have I walked here from the Toronado, late at night and craving a burrito like a fiend, only to find them closed. I still don't know exactly when they close, it isn't posted and seems to change, but I try again and again anyway, because it's just that good...
author: Brandi K.

description:
this place was a little tricky to find, the place is cash only, there was a huge line. we went in the burritos were HUGE, did I say Huge,

they have a few tabels to sit at, 

there was a street person who came in and grabbed food out of the trash and that freaked out my daughter a little bit,

food was good and inexpensive we ate for 4 under $21.00
author: jessi s.

description:
A little dirty but very tasty Mexican food for cheap.  I have not been here for a while but I miss it now that we live so far away from any good Mexican food. 
Great burritos, if you're into that kind of thing.
author: Nilu r.

description:
I had to choose this place as my first review on Yelp...because I am completely, utterly, 100% in LOVE with their grilled veggie burrito. 

For $3.89, you get a torpedo of goodness, loaded with carrots, zucchini, broccoli, and the standard burrito fare of rice and beans. The filling is grilled to amazing perfection and stuffed GENEROUSLY into a tortilla shell of your choice. 

Seriously, these burritos are MASSIVE...and I've eaten my fair share of burritos. (I live in the heart of taquerias in the Mission, and I venture to Church and Market for these bad boys.)

Plus, who doesn't love a salsa bar?
author: Danyell K.

description:
I'd lived in the Mission for several years in the 90s.  I've braved the knots of Surenos outside Cancun.  I've walked through drunken indie vomit outside Farolitos on 24th and mission.  I've balanced my big fat behind on the little leather bench at La Taqueria.  I spent at least one year where my daily diet actually did consist of One Fat Burrito, cut into thirds - 1/3 for late night dinner, 1/3 for next day breakfast, and 1/3 for lunch.

Then one day I found myself in a serious relationship with someone who, shockingly, did not live in my neighborhood. In fact, who had rarely visited my neighorbhood at all!  

So when he wanted to stop at El Castillito one day before we headed home, I trepidated.  I said "No no! This is north of Market and west of Church!  This is far outside the bounds of the Mission.  This cannot be a burrito!   They will steam their tortillas!  There will be a Korean at the grill!  No no no!  This is wrong! So very very wrong!"

But it wasn't.  It wasn't wrong.  It was right, so very very right.

Which was a good thing because I had moved out of the Mission to his place at 14th and Church and this was now the closest taqueria to my kitchen (that other place up the street next door to Golden Produce is FOUL - that's a one timer and never make that mistake again kind of place - you were wondering and now you know - forewarned and forearmed etc etc).

So now you know, there is an island of real Mission-ness in Duboce Triangle called El Castillito.  Go ahead.  It tastes good.
author: Robyn C.

description:
I feel super fat now. 

Went here after being persuaded by these yelp reviews... damn you all. 

Anyways, got the super burrito w/carne asada. And I must say, it was damn good and juicy. Total came out to $7.04... which sounds approximately right. 

It's good, it's reasonably priced, customizable, and fattening! 

If that's not the qualities of a winner, I don't know what is. 

1 star off because I swear I've tasted this somewhere else before. Not the most unique of flavors... but still a damn good burrito.
author: Eugenia Y.

description: This place is awesome. I come here once every couple of weeks. The people who work here are really nice, and their pastor is the best in town. This is seriously one of my favorite taquerias in town. Might actually be my favorite. Writing about this place right now makes me want to head over and get a pastor super burrito right now.
author: Joe M.

description:
huge portions for plates and drinks (horchata and aquas).  very good prices.  very attentive cooks.

i really enjoy this place.  it's a hole in the wall, and the food is either going to be bad and cheap or good and cheap.  it's good and cheap.

and very satisfying.  

i ordered just a beans and rice plate, but i was left pleasantly full and very satisfied.  i hate a taste of my friend fish taco, and it was really good, too.

i order a "medium" aqua, and it was HUGE.  soooo good.

come here.  the food is simple, unpretentious, and hearty.
author: Peter K.

description:
People can preach up and down the Mission about La Taqueria or Cancun or whatever, but I prefer the Church Street Castillito over any other taqueria  in the city (except for Farolito at 3am, for obvious reasons).

I lived up the street from Castillito for 11 years (Yea, i know, I got a little comfortable), and they knew my order. It wavered in the 90s to a veggie burrito, but the condiments and additions were always the same.

 "Super burrito with carnitas. Beans? Oh black, thanks. Everything on it, yes. Thanks. Mild salsa but can you spoon some jalapenos into it? Thanks!"

And then i would go to the salsa containers and spoon the verde salsa into 3 plastic little containers. Walk home and snack on chips for two blocks.

Repeat this atleast once, if not 2 times a week. 4 times a week while i was in college and broke.

I love you, Castillito. Nothing can replace you or your amazing carnitas.
author: Olivia W.

description:
Cheap and delicious Mexican food right across from Castro Safeway.  I often get burritos and tacos with pastor at The Little Castle, but my favorite is the chicken super nachos.  The chips are not the greatest, but they are very thick - an ideal foundation for the massive payload of grilled meat, beans, cheese, avocado and salsa that the super nachos deliver.  Don't plan on doing much after you eat the super nachos - just get to a safe, soft place, and allow yourself an hour or two for the blissful food coma to pass.  

While I don't ever get it myself, friends swear by the super veggie burrito, despite its lack of vegetables that aren't lettuce.  The salsa is also excellent.  My roommate once filled a styrofoam pint cup with the tomatillo variety, and while customers looked on incredulously, I couldn't judge him for wanting to bring as much home with him as possible.
author: Sean K.

description:
The al pastor here is the best I've ever tasted.

I'd reccommend the al pastor taco con queso with avocado on it.

I've pushed this little item on many a friend and now we're all hooked.
author: Shannon W.

description: This is a great place to get a late night burrito but its not the best though that I have had. The chips are great but they charge you for them instead of coming with the burrito as complimentary. Its awesome that they are open until midnight
author: Nadia N.

description: Great burritos, super nice staff, fair prices and always fresh food. Really nice people and I love that they have an ATM inside.. the guys who are cooking are super nice, friendly and have a great sense of humor..
author: Brian W.

description: Came here after drinks and I had the munchies. Ordered a regular burrito and my cousins ordered nachos. Freshly made and they give good portions. Staff was really friendly and helpful. I guess you shouldn't go late at night because they ran out of ingredients for this fish burrito that I wanted.
author: Laura F.

description:
$3.98 for the super fish taco is a fantastic and tasty bargain.  This is a surprising amount of food.  

The rest of the menu is similarly tasty and cheap too.
author: joe b.

description:
My favorite burrito place in the Castro. It's probably not really a lot to write home about, but I really like the breakfast burritos and I've gone enough that the staff knows me and that feels pretty nice. 

Just had a beef tamale last night and was pretty happy with it.
author: Tyler S.

description:
Not much else to be said about this place, this was my neighborhood spot for a few years and I want to move back so I can eat it more often.  

I do want to point out that it's relatively cheap by itself, but let this jew fill you in on a secret, Safeway receipts on the back have a "buy one burrito and a drink and get another one free" printing.  So I used to shop at safeway all the time, I had piles, but now when I'm in the area I usually scour the safeway parking lot for a receipt.  I kinda feel bad for using the "coupon" but shit, they have an example one on their register, they WANT me to use it!!!

Their amazing burritos just got twice as good!!

I hate soda but I also get their mexi-cokes.  mmmmm
author: jack s.

description:
Carne Asada Super Burrito

- It never disappoint, every single time, consistently awesome

Salsa Verde

- By far the best Salsa Verde I ever have, must be the avocado in it that makes it uber awesome
author: Davvy L.

description:
I ordered the Veggie Burrito and basically got sour cream and iceberg lettuce wrapped in a tortilla with a little bit of rice and a few beans. It was seriously nasty.  The breakfast burrito was super greasy and contained only sausage and eggs.  The Super Pastor burrito was edible, but on the whole it was a very disappointing experience.

With all the other Tacqueria options available in San Francisco, I doubt I will ever visit El Castillito again.
author: Shayna N.

description:
The al pastor is a classic case of lust vs. love -- there's a rotating spit of it where you place your order, but it does not meet my needs for long-term burrito satisfaction.  I have five "issues" with my favorite taqueria meat as prepared at the Little Castle:

1) It is really sour and one-dimensional.  It lacks the balanced "tang" that still lets the sweet pork flavor come through, such as with the al pastor at Taq. Cancun or Taq. SF.

2) Call me cray cray, but I don't enjoy magic-8-ball-level variability in the size of my burritos.  The quantity of meat (and other ingredients) in burritos varies substantially from visit-to-visit.  Yesterday, the burritos were gi-fucking-normous.  But two weeks ago, they were only average-sized.  

3)  Rice always has a Minute-Rice (tm) flavor and texture -- it's bland and stands out in all the wrong ways. 

4) The great self-serve salsas lack a great sneeze-guard.  

5)  Food safety-wise, there was a counter full of raw chicken parts that was a) sitting at room temp for the duration of my visit and b) seemed a little too close to the cooked food prep area.

But these concerns aside, Castillito is worth trying if you like your burritos with well-grilled tortillas and lots of melted cheese.
author: Steve K.

description: Great food (get chicken burrito). Very cheap for quantity. Plus they serve Jarrito's soda (Chipotle really needs to get on their sh*t with that). Only problem that street/area seems a little sketchy. There were two fights within the restaurant, thus not greatest dining experience.
author: Brinda G.

description:
This place rules. Hard. 

I can't even recall how many times I've stumbled in here after serious benders to munch on one of their fine, fine burritos. These burrito's are huge too. I'm talking the size of a rather large infant. The quesadilla's are also the jam, and roughly the size of a smaller, flatter infant. 

One word of warning. Don't eat one of these bad bwoys before you go out drinking with your palz...bad things will happen.
author: Cliff C.

description:
YUM CITY, is what this place should be called.  the chicken quesadilla is to die for.
it's also home of my favorite burrito - chicken burrito, xtra quac and avacado, chz, pintos, sour cream.
i think it's the grilled tortilla that makes them so good.
mmmmmmm
author: Mary C.

description:
It was pretty damn good ... not shockingly great though. I went off the advice of fellow yelpers... got the carne asada quesadilla .. it was really good .. don't get me wrong ... but it was as one yelper said .. a little runny and watery. I was actually down to like three bites left on one half and the bottom exploded and shot sour cream/watery sauce like a foot across my dining table. :)
I also ordered a jumbo carrot juice (only  $5) pretty large... drank some this morning with breakfast .. delish :) 
They lose points for the chips they gave me being stale and the salsa fresca was not that fresca.
If you are near the Castro Safeway and are in the mood for mexi .. park your car in the Safeway lot ... cruise over there and try it out ... 
definately above average.
author: Jeremy R.

description: I want to give this place four stars, but maybe next time. I walked here from Cafe du Nord because I was starving and it was the only highly rated establishment in the area that was still open. The burrito I had was pretty good. My only gripe is that the salsa wasn't evenly distributed and so I forgot I had even gotten a spicy burrito until halfway through when the spice finally hit me. It was also a tad wet, and I'm just going to blame the salsa for that too. Other than those things, my veggie super burrito was one of the best meatless burritos I've ever had. I will definitely return if I'm in the area.
author: k h.

description: Torta Al Pastor is hella bomb! (: I am normally not one to finish my food but I just had to. My bf usually ends up eating half of mine but this time I finished the whole torta. Yes, it was THAT good. It's rather cheap and fast. The al pastor was to die for. It was marinated and cooked to perfection. The meat was incredibly juicy and I literally ate every little piece that fell out of the torta. I did not mind looking like a messy kid because it was finger lickin good. (:
author: Jeanette N.

description:
Good, reasonably priced Mexican.

If you are craving a heaping mound of cheesy, meaty, deliciously greasy nachos, this is the place, particularly if you are a Muni rider--El Catillito is a mere block from the underground.

Spend an extra couple dollars and order a large Melon drink. Horchata is decent as well! I definitely frequent here when I am in the area and craving good Mexican.
author: Sara D.

description: Good chips and salsa, fast, cheap.  Better chips than similar taquerias and ties with Farolito for best deal.  My go-to is the epic Super Nachos with their pickled jalapeños, any meat's fine really.  The fish burrito's also quite nice.  Easily the best taqueria jukebox.  Quaint atmosphere, more pleasant than the tourist factory at Pancho Villa or the divey grunge of Farolito or Cancun.
author: s b.

description:
It feels a little odd to be leaving the Mission to get Mexican food.  But when I am the only person ordering in English, I feel like I am getting pretty authentic food.

Also, the Huevos Rancheros are super tasty.
author: Steve S.

description: I was really drunk when I went here but I remember really loving the people inside, layout, food; the whole experience.  I should go back :-)
author: Aaron W.

description:
Besides the fact that their food is stellar... the burrito guy always flirts with me in Spanish ("Frijoles negros, como tus ojos?"  "Queso o un beso?") which is somehow completely adorable and acceptable...    To top it off, the cashier guy draws hearts and smiley faces on my foil wrapper which is so cute it makes me want to die.  And they let me practice my mediocre high school-level Spanish and not feel like a complete idiot in doing so.

Please don't PM me and tell me he does this for you too, because my small bubble of burrito happiness will be popped and it will be all your fault.
author: Tovah S.

description:
Best Burrito in the city-Hands Down!
But my tip to you--Do not leave your burrito unattended, as a homeless person may come and grab it.
author: Shari E.

description: My very favorite Taqueria. Cheap, authentic and consistent.  The same people, with the same awesome food. I recommend the "Quesadilla El Castillito." It is simply fantastic.  The perfect solution to satisfy post run or long ride cravings.
author: Christopher S.

description:
Not exactly the most flavorful but this place is a great standby.

The burritos are HUGE and the staff extremely friendly. My boyfriend usually tells me his order while he hides outside (yes, we've memorized the menu) and I go order ... the ladies tend to get HOOKED UP if they're extra "smiley," hence my cheap ass boyfriend hiding out front (Baby, if they see me with you, we won't get the overflowing meat! We'll have to pay extra!). 

The salsa seems to have gotten even hotter over the years but that don't bother me at all.
author: Joyce S.

description: Pretty great place. The service is quick and friendly, and the burritos are delicious and generously portioned. I like the burritos at Taqueria Cancun only marginally more by comparison, but I go here much more often because it's closer and usually not as crowded.
author: adrian b.

description:
you know, I got a burritto from here last night and there are a couple of things that make this joint my favorite taqueria in the city. 
First off, probably the most flavorful carne asada around. I am really kind of talking about the vicinity of the church street area. I've tried the other two and this one takes the cake. 
secondly, who could resist a taqueria that draws a heart on the outside of your burritto? It melts my heart. Thank you.
author: Erin O.

description:
Listen up, Yelpers.
I'm about to get serious.

This place has the best fucking burrito in the Bay Area.
Not just the city - but the entire Bay - perhaps even all of Northern California.

I was hesitant to eat here initially - since my sensibilities were offended by the smelly and toothless homeless guy out front, gumming his dumpster-dive tacos. However, after much hassling by my boyfriend - I finally went in.

And have raved ever since.

My bf, at the time, lived in the triangle and LITERALLY ate a Carne Asada burrito - these things are the size of your damn head, people - every day.  EVERY DAY!! and I didn't get it... 

so I went in. and was converted.

I don't eat meat so I can't comment on the CA -but the veggie burritos are heaven on earth, as are the quesadillas. Basically a burrito that is way cheesy and toasted on the grill.  Mad props for the entire damn avocado in there and the wads of cilantro and fresh salsa...mmmmmmm
author: Gina P.

description:
Well, I had never eaten here because it was located almost next door to another taqueria that I like very much. In fact, I probably wouldn't have visited at all, but I was a little um... how do you say... buzzed? So, it didn't matter that this wasn't my first choice. I was hungry and I was going to eat.

When we walked in, it didn't look super nice. The trash was full (almost to overflowing) and the floor seemed a bit dirty. The colors inside were sort of like the color of a hot dog - yellow, red and white. I thought - hmm... this food could be really bad, but I'm hungry enough that it doesn't matter.

So, we stood in line and ordered from the out-of-order menu on the wall (just look at the numbers - you'll see what I mean). I didn't really see anything I wanted (was looking for a combo with tacos, and they didn't have one). 

My experience took a turn for the better when I started ordering with the cooks directly (this is how everyone orders). You actually talk to the people cooking your food over this fiberglass window. It's great! I ended up asking for a bean & cheese burrito and a cheese quesadilla. My boyfriend ordered something similar (oh, he got a veggie taco - mmm!). The cooks we ordered from were really funny and nice and understood our Spanish! Plus, they pretty much gave us whatever we wanted on our food (salsa, guacamole, sour cream - whatever you wanted to add).

The next thing was paying for the food. It was less than 10.00 for two quesadillas (little ones), a veggie taco (huge!) and a bean & cheese burrito (huger!). Wow, nice to eat this cheap in San Francisco once in a while! I was impressed by the price.

Finally, the food actually tasted great! This is according to our slightly inebriated palates, of course. But, you know, I think I would go back and try it again!

Overall, this is a very friendly, tasty and affordable place to eat. If you don't mind being a little less classy for a meal (because this is anything but glamorous dining) and you generally like taqueria food - go for it, I say! Just don't slip on that pile of rice and beans in the middle of the floor...
author: Jason B.

description: hands down best burrito spot in the city. I grew up in SF and have been going to this place for ten years. I usually average about 4 cups of green sauce per sitting. and thats on a bad day.
author: Liam H.

description:
"Some people, well, if they don't like Scientology, well, then, fuck you. Really. Fuck you. Period." - Tom Cruise

That's kind of how I feel about this place.
author: Jackson R.

description:
This is the kind of place that when I'm on the freaking N Judah from downtown on a weekend going to my boony apt in the sunset (and i've already waited 30 minutes for said muni train at market street mind you), it makes me jump off the train regardless of hunger levels and lures me inside in a taqueria-loving zombie-like manner down church street.

despite the slightly sketchy tortilla warmer guy who drew a flower on the foil on my burrito cause he thought i was bonita, i have been known to finish said remainder of burrito at work the next day for lunch, grease soaking through the tortilla and sharpie flowered foil and all. don't get me wrong, i could finish one of those suckers in one sitting, however, its SO good to look forward to the next heaping half the day after.
author: verna b.

description:
I've been broke as hell putting my butt back through school at a much later age than I should be.  However, despite the work load I found a little plastic basket filled with happiness at the end of each day.  A veggie taco for $2.00 (update $2.25).  It was appx 1/2 lb. of latin love, add to that the chips they give to you and you have a decent meal for under $3.00.

But now that I'm done with school and don't have to scrimp and scrape to much I've opened up my horizons with my amigos.  The chorizo breakfast burrito is awesome (toss on some black beans and it's a fiesta that everybody will be invited to!) and available early enough to make me want to skip the lines at the trendy breakfast troughs and get my burrito to go so I can be on with my day.

Ditto on the pastor, it's pretty fantastic...but I usually like to split that burrito when I get it super because it's bigger than all of the human race put together.

Bonus points for window seating.
author: josh h.

description:
I used to hate this place: I tend to get all warm & fuzzy for a good burrito, and the burritos here do not meet my exacting standards.

the quesadillas, however, ARE UNBEFUCKINGLIVABLE. 

I order a carnitas quesadilla with just avo & sour cream. what I get looks more like a burrito than the quesadillas I'm used to, but it is amazing, dripping grease and things that will no doubt clog my arteries. 

that is all.
author: Kelly Kate W.

description: I was really disappointed in this place. I made an effort to try it after hearing it was very good, but my burrito was AWFUL. I ordered the Super Vegetarian Burrito and it was 85% runny pico de gallo. Just because I ordered no meat doesn't mean I want all onion, cilantro and tomato. My boyfriend had the Super Burrito with carne asada and seemed pretty pleased with it. But after all, this is my review and I'm sorry to say it was the worst burrito I've ever had. Perhaps it is just not the place to go for a veggie burrito.
author: Katie S.

description:
Dinner for 2 for under $10, well until they raised their rates a bit and now its $11 something, but still a great deal.  Fast, consistently delicious.  Love the location and the folks who work there they are always friendly and fun!
Its my staple taqueria.   And don't skimp on the the salsa bar!  The green salsa is amazing!!
author: Rachel V.

description: I just had a burrito here the other day and was pretty disappointed. The EL Pastor was boring. The burrito was mostly rice. the $7 price tag seemed a little much for mostly rice. I wouldn't stay in there to eat because its a little gross. So many better options.
author: Gregory P.

description: YUMMY! One of the best burritos I've had, they are up there with Gourdos! I had the fish burrito and it was really good. My other half had the vegetable burrito and it was great and definitely a healthier burrito. The vegetables were cooked in front of you and hot off the grill. Will definitely be back.
author: Cherish J.

description:
This place is consistently great! The cooks are so friendly and seem to care about the food they're making. I always see them chopping up fresh ingredients and it comes through in the flavor. AND, one of the cooks always draws a funny face on my quesadillas (5th star for that!). 

The Food:
Fish tacos: AWESOME!! Fish never tastes fishy. Huge portions.
Al Pastor tacos: Delicious!
Suiza quesadilla: Almost too good - in an indulgent kind of way :) 
(Tip: ask for fresh avocado instead of guacamole in burritos and quesadillas)
Carne asada - no "bad pieces", not dry.
Shrimp platter (I forget what it's called) is really flavorful and fresh and the shrimp are usually cooked perfectly (still juicy, not tough), although one time they were slightly overdone. It's the most expensive thing on the menu, but worth it.

I'm pretty picky about Mexican food - this place tastes like the owner and employees care about making great tasty food.
author: cori r.

description: Simply the best menu around. Super friendly service. Try the super barrito
author: Aris S.

description: 2 words.. Super Nachos. Another word? OUCH. No seriously they were good, but most of it was CHEESE. I mean, cheese is good, but not when you have to cut the cheese with a fork.
author: Gina I.

description: Hands down! This place makes the best carne asada!! I come here for their burritos at least once a week since my bf loves eating it so much!! They're probably the best burritos I've ever had. The workers are super friendly and funny! They always draw things on my burrito.. haha cute
author: Malisa W.

description:
This place is solid. Burrito al pastor is a delicious, greasy adventure ... on the healthier side I like the pollo asado or carne asada plate. Portions are huge .. if your hunger is epic, ask for tortillas at the kitchen and chips at the checkout, they are free and delicious with El Castillito's awesome (and spicy) salsas.
Logistics ... this place is small, there's about 6 or 8 tables and a counter. If you're a big group you might have to jockey for a while to get adjacent tables
author: Teo W.

description:
My ABSOLUTE fav!! I stop here on the regular. It's right down the hill from my 'hood. If I'm driving, I can park across the street in the Safeway parking lot - shhh, don't tell them that I said that. And above all, the SUPER CHICKEN QUESADILLA is DELICIOUS, AMAZING, yes my friend, the ABSOLUTE SHIZZ!!! 

It's as big as a burrito and there's a ton of chicken with this marinade that is addictive. I suggest ordering it with the mild salsa b/c if you get the hot it will interfere with the tangy goodness. Get your medium or hot salsa fix on the side. And yes, I would like fresh advocados instead of the guac. I have had the super nachos - delish. I have had the taco salad - delish. All with chicken, of course. But I always go back for the quesadilla b/c it is the truth.

Also, everyone who works there is SUPER NICE! Sometimes I even get some flowers or hearts drawn onto the foil of my finished quesa masterpiece. Made with LOVE.

Yes, the line may be long. It's well deserved. Get in there and order up when called upon. ENJOY!!!
author: Ilisha J.

description: GOD LOVE YOU! Alls I got is Pura Carne Burrito, BOO-YA!
author: Rob L.

description:
It's a cool place, they're almost always a futbol match on the TV and the guys who work there are funny. Not to mention the crazies who come in that'll entertain you ("I'll kick your ***, boy! I was in the naaaavy!")

I came here with friends and wasn't really hungry, so I thought a quesadilla would be good. I ordered the  Quesadilla de Castillito and what I got was a new favorite Mexican place in San Francisco. I thought they had given me the wrong order, because this thing was freakin HUGE. It's grilled on both sides and appears more like a burrito than a quesadilla, I highly recommended it.

Their burritos are pretty much the cheapest in the area (but still good), their tacos are stacked mountainously tall, their enchilada plates are great as well. The only thing they could improve are their chips and red salsas.
author: Daniel R.

description:
Many Muni Riders may know of this place, and it is good.

Oh, San Francisco and Burritos.  Those two words have been synonymous for many night dwellers of the city.  Everyone is up to try each taqueria in the city to see for themselves who won the Burrito Wars.

This place is awesome.  I think that this place is a kind of an unsung hero; and I would say it is one of the best tacqueria in the city.  This used to be one of my regular neighborhood stops.  I would always come here for a quick and cheap juicy burrito.  I absolutely love their Super Burrito.  They also added a Wet Burrito to their menu quite some time ago.  The Carne Asada here is so juicy and delicious.  To me they are much better than many of the other tacquerias in town, and you dont have to venture far from the center of the city to get there.

The service is fast, and they get you in and out of the door relatively quickly; no matter how long the line can get.   By the time you know it, you will be out the door ready to banana-peel your greasy burrito out of its foil wrapping to hastingly devour it.  

However, I do wish they had more side fixings like Azteca Taqueria down the street has.  The burritos here are better though.  I would probably sneak into Azteca to grab some of their salsa and cilantro for my burrito from El Castillo.  Shh...don't tell anybody.

Great burritos for either on the run or to sit down and enjoy.
author: Satoru Y.

description:
SUPER BURRITO WITH CHORIZO! love it! 

Used to go here every so often when I worked about 5 minutes away from this spot...and I REALLLY MISS IT!

Probably one of the top burrito spots i've been to! They are usually pretty quick with orders. Really great service!
author: Paul A.

description:
Hands down my favorite burrito in SF!

  Jaded Socal transplant here! Ever since I moved to the bay area I have been trying to find Mexican food that matches my SoCal haunts. Say what you will but black beans and whole wheat tortillas does not an "authentic" Mexican meal make. Not to mention the lack of spiciness in many salsas up here.  El Castillito is an exception to this however. I love love love their veggie burrito. Refried beans, HOT salsa, gooey cheese and fresh avocado if you ask for it!. I have to admit there's room for their chips to improve BUT their avocado salsa makes up for it by far. It's crisp and refreshing but spicy  and full of flavor. Pair it with a beer or a Mexican Coke and you're in heaven :) Granted I haven't tried anything else on their menu, but when you find perfection that's consistent,  portable and affordable why veer from it?
author: chelsea b.

description:
If I happen to only catch the J home or any others and stop at the Church station I immediately think it was in the cards.  Now I am able to justify bringing home some El Castillito!  The taqueria gods shine upon me when such instances occur!  

Hmmm, always a line.  Maybe the gods are shining on others too...Oh well, that way I know they'll stay in business.  

Everything on the menu is good to go.  The staff is efficient and friendly.  The prices are what you'd expect.  The interior is comfy enough to get your fix while there, i.e. can't wait to get home to stuff my face.

Only one negative though.  Outside, w/i 20 yard parameter, there are numerous people hanging out asking for money.  I offer something from inside as I'm going in and usually treated w/ disgust for such a stupid question.  I have to ignore when I leave as the first couple times I restate that I'm willing to buy them a burrito or something got the repeated, "not going to help me!"...Oh well, given the awesomeness of this place they are missing out double time.
author: Chris D.

description:
I've done the shopping. I've done the reviews. Best Dang Burrito in the City. I'm sorry, but this is some of the best chicken in the city for burritos.

Great flavors, great portions, great prices. I could do without the hobo's and crazies, but that's why we love San Francisco right?
author: Erik U.

description:
Lets call a spade a spade. there are a few kinds of burrito joints. The Fresh ones, the Salvadorean ones, and the sleazy ones. This is a fine example of the latter (El Farolito is also in the class). I wouldn't generally give a place like this 3 stars, except sometimes I get in this mood, and I just have to have an Al Pastor burrito with sour cream. And this is the place to get it. Holy Jesus its goooooooooooooooooooood.

Most days I would go to Casa Mexicana three doors down because that place is far and away a superior taqueria, but like I said, sometimes I get in a mood. If you are looking to get your slum on, this is the spot in the Church and Market hood.

Don't get your hopes up though. This place is greasy and raunchy - just in a good way.
author: Zac H.

description:
8.3.06 UPDATE:  Have had a few burritos from this place and they rock!  Love that grilled tortilla flavor.  That's the difference between a good burrito and a great burrito, the grilled (not steamed) tortilla.

Four stars for the chicken soft taco's with fresh avocado I ordered.  One star back for the ambiance. 

I like my taqueria's to have a healthy dose of ambiance which can be t.v. with soccer, music, families sitting around talking with children running all over the place, anything...this place has none of that.  A good place for Take Away.

They do make a great soft taco.  Plain, simple, no beans, rice, or other unnecessary stuff.  Just the small corn tortilla, grilled white meat chicken seasoned, salsa, and I added fresh avocado.  Yum.   

For you burrito lovers, as I was waiting for my food, I looked around to see what other people were eating and it looks like they grill the burrito tortilla instead of steaming which is a nice touch and adds a ton of flavor.  

El Castillito es sabroso!
author: James M.

description:
This place is good. 

They have a variety of tortilla options (wheat, spinich etc) which is nice. 

I am allergic to onions so Mexican food can be a challenge for me but they are always very accommodating and do things like offer plain avocado instead of pre mixed guac. 

if you are a vegetarian there are plenty of options here. I would recommend the super veggie for value. 

If you are a regular here be sure to save your SAFEWAY receipts because they almost always have great coupons for this place. My boyfriend eat here often with the coupon and our bill comes out to $8.50 for two super veggies and two drinks. That's cheap and a lot of yummy food!
author: Holly S.

description: I was deciding between 3 and 4 stars.  It is very cheap and most of the time it is very good, but I have had a few bad experiences.  There is one nasty check out lady that can ruin your experience, but overall the staff is very nice.  They have fresh juices, but my main reason for the 3 stars is because the food is inconsistent.  Sometimes it is 5 stars and sometimes it is 2.
author: Jonathan U.

description: Okay I am confused. This place can not be the same place I went to. The first time I was there my quesadilla tasted like a dirty wash cloth and I wasted my money on that meal. Not even the homeless people that wander around near there would take it when they found out it was not from casa mexicana (the neighboring spot). Decided to try it again and got there veggie burrito because it supposedly has VEGGIES. It doesn't and it was not under 5 dollars like a previous comment stated. In addition, it gave me mud butt like you wouldn't believe to the point that I am making this review from the same place I have been for the last 35 minutes - my toilet seat. Maybe I just have a weaker stomach and different expectations from Mexican food but I will not come back here again.
author: Tokunbo A.

description:
Ok, so, I like this place specifically for the Carnitas.  
Say it with me: Car-ni-ta-licious.

The best pork in the city, IMHO.
author: Chris M.

description:
I really like this place.  It's not the best food, but when I lived in Berkeley and before I had a bike I'd stop by here before catching a train to get back to BART and out to the East Bay.

Anyways, I enjoy their tacos and usually get a taco or two with a Mexican Coke (no hfcs ftw!).  Pretty good and filling for on the cheap!
author: daniel m.

description: I'm still a burito whore:-D I came here pretty often.  My favorite cook guy seems to be gone somewhere else but they still make the best burito. Oh Yeah, they have to increase their prices on the buritos:  $5.45 for the regular.   They added more choices for the salsa.  Added fresh squeeze juices like carrots, and OJ.  After a tough day at work and you feel like not cooking and always my mind tells me to ran and not walk to get the carne asada burito.  Boy, it has to be the tastiest salsa that  I ever have I want to swim in it!!
author: Mar H.

description:
I have had the burritos here many times since it is so close to where I live. This is a good place, but not amazing like some of the taquerias in the city. They make the burritos how you ask them and have good service, but their meat and tortillas are not super flavorful.

Again this is a good place to go, but you can find better mexican places in San Francisco.
author: Daniel L.

description: Amazing food, friendly staff.  Usually pretty quick too, though sometimes a line.  We live in Duboce Triangle and often take guests there, they dig it too....
author: J M.

description: The El Castillito Quesadilla Suiza rocks. They have the most flavorful meats and everything is incredibly fresh. They make awesome homemade salsa and juices. Everything a this place is awesome!
author: Nicholas H.

description: I want to be best friends with their green salsa.  Sleepovers, movie nights, trips to the spa... I love it.  I need it in my life.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
After trying a slew of burrito places around SF, El Castillito on Church is still one of my favorites.  The main selling point for me is the green salsa, made from avocado and tomatillos.  When they get it to the right consistency, it is the #1 salsa I've had anywhere.  Of course, it's not always "on", and this, in turn, might make for a slightly disappointing meal.  But overall, really good stuff. 

For ambiance, the El Castillito on Mission is my favorite.. the quality *may* be a little worse, and the customers are - for sure - a little worse for wear (ok, some ALOT worse for wear), but that's part of the charm, I suppose.  I've seen some pretty mundane things, some sad things, some uncomfortable things, and - most importantly - some funny things (at least in a cosmic sense) while eating meal at this other Castillito.  I chalk it all up in the name of dinner theater. 

And the green salsa flows here just the same.
author: Eric H.

description:
My friend told me this was her favorite burrito place in the city. It's in the Castro right across from Safeway. The restaurant is small. You order in the back from the restaurant and the place gets pretty crowded. They have a selected menu - mostly of burritos. We ordered 2 regular burritos and the guy made 2 super burritos instead. When we paid, they charged us for 2 regular burritos. (I hear they get nasty on you if you call them out on the wrong order!) They have a good variety for a salsa bar - it's pretty spicy! 

The burritos themselves are HUGE! They were pretty good despite it wasn't what we ordered. I think I'll stick with the taquerias on Mission.
author: Gladys C.

description:
I would do anything to come here on a lunch break, and I work all the way downtown! I had heard they had some really good burritos and I wasn't disappointed. It's pretty simple: go up there, order what you want with your choice of tortilla, meat, and whatever else you want in there. I love that it's hot and oh so good. 

A good burrito that's not expensive: as it should be! I'm sure I'll try something else later on (like the chicken tacos, since that seems like that's another good choice), but right now I'm sticking with what I love.
author: Caroline L.

description: I didn't expect pickled carrots in my vegetarian quesadilla; it was good! $4.89, plus tax and tip circa $6. The place looks a little shabby, but their  SF Health Department inspection score is 100/100. By comparison the fancy, overpriced Samovar Tea Lounge scores 85/100.
author: Mortimer S.

description: Wow! I can't believe I work so near here and haven't tried the place yet. I was really missing out. I had the Chicken burrito (regular) - You can stand there and watch them make it in front of your eyes. The prices were really reasonable and the burrito was delicious. The chips were thick and fresh and the salsa bar gave me plenty of choices. I really love a sort of dry burrito cause then I can just pour salsa on it as I devour huge bites and not let the burrito get soggy. I definitely plan on making this place my next go to burrito joint.
author: Jena D.

description: No doubt the best al pastor in The City! A flavorful rush hoarding each and every corner of your mouth. By the end of the meal your eyes will be half open in staggering search of a pillow.  It's an addicting CHOW experience.
author: Soryya S.

description:
Oh my beloved little castle...
I live in the area and with a wide variety of Taquerias to choose from, and I always choose this place because of it's great service, great food, and great prices.  Here you'll find the best burrito outside of the Mission served up just the way you want it by a very warm and genuine staff.  I only wish they were open just a little bit later for a post-bar burrito run.    
Beautiful burritos abound here.  Just make sure that when the guy asks you if you want a kiss or some cheese (queso o un beso?), you choose the cheese.
author: Marie S.

description:
You won't find me writing many five star reviews and it probably is overkill for this taqueria, but I cannot help myself.  Nowhere (and I mean NOWHERE) else can I get spicy green salsa with my burrito.  And VERY few places offer chorizo for a burrito as does El Castillito - as a matter of fact, it is a low fat version that is spicier and better than its full fat brother!

The staff is friendly, the food is edible and tasty, and it doesn't cost a whole lot of money.  What more could I ask for?  Nothing!

I eat here a lot.  :-)

PS My criteria for judging a restaurant is based on price vs. what you get for the money.  If I eat at a fast food restaurant and can keep it down, then that's money well spent.  If I dine at a five star French restaurant which serves a three figure meal and I do not reach Nirvana during the meal, then it's money poorly spent.

UPDATE: Unfortunately, for unknown reasons, this place is declining in quality.  The "refried" beans have become watery, the chorizo has become less spicy, and the cooks have taken to being less attentive to the ordering.  The prices have risen and the burritos have become smaller!  Whereas I used to delight in consuming their burritos, I now no longer go out of my way.  Three stars.
author: Richard W.

description:
Yum!  It's worth going a little bit out of my way for a burrito from El Castillito instead of opting for the easier but ultimately less satisfying Pancho Villa fare.  There are many reasons El Castillito kicks ass.  Let me tell you a few:

1. Their tortilla chips are awesome.  Some of the awesomest tortilla chips I've ever had.  Crispy but not too hard, a good amount of corn mealy-ness, and just the right touch of salt.  Even the next day, when I woke up starving and ended up eating them for breakfast, they were delicious, if a little stale.

2.  They put real avocado on your burrito!  And a lot of it, too.  You can get guacamole too, but I love me some fresh avocado.

3.  Perfectly soft tortilla.  Perhaps this doesn't seem to merit its own mention, but a hard or overly floury tortilla can totally ruin any burrito experience.  No worries here.

4.  Fresh cilantro!  As a kid, I hated cilantro.  Whenever my mom bought salsa with cilantro, I would instate the silent treatment until she went out and bought some sans cilantro salsa.  No longer.  Now I can't get enough of the stuff.  And El Castillito is generous with this herbaceous goodness, bringing their burritos to the next level.

The carne asada was pretty good, but I'm excited to try to carnitas and pastor next time I come.  Hell, I'm just excited for the next time I come.
author: Rachel B.

description:
I went here the other day, and got a pollo burrito... and I wasn't really that impressed- I didn't think the chicken was very good. I was fairly distraught at this, because most of the reviews for this taqueria were very positive! I knew something must be wrong, as who was I to question the will of the masses?

So, today, I again found myself at the corner of Church & Duboce, so I figured I'd give the place another try. This time, I eschewed the chicken in favor of a carne asada super burrito. It was a good choice, as this was an awesome burrito. It was big, and stuffed with meat, rice, beans, cheese, and all other things that one would expect in a burrito (a super burrito, nonetheless). I don't know if I just had bad luck the last time, or if the beef is just better than the chicken, but this time around, the meat was great. I donno what the guy that says the beef is really bad chicken is talking about - this was definitely beef. The fact that they grill the tortilla for longer than most other taquerias was really nice, too. Also, the burritos are cheap, especially considering the amount of stuff you get in them.

My only complaint is that the guacamole could be thicker.

p.s. their salsa verde is pretty good. get it.
author: Edward C.

description:
Hands down my favorite taqueria in San Francisco.

What I like about this taqueria:
The tortilla is warmed on the griddle, not steamed.
The meat is warmed on the griddle before being put in the taco/burrito/whatever.
You can see the food prep and cooking happening all the time and it is easy to see how they handle the food, how sanitary are the conditions, and what is homemade, etc.
The service is fast.
There are usually 3 aguas fresca choices and they are always good.
Prices are great.

What I would change:
The tortilla chips are just okay, heavy in salt, and obviously mass produced. But I eat them anyways.
author: Gary M.

description:
1. Best salsa verde in SF.

2. The Quesadilla Castillito stuffed with jalapenos.  Soooo spicy.  Sooo good.  Get it with al pastor/ makes me want to eat meat again.

3.  Speaking of- their veggie burritos are greeaaaat.

4. The super breakfast burrito is the ultimate bundle of cholesterol and protein.  Just eggs and chorizo.  I think I cried the first time I had one.  

5.  Did I mention the salsa verde?
author: H H.

description: This place is better than I originally thought. Since my first time going, I have ordered the regular vegetarian burrito with a wheat tortilla and it was really good! I even asked the lady working there is they had slices of lime, and she hands me an entire lime on the house! For being a block away, it's totally worth it! ....oh and did i mention cheap?
author: Sonya D.

description:
Bo may knows sports, but El Castilito definitely knows burritos (and sports aren't edible).

If you're PFH (pretty f*ing hungry) then order the super burrito.  Pick a meat.  After you've fired off your order, right in front of your face the nice gentleman (and they are all very nice) grabs two spatulas full of the meat you've ordered and plops the pile on the grill.  After taking care of salsa, cheese, beans, sour cream and guacamole, the meat is then ceremoniously put on top of your open burrito, a dazzling crown, if you will, to make you drool for a few seconds until your burrito is carefully rolled and then handed to you.  For a little more than $7, which beats the prices of a few places in the mission, you get a depth charge of meat cheese and beans with all the extras without paying extra.  If you can finish the whole thing, you likely won't need another meal until night.  It isn't any wonder why I've started coming here twice a week... (I was hungry).
author: Steven R.

description:
Hands down, best taqueria in san francisco.
I love the regular burritos al pastor (yummy spicy barbequed pork that I crave at least once every few weeks) con salsa caliente (with jalapenos!) and un poco de crema. And homemade tortilla chips with mexican coke in a bottle! It doesn't get better than that!
Recently I went there 4 times in one week! Walked down there one afternoon, realized I forgot my wallet, was super bummed. Went home angry and hungry but returned only a few hours later with wallet in hand. As I was loading up on salsa, I managed to knock over my coke and broke the glass bottle on the floor and made a huge scene. The staff was friendly and amused and gave me a new one for free. Then I had two different friends visiting from nyc the next two nights and I brought them both to el castillito for a true taste of sf! So delicious!
author: Emily L.

description:
Well I only order veggie at taquerias because I am not into low grade animal flesh. Thats right, I will only gnaw on high grade animal carcasses.

So when I direct them carefully how to construct the perfect veggie burrito, I get a decent burrito. If I turn my head for a second though, it'll get f'ed up with lettuce or crappy guacamole. If they eliminated those two things, however, they would be a contender.
The ingredients are average but at least they melt the cheese onto the tortilla.
They added red salsa to their repertoire about 2 years ago which is really nice. Yo can have the avacado tomatillo standard or this lovely red sauce with some sort of roasted ancho or maybe guajillo chili in the mix.

All around solid, decent food.
author: Derek O.

description:
I love good food.  I am a food whore.  This place rocks!  My favorite thing on their menu is their super nachos.  For $6.50, you get an amazing amount of food!  The nachos are more than enough to feed two people to stuffed.  

I also tried their super fish taco last night.  Never had that one there.  I was just thinking I was going to get a taco.  This bad boy was packed full of yummy goodies, plus it came with a side of beans and a side of rice.  All that for only $3.65 or some ridiculously cheap price.

All in all a great restaurant.  I agree with the other reviewers that you need to know what you want already when you put in your order and that it is nice to see your meal being prepared in a clean kitchen in your presence.  Big downfall for me: paper takeout containers.  Not that I'm not for the environment, but paper containers are not conducive for transporting wet, hot mexican food.  My nachos were double-containered last night and it still leaked through both containers.  Yuck!  I know, I'm a pig.  I did eat both the fish taco meal and the nachos.  My meat recommendation: half carnitas and half pastor.  Both are so friggin' good and if they give you both, you get to double dip.  Yay!
author: Aileen B.

description:
Writing a review for this place is betraying all those who wish to keep it as their own little secret.  I average one burrito a week -
- super chicken or chorizo with everything
- avocado instead of guacamole
- wrap it, then cook it like a quesadilla!
The people that work here are very friendly, especially considering the average you typically meet at every other taqueria.  Their new juicer squeezes a mean orange juice and burritos come with chips.  (tip -   heat your chips in a toaster or oven!)
author: Clay K.

description:
Ahura Mazda, you have answered my prayers for an all meat burrito.  ALL MEAT.  Well, not really all meat, it has some important things in it, and some things that should be passed.  I nixed the lettuce and the sour cream (and should have done so to the cheese), but the rest was beautiful meat, avocado, and salsa.  Eating it was close to heaven, or Valhalla.  Yummy tender carne, meat and salsa juices dripping down my hands, and some additional green salsa.  YUM!  Thank you Castillo, you did not disappoint.  I don't really care what else you serve, though I've had some good tacos from you too.

F! beans and rice, go all meat.
author: Adrian L.

description:
No homo, but I really like this burrito shop in the Castro!

For the first time ever, I had a veggie burrito and avacados and I love both! I usually eat carne asada but there's just something about their veggie burrito that calls to me. Never had their carne asada before so I can't comment.

I find myself coming here almost 2-3 times a week, so I can have an early dinner and hit the gym when I get home. Here's my usual - super veggie on whole wheat, no sour cream, hot salsa, avacado, extra jalapenos, verde sauce, and no chips.

A mystery is why their regular veggie has mushrooms, carrots, celery, etc and a super is just a burrito with no meat, no extra veggies.
author: Cavan W.

description: After living in Mexico for 3 years, I'm somewhat suspect of any taquerias, especially ones in the mission at midnight.  I was pleasantly surprised.  My chorizo and carne asada tacos were incredible, and the condiment bar was full of creamy guacamoles and salsas that would get anyones taste buds a jumpin'.  And man, thank god I can speaka the spanish, because we chatted up the cooks (whom are from Puebla and were seriously nice) and they treated us like royalty.  I might make another late night pit stop here again.
author: Ali L.

description: Maybe they had an off night but my veggie burrito was not the delicious tortilla of heaven I've seen described here on Yelp. We came in on a Tuesday night, post-church hill libations, pre-cafe du nord show. The menu looked awesome with like 5-6 veggie burrito options and all the staff were very friendly. We opted for the traditional super veg burrito with black beans. I asked for avocado instead of guacamole but never got either :/. The burrito was big and perfect for sharing but there was entirely too much rice and the burrito was super bland. Maybe the rice or beans were under salted or something. The bites with cheese were tasty but the burrito overall was not well mixed, my bf had all the sour cream and I had none. I bet that avocado would have helped. The salsa bar is awesome, excellent green salsa and spicy pickled carrots like those I've had in San Diego. I'll definitely come back and give some of the other burritos another try, hopefully they will be more flavorful or I'll get extra avocado.
author: Cori W.

description:
With so many burrito places in the area, it is hard to say which one is the best. While this one currently ranks in my book as the best, there are so many more to try...However, it is very easy for me to pick a favorite. That would be El Castillito on Church st. The el pastor is to die for, especially in the late evening when the spices have really set in... so good with fresh avocado and the fixins'. The chicken in alwasy just right and the beef is neither chewy nor pungent like some burrito places... 
Hands down I like this palce better than Cancun... I find it is fresher, tastier, and they let you pick the fillings and amounts. Cancun is always in a rush and I find them not as "made to order"... yet still good.
author: Mitchell W.

description:
I live 2 blocks away but proximity aside, this place makes excellent burritos.  Carne asada is my usual default for a first order at a new mexican place, and I've noticed it can vary considerably from place to place, more than other types of meat.  I find it a good indicator of any given establishment's burrito methodology.

These guys do it right so it's flavorfill and satisfying, but doesn't dominate the cumulative burrito experience.  Sliced into small pieces (so it plays well with the other ingredients) and it doesnt taste too cow-ey.  They also put MELTED cheese on the tortilla, which I thinks should be SOP at any self respecting mexican joint.

I also highly recommend the Al Pastor  (try it on a totra w/ refried beans, they spread it on the bread like mexican mayo - so money) and the salsa bar is solid as well.

Tacos were too overfilled to eat without looking like barbarian IMO.  I say stick to the burritos.
author: Joe B.

description:
It looks like El Castillito hasn't been reviewed for a while, so I'm giving it some love right now. Most taquerias neglect their nachos in favor of the flashier, more popular burritos. And as a result, even places with great burritos often have disappointing nachos. While I love El Castillito's veggie burritos -- especially the way they melt slices of cheese onto the tortilla on the grill -- the veggie nachos are reliably better than anywhere else in the city.

I think it's the huge portions (order 1 for two people). And all that smoothly melted cheese.
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
