I probably eat here 2 nights minimum out of every week. The Super Vegetarian Burrito is a great deal and tastes fantastic. Friendly service, high quality components in their food, fast, and cheap.

I recommend going to this Castillito, not the one on 18th. I walk the extra distance to this one because I've found that the El Castillito on 18th has a chemically taste in all of their food.

Also, if you're going at dinner time, expect a line.
author: Gene W.

description:
Fish burritos. Giant fish burritos. Actual sea food. All for less than 7 bucks.

Can't beat that anywhere, especially at a place this clean. And you get free chips!

No, seriously, get the fish burritos. They're good.
author: Andy A.

description:
OK, the burritos are good, but I agree with whoever bagged on the carnitas quality.  There is occasionally a rogue fat globule that ruins an otherwise top-notch Mexican food pouch.  But other than that, they are ginormous and tasty, they have unique quesadillas, and I think there is a secret thing you can order on the menu where they bring out a wet burrito about the size of a cat.

Now, let's talk about the juicer thing behind the counter that I think they got off the set of "The Price Is Right."  Does anyone ever use it?  I know they offer fresh-squeezed fruits, carrots, and *beets,* but I have never seen it in action.  And fresh-squeezed beet juice?  Beets?  Why not potatoes?  Ginger root?  Bok choy?  I can't figure it out.

Somebody find about these fresh-squeezed beets, because I am too conventional about my burritos to even consider it.
author: Jeff M.

description:
I like this place.

Thats all I have to write isn't it?

No? Okay. Here we go. I've been a few times, tried burritos and tacos. Each and everytime the food was satisfying. Sometimes even more so, and I've walked out with half a burrito or the extra taco. Damn those big eyes and that small stomach. Maybe the best thing about this place is the convenience of the whole affair though.
author: Matt L.

description:
Best damn burrito I've ever had.  Sober that is.  I'm pretty sure I've staggered into Can-Cun after a few too many Anchors in the Mission and fallen in love with a Can-Cun burrito and proclaimed, with superfluous volume, "This burrito is the best god-damned burrito I've ever had!" but I was mistaken.

The al pastor at Catillito takes the cake.  Spicy, juicy, good black beans, friendly staff, quick service, and a regular burrito is under $5.  Top that off with free chips and a top flight salsa bar and my proverbial cup doth runneth over.

Pretty good breakfast egg/chorizo burritos as well.
author: Jake S.

description:
This is by far my favorite taqueria yet. The food is killer, cheap and my favorite thing in the universe (well, one of them); the kick ass salsa bar. I don't really know what that green stuff is but I could swim in it! 

I usually get the rice and beans burrito but if your super starved I would recommend the veggie platter. So, I can't really help y'all out with the meat part but I have been here with carnivores and they seem to be purty happy.
And thank god, they make delicious guacamole! 
The staff is adorable. One of the grillers sings to me every time I go there. I want to think he does this just for me but I think that is being delusional. I happen to also be a big fan of the vinyl 50's style diner chairs they have. Kinda want to steal them.
All in all the best place for delicious, cheap eats!
author: Eryn L.

description:
There are tons of really good taquerias in San Francisco, but El Castillito has them all beat.  The super deliciousness of these burritos is the result of a perfect combination of fresh ingredients, cooks who really know their stuff, and the complete lack of post-burrito lethargy, that feeling of overwhelming fatigue that accompanies many taqueria dining experiences.

I always go for the carnitas super or wet burrito (red or green sauce) and I've never been lead astray. The bf always goes with the chicken super burrito which has got some really interesting savory and sweet spices in there (definitley a hint of cinnamon going on in there).  The salsa's are excellent and fresh.  There are a ton of other things on the menu and they all look really good, but when I get the craving for El Castillito I just have to go with my favorites.

The cook's are also always very accomodating with any special request that customers make (I pretty much stick to my regular, but I've seen other customers make all sorts of requests and they never get a sour look).
author: Greg R.

description:
FYI:  Review on the food only.

The BF picked me up a burrito from here last night and it was AWESOME.  Pulled chicken, rice, beans, salsa (nice and spicy) with fresh, and I mean FRESH avocados all wrapped in a spinach tortilla...it was yumdeliciofabulousness!  When I finally got home with it after about an hour or so...it was still hot as it was double wrapped in aluminum foil.

Aye ye ye!
author: Shane P.

description:
So if I were writing about burritos, this would be a different review.  Please, get the torta or quesadilla instead.  

I know that many of you from New Hampshire were told a story about the "Mission Burrito" (isn't this an item at The Friendly Toast?), and indeed there are many fine ones all over the Mission.  There are other things to eat at taquerias.  Please, at El Castillito, get the torta or quesedilla instead.

Many fine yelpers have said many true things about the quesedilla - no need to cover old ground.

Get the torta - especially Kelli Kate W - because they are also "UNBEFUCKINGLIVABLE".

A couple of things the team hasn't mentioned.
1) The burrito / quesedilla / torta fillings are finished on the grill for order.  I'm not opposed to the steam tables at other places, but the griddle treatment at El Castillito is awesome.
2) They don't just have avocado, it's a choice between that and guac.
3) For tortas, the bread is toasted on the griddle.
author: Stefan A.

description:
Everyone's in love with their burritos, but I don't think their amazing tacos should be overlooked either. 

My favorite things about El Castillito are: its tacos are delish, its 2 blocks from where I live, its basically open 247, and their lickidy split with your orders. Did I mention that its dirt cheap? I don't really know what else you could ask for from a taco joint...

I can't knock these guys for anything except for making fun of me when I try to order in Spanish =P Wait, I remember, their chips could be better, sometimes I get stale chips... -1 =(
author: Kyle W.

description:
The burrito eater site recommended this place, and I've been very happy with it foor a couple of years. Good and pleasant service, they're happy to get a tip and they express it, and this little place has a broad variety of Mexican foods. Burritos are served with the cheese melted while heating the tortilla, unique in my experience.
The quality seems to have gone downhill recently.  I ordered the usual burritos fer me 'n' the little lady. I ate half of mine as usual, but stumbled on _four_ pieces of gristle - a daddy, a mama, a baby and the grande dame. Kind of a turnoff. I hope the photo takes.
It's at a convenient location near my Safeway and multiple Muni lines, but I won't rate a restaurant on factors unrelated to the food, the value, the service, and the ambience.
I'll try it again, but I'm ready to check the burrito eater site again, even though this is the best experience with a taqueria I've found recommended there.
author: Sam S.

description: Best burritos ever! Seriously. I'm from LA. I only had a bite of my friend's barbacoa, but I was mad jealous!
author: Gina Q.

description:
Sadly I no longer live along the N-Judah, which makes coming here oh-so-easy.  The key is really that one orders directly from the cooks, and so you can see exactly what's going on with your meal.  Best part for me?  Seeing them pick out a whole avocado, and slice it up right into your burrito.  Can't possibly get any fresher than that.

On the whole, much more value than the overhyped Mission tacquerias, and super tasty.
author: Sujit R.

description:
best burritos north of market street!
They grill the tortillas (no steaming) and they grill the meaty ingredients so they get a nice crisp browned crust, and it allows the oily stuff (chorizo, pastor) to off load excess oils.  
My faves are carnitas or pastor with fresh avo.  Regular.  Burritos shouldn't contain sour cream or lettuce, thanks.  Or chicken.

There are a couple other Castillitas', but this is the best.
I just wish they had sesos and cabeza like those Mish spots.
author: Rob B.

description:
They could put their pastor in a blender with cilantro and onions and sell  it as a pastor shake--I'd drink it everyday.

The only other place that rivals their pastor is the taco truck outside the Best Buy on Harrison Street. Other than that, there is no other reason to go to a different taco/burrito place.

Always good.
author: Marc M.

description:
My favorite burrito in San Francisco.

I've read some of negative reviews of this taqueria on Yelp, and I'm perplexed by the complaints about the homeless folks who camp on the sidewalk, the dirty floor and tables, the garish lighting, the sketchy/annoying clientele . . . all true, but also irrelevant. Seriously, who goes to a taqueria for the ambience?! The food is good, and the prices are right. The salsa cruda is friggin' awe-inspiring. I like that the entire food-preparation area is visible to you when you order, so that you can ask the cook to customize your burrito by pointing to whatever looks good.

Cash only.
author: Steve K.

description:
Man I love this place! For about five years now, I've been coming here once a week, cause there isn't much that can top the burrito they make for me. 

After spending some time in Japan, I came to love Oyakodon, which is sauteed chicken, onions, mirin, soy sauce, and a fried egg, all over rice. ("Oya" means parents, "Ko" means children - get it? chicken and the egg). 

So I got the idea of having this place put fried eggs in the chicken burrito. At first they thought it was a little odd, but they did it - and wow, it was orgasmic! 

The exact burrito, should you care to eat like a God, was a regular chicken burrito, two fried eggs, little bit of black beans, no rice, mild salsa, cilantro, onions, and hot sauce, on a whole-wheat tortilla.

So what makes this place so different from others?

1. They grill their tortillas - who likes their tortillas moist and gummy?
2. Their chicken is marinated in this amazing amber-red spicy sauce and then cooked to order, so it never comes right out of a hot pot. My friends, this chicken comes out hot and crisp and tender. 
3. Their salsa, spicy or mild, is incredibly fresh and delicious. 
4. They have a humongous juicer to make fresh oj or veggie juices - a pleasing oddity for a taqueria. 

Go there and order this burrito - you'll love it!
author: Mike T.

description:
I've been going to this place for years. 

Why?

1. The Grilled Chicken

2. The Green Sauce

3. If i ask for extra chips they don't charge

4. The seats by the window. Good for people watching



my 2cents
author: joey w.

description: only had a quesadilla. put way too much cheese and overcooked it. casa mexicana (just a few stores down) way better. this place is too fast paced and loud. at casa mexicana you feel relaxed because they have a lot of space. wont be back here. you want better mexican food then go to casa mexicana
author: Mohammad A.

description:
This place is great. 

Most Mexican joints in SF are serviceable at worst, but this place I love. The people who run this place are awesome and friendly and playful and run their grill with the care of a chef and the speed of a line cook on meth. Very nice. Highly recommended.
author: Mr. R.

description:
I'm not a veggie.. and I have to say

This El Castillito is way Better than Cancun... so sue me.  I usually get a Carne Asada Burrito.. and they are top notch.. they have guacamole too.. which Cancun foolishly lacks..

one star off, for serving those crappy yellow dry chips...that most the other places serve.
author: Georgio S.

description:
I have been eating at this location for years.  
My favorite food on earth would probably have to be the burrito.
This place makes the best burrito i have ever had. 
The ingredients are always fresh and the people that work there are always laughing and having fun..plus they are really friendly.
I am also an avocado whore...i love that they put fresh avocado on their burritos instead of guacamole.  When you ask for extra avocado they put a whole extra half on top of everythign else.
Seriously, if this place ever closed, I would die...

The quesadillas are pretty good too...more like a sandwich wrapp than a regular round quesadilla...they are a little watery cuz but still super good!
author: Ripley B.

description: Awesome cheap no-nonsense burritos, great flautas too and open late.
author: Beth D.

description: Good. Shouldn't have ordered chicken. I've been back and ordered the super burrito, which was fantastic and enough to share.
author: Chas B.

description:
I enjoy the low prices of this place and the fast service, but you hafta watch them making your food, especially if youre veggie like me. More than once theyve thrown my tortilla right on top of the grill where there are meat crumbles....where they havent cleaned it off yet. They really need a separate section for heating veggie stuff.....
they wipe it off with an already greasy rag too...
but if your on a budget you cant beat two dollar and sixteen cent taco with all the salsa you want!
author: John G.

description:
The paltry number of reviews for this institute makes me believe that everyone I've seen here at 10 PM are stoners/blacked out drunks who immediately forget the food they devoured.

I love this place ... I can watch my food be made, drool over the absurd number of choices on the menu, enjoy a tasty glass of beet juice, or just watch the people walk by through their huge windows.  Cooks are quick and incredibly patient (watch them talk to a drunk who forgot what they just ordered).  Their chip salsas like most taquerias aren't that great, but they are always willing to dump extra jalapenos on my food and as long as you are not an ass about it are willing to take suggestions for burritos (more cilantro, no onions, fancy tomato tortilla).

This is my favorite Mexican place in the entire Bay Area ... a bold statement from someone who grew up in the Bay, but I stand by it.
author: Justin T.

description:
My favorite burritos, ever. 

Except recently they've replaced their BOMB-ASS pico de gallo with some NASTY ASS sludgy tomatoes. If I wanted that, I'd just dump pasta sauce in my meal. BRING BACK THE GOOD PICO! 

Oh, and the dudes that work there are sweet. I love to sit in the window and watch all of the freakish occurrences that seem to transpire in and around that Safeway parking lot.
author: sophia a.

description:
I would go hungry without this place. Seriously. I love the food and everyone is super nice. The guys working the grill are all friendly and know what I want before I order it. In fact, I've thrown them off a couple times by getting something different, since they already had ingredients in their hands. Same goes for the lady who works at the register. 

I think they may have raised prices recently by just a little bit, but it's still pretty cheap for good quality food. They don't have the gristly meat like some places. They use actual avocados instead of mystery mush. 

This place gets all five stars for selling the good Coke with real sugar in it.
author: Amy M.

description: These guys drew hearts and roses in red sharpie on the foil of my veggie burrito before presenting it to me. Most romantic dinner I have ever had. SWOON!
author: Anna R.

description:
This place has a great veggie burrito.  It's called the Veggie Special costs 4 bucks and is custom made to satisfy your hunger.

They have tons of other menu items, people are cool there and it's not a a bad place to people watch during the day time.
author: Dino K.

description: I live a few blocks away, and this is my favorite standby. They make an AWESOME vegetarian burrito - there are actually a few options, but I prefer the "veggie special," with sauteed mushrooms, carrots, and broccoli (sure, it's not traditional, but it sure is tasty.) The menu is short and sweet and reasonably-priced (a burrito the size of my head, plus chips, for less than $5.) Choose between a flour or a whole-wheat tortilla. The staff is friendly and the line moves quickly.
author: Kimberly N.

description: Excellent burritos and large portions. Nachos are so so.
author: Captain B.

description: My favorite burrito place in SF so far.  These things are like full, wet diapers...mmm....just how I like my burritos.
author: Allison Y.

description:
Two tacos - al pastor - it doesn't get better!

There aren't many places I've seen that do beet and celery juices - and at reasonable prices.
author: S H.

description:
whoah.  really amazing, authentic mexican.  the burritos and quesadillas are perfect.  great chips and a pretty extensive salsa bar.

i know it's a hole in the wall, but it was pretty dirty when we were there.  hence the missing star.
author: Alyssa W.

description: The burritos and quesadillas are as good as any you'll find in the Mission, and there's the added advantage of being able to park in the usually-empty and never-monitored Blockbuster lot long enough to enjoy a leisurely lunch. That in itself is worth an extra star.
author: Gourmet G.

description: El Castillito has the best veggie burrito around, and the nicest people work there.
author: malorie l.

description:
wheres that god damn taco truck?!?!?! ahahhaha

well el castillito makes the usuall fare, but i must admit, its pretty damn fucking tasty. i must go back one day when im not brown bagging a mickeys 40 and drinking with a bunch of rowdy yelpers. 

mucho propos for the cool staff that seemed to enjoy our rowdy drunk asses.
author: Euge L.

description:
Really excellent taqueria.  One of the best for the money!

$3.40 gets you an entire vegetarian taco with sour cream, guacamole & chips.  Add pico de gallo and salsa from the salsa bar and you have an entire plate of food.

Go early and often.
author: The P.

description: I had the wet burrito with steak (cheese, sauce, and avocado on top). It was great! Also, the people here were super nice. It was only 10:00 a.m. and breakfast was still being served, but they gave me my lunch item anyway. I would definitely go back.
author: Eli R.

description: Food poisoning. This place used to be good but has aged poorly and last time I ate their gave me honest to goodness food poisoning.
author: Jason B.

description:
I fear Spanish. Spanish the language, not the cuisine or people of that cultural heritage.  For years, I spelled 'Hola', as just 'Ola', until my supposed childhood best friend finally broke it down for me, "honey, I've let this go on for too long...there's a silent H in 'Hola'." 
So last Wednesday, I whined and cried until Luis M ordered my plate for me when it was my turn at the counter/window to their kitchen.
Completely intimidated by Spanish titles on their entire wall menu, I went with the limited plates w/a pictoral guide and english description: shrimp in garlic sauce.  
I looked around at other people ordering carne this, pollo that, and thought I made the wrong selection, when a tap on my shoulder made me turn around.  Ed M was behind me, and he pointed to the grill top, "Check out that stick of butter they just dumped on your shrimps".  YES!!! We high fived each other and I did a little hop-dance.
MMMMM - the butterflied shrimp were SOOO tasty, SOOO fried that I ate shells, meat and all. Didn't love their guac though, that is not the color that avocados should be.  
I guess someday I'll manage to order something else, maybe I'll listen to the patrons in front of me in line, and just say  "I'll have what they're having". In the meantime - I'll point at the picture of the shrimp in garlic sauce, instead.
author: CINDY K.

description: Pretty good burritos...I like the fact that they grill the tortillas, which is a rarity...makes everything else taste better, ya' know?  The tweekers milling about outside of the place remind me of fucked up pigeons though...I was tempted to throw out a few tortilla bits to see if they'd mistake them for crack.
author: Monique H.

description: Inconsistent, but generally a much more interesting concoction than Casa Mexicana. I think the quality has declined just a bit.
author: Maria D.

description:
i've been going to this place for the past 8-ish years... its delicious every time! i have never had a bad experience here ever. the guys are super nice, the ladies at the cashier are awesome and it always hits the spot!!

i've tried others ones around the area, a no go... i always come back and realize that i should never linger too far from my local taqueria. i love their green salsa and the spicy bbq pork tacos are my favorite. well anything with the spicy bbq pork!
author: sue k.

description: Rarely do I feel like my stomach is going to explode from eating too much. Went in with a SAVAGE hunger, so I ordered a veggie burrito. By the time I was done, I felt like I was going to keel over. It was the most delicious pain I have ever felt! Awesome!
author: Haz O.

description:
the zapata burrito was a heavyweight both to my delicate hands/fingers and to my stomach!!!...what a delightful mixed of guacamole, sour cream, cheese, tomato, hot salsa, lettuce, rice, beans and grilled chicken on their grilled flour tortilla...

i was really stuffed!!!

a very worthy taqueria to spend your spare change, for the prices of the dinner plates, burritos, tacos, quesadilla, salads & etc are absolutely cheap, with such flavorful ingredients.
author: Nelle A.

description: Ive been here a few times, and the last time i was here, i ordered a carne asada burrito. They made me a veggie one. I told them i wanted carne asada, and they said "No...you ordered veggie." Argument ensued, they got pissy and opened my burrito and stuffed meat in it and said "Fine. Carne asada. Next!" Gotta admit, still tasted good, but they definitely need an attitude adjustment.
author: Mick F.

description:
Got a veggie quesadilla and super veggie burrito last night.  I expected the quesadilla to be cheesy but I'm pretty sure it was identical to the burrito - that is, not particularly cheesy - except maybe that the quesadilla is 5% smaller and 10% cheaper and slightly differently wrapped.  

I don't really see what all the fuss is about.  Definitely NOT better than El Farolito as the top review would have you believe.  Not bad but no compelling reason to come here instead of anywhere else, except its proximity to my apartment.
author: Danny T.

description:
get the quesadilla el castillito. all this talk about burritos and this item really makes burritos seem like styrofoam peanuts in a paper bag. all flavor -- no filler.

it is absolutely the PERFECT hand held food item. 

i recommend carne asada.
author: merkley m.

description: Instead of the traditional Sunday morning SF brunch at the overrated and crowded neiborhood cafe, I opt for some huevos rancheros or huevos a la mexicana at El Castillito.  They're quick, friendly, affordable, and oh-so tasty.  Fresh salsa galore and a juke box loaded with only the best mexican/spanish jams.  I LOOOOVE me some mexican food and this place is probably my favorite taqueria in SF.
author: seema s.

description: The burritos are pretty cheap, but so are the burritos at every taqueria in the vicinity. This may be more convenient than the mission if you live north of market street, but it's worth walking a bit to get a real burrito (plus, you probably need to burn some calories if you plan to eat the whole thing). Mine fell apart when I tried to eat it, and was soggy. Sure the burritos are big, but that's just because they put a lot of rice in them. Heck, the $7 burrito I got at love parade was better than this shiz.
author: Dana L.

description: Talk about some MASSIVE burritos....the guys here know what is up fo sure!  And it is walking distance from  my house, which is always plus.  I have also tried the vegetarian quesadilla and must say that I was highly impressed with that as well.  The veggie taco's could make a full meal with the bag of chips that come with it if you are running on a budget (it's only $2.69).  I have only gotten take out, but always end up very content!
author: ELIZABETH W.

description: Got the Carnitas taco. Simple and Delicious. Carnitas, onion, cilantro, hot sauce, done. The meat was nice and tender and even a little crispy on the edges. You gotta love the small taqueria's that manage to churn out good and reasonably priced food ($2.50 for a taco). I'm definitely coming back for a burrito...
author: Nicolas H.

description: This place makes me sick to my stomach (literally like 2-3 times). The chicken is in this sauce that is so nasty (ask for it grilled)! AND they put rice in the quesadilla?! That confuses me too much...it's not like a taco or a burrito, it's a stupid quesadilla people! Anyway, I guess a veggie burrito is the safest bet here since the meats are sketchy and you can see them slicing it up in the back (EW!) I know a lot of people like this place but it's a very gringo taqueria and not that good at all. Sorry.
author: Gina R.

description: Stopped in today for lunch after going to the gym.  All I can say is that the Taco Truck in NYC has some serious competition when it comes taste, price and seating.  The food was out of this world and the service was quick and clean!  Taco Truck NYC - I'm nervous you have West Coast competition.  Looks like I'll have to do a taste test when I get back to the East Coast in the next few weeks.  Definitely worth trying both and getting your opinion heard!
author: Anjali K.

description: 3 hours ago I read the reviews on yelp, 2.5 hours ago I ate the burrito, 2 hours ago I went for a walk to help digest and now I am writing about it and still VERY full.... I shouldn't have eaten the whole burrito because it was big but it was good.  I'm glad they had the whole wheat tortilla/black beans combo which makes me feel better.  I had the chorizo based on the recommendations but I don't think it's for me, it's too heavy and overpowering....I think I'm more of a chicken asado person.  I think I found my new local burrito place!
author: Debbie Y.

description: I like the idea of having a taqueria down the street from me when I don't feel like heading out to the Mission, but unfortunately, El Castillito has dropped off in a number of ways.  They raised their prices a number of months ago, and I cannot justify spending 7 bucks on a mediocre super burrito.  I'm a HUGE fan of carnitas, and the carnitas is nothing to write home about, it just fills the void.  Every time I've ordered the steak, I end up wondering why I did so.  It's consistently bland and dry.  On the plus, their torta is a somewhat better alternative to the burrito.  The chips leave something to be desired.  Sure, it'll work in a pinch, but typically, I try to steer clear.
author: DamnGringo X.

description:
best taqueria in the city. 
i  love this place i eat here three times a week and the guys are super nice. great veggie burritos and tacos.
author: Morgan G.

description: Damn you to hell El Castillito. I want to sue you for contributing to my fat ass and rotund belly. I would also like to sue you for putting rice on my torta.
author: Jeremy C.

description: Burritos with a rather unique taste. I think it's in the salsa, but they are a little spicier and the cilantro really makes a show of it. Unfortunately I'm too lazy to hoof it up to Church street from my apartment get these bad boys more often.
author: Michael E.

description: shots of jamesons and salsa verde on a quesadillia suiza does not go together late night, but it's not their fault.  hence the 5 stars!
author: Pickle R.

description: Went back again with my new roommate and boy do I love the look on my friend's faces when they get their first bite. She agreed that they beat El Farolito hands down with both quality and price--and that's coming from an authentic Hispanic who makes her own Mexican delights at home.
author: Angela R.

description:
I've been going to  El Castillito for over 5 years, why ? mainly for the price and the quality seemed good, it was a bargain, but now that the burritos went from $4.49 to $5.89  in one single shot ! back in Jan. I'm sad to say I will no longer be a customer of theirs. No other burrito /taco place has raised their prices like this , it's frankly OUTRAGEOUS ! 
There are better quality places with more reasonable prices.
author: Gia L.

description:
Lily never likes to leave her house, ever. She's lucky her hair is so curly or I wouldn't put up with all her crazy guff. So, it was one of those nights when we she lured us over, or bullied us over, for drinks.  Now this was back when she lived on Shrader or Steiner, or something with an S that required the N. While waiting for the N hunger struck us, and struck us hard. But what could we do? Who could we turn to? You can't really get a burger to go. Safeway seemed too risky. We decided to take a chance on El Castillito, and discovered the tastiest al pastor this side of the Mississippi.
Seriously, the al pastor is heaven. It's dripping with mouth watering goodness. God, that meat is great. I've tried the al pastor quesadilla and the al pastor wet burrito, both are HUGE. El Castillito never disappoints. The salsa is hot. The chips are good. The men in the back make weird meowing sounds sometimes, and that's funny. I really hope it's code for something crazy.
Now, I can't tell you about their chicken, because I don't believe in chicken. And I wouldn't be able to tell you about their vegetarian stuff because that's not my thing. But I would stake my life on that al pastor.
author: Daniella C.

description:
my mouth gets all watery just thinking about it...

i say pass on the lettuce, get the black beans, split a super with a buddy and definitely try a little of the spicy salsa even if you're a wimp. es muy delicioso.  i really like the chips. -1 because i like a thicker guac and theirs is a little on the runny side. like avacado sauce. but nothing bad can really be said here.  they're fast, it's yummy (i usually get chicken), they're ten steps ahead of you (i'm guessing they get a lot of stoners i.e. other yelpers), they have chorizo, the regular size is a great cheap lunch, it's conveniently located next to other convenient things.... i may build a little shrine if i have time.
author: Nicole M.

description: I have a hard time saying if El Castilito or Cancun makes better burritos. I usually go here because it is closer to home but a lot of the time makes better burritos. NIce warmed tortillas and ask for avocado instead of guac. Also, you get to chose exactly what they put on your food like type of beans, lettuce, etc. (not always the case at Cancun)
author: Alyssa C.

description:
opening act: El Castillito featuring Coronas and the Veggie Burrito
main show: Cafe du Nord with Scrimshaw Pilsner 
encore: The Transfer and $2 Hamm's

Greatest lineup I've had in a while. Hooray for me!
author: Ferol G.

description:
i want to be a vegetarian, or at least a pescatarian.  one of my all-time-favorite meals is extremely spicy thai papaya salad, i actually enjoy tofu and spending two months veggie in southern india was a pleasure but then.....

oh el castillito, look what you do to me?!  i'm no bastion of moral fortitude but its certainly not food that leads me astray or at least not until......

quesadilla el castillito with chicken and fresh avocado - try one and i promise you, its over.  i'm sorry my poor feathered friends:(
author: Amy M.

description:
I would consider myself burrito literate, a self-proclaimed status I've worked hard to achieve in my six odd months here in the Bay Area via Cincinnati (a city known for it's chili and Indian rather then it's Mexican). Making Mexican a staple in my diet was an easy task as this seemingly unique Nor-Cal cuisine transforms the tired bean and cheese into a rich concoction of Southwestern flavors leaving the usual search for "authentic" behind for the "reinvented". When it comes to San Francisco this search is brought to a new level as my rough estimates put the number of Mexican establishments at 500. Adventure also makes it's presence into this search, as anyone who has tracked the Holy Burrito knows some of these places can be seedy (like Indiana Jones putting his hand in that hole with all bugs seedy) but don't let appearances deceive you as even these visual temples of doom can yield tortilla wrapped gold. Now, this city wide search has brought me, time and time again, back to El Castillito. Let me run down my reasoning.

- Terribly good service. Efficient, clean, and friendly. They even indulge my poor Spanish skills when I build up the courage to try. 

- Good atmosphere. Plenty of sunshine beeming through the glass storefront won't drive you to get your burrito to go. 

- Lastly the quality of the burrito is awfully high. A melding of the authentic (of which I base on the occasional odd vegatable, such as a carrot or radish, emerging from the burrito innards) and the reinvented (perfect amounts of guac and sour cream, choice of beans, and the occasional colored tortilla). 

Based on these highlights Castillito has become my neighborhood Mexican haunt (Lower Height!!!) and will continue to be a mainstay as long as I remain in the area. I say this, along with only offer four instead of five stars, because I leave the King of Kings (it's Easter!) accolades to the one and only Farolito!
author: Jennifer Z.

description: LOVE this place! The employees are friendly (but don't take any shit so don't go to the front unless you're ready to order, but that should just be a given, right?), you order exactly what you want, multiple tortilla options, great prices, delicious horchata and fresh juices, super salsa bar (the dark reddish brown is the best - smoky and spicy!). The veggie quesadilla is a great alternative to the usual burrito and try the veggie special - good price for more vegetables. Bring cash.
author: Brittany L.

description: I love this place.  The guys making the stuff are always super nice and entertain my bad Spanish speaking skills.  The best part of this place though is that you can actually substitute fresh avocado for guacamole.  It makes a huge difference in taste (assuming you like avocado).  The salsas are really tasty here and it's always very fast.  I usually get the fish burrito these days, but I've gotten the quesadillas and tacos before and they're all good.  The quesadilla is wrapped up like a burrito though for reasons that I don't really understand.  Maybe it's easier to wrap up?
author: Joann C.

description: Other than that one time my former lover got food poisoning here this place is great.  Real whole slices of avocado on their burritos or quesadilla's.  Speaking of quesadilla these are the best I've had in the city.  Generally speaking I'm not one for half a pound of melted cheese betwixt a tortilla, but with all their fixings it's a delight to consume.  Even if you end up hurling it all back up a few hours later. (All prices are in the $4-5 range).
author: Ian H.

description:
I LOOOOOVE the nachos here.  Okay, I love nachos anywhere, but here it just seems like the eat-in nachos are served on this huge oval plate and that they are superior to all other taqueria nachos in SF.  
Also, the carne asada Super Burrito I had yesterday was so good that I purposely got it to go so that my boyfriend, who was with me but claimed he was not hungry (unheard of!!) and would not like a burrito (double unheard of!!)  would not ask for a bite of mine as I was eating it, "bite" meaning literally eating half the dang thing.  So instead, when asked if I would like my yumsters to go, I politely said yes, paid the nice people, and starved for about two hours after returning home while I waited for the bf to leave for work.  As soon as I saw him drive away (you can't be too careful), that burrito was out of the fridge and in my stomach.  And it tasted every bit as good as if had just been assembled and handed to me.

The thing I really like about El Castillito is that they cook the meat when you order, so it's piping hot and not stale and yucky when you receive your menu item.  One star off, though, because this time when I ordered my Super Burrito, the guy that was making it asked me, one by one as he was adding the ingredients, if I wanted each one -- EXCEPT FOR ONIONS!! The one ingredient he didn't ask if I wanted on my burrito was the sole thing I cannot stand.  But you know what?  I forgive him.  Because the burrito was that darn good.
author: Christy J.

description: YUM-O!  This place is worth all the raves.  Fresh & clean are the main points of attraction here people.  Carne Asada has no fat.  You know what I'm talking about.............have you ever bitten into a burrito and while your processing that half masticated cow in your mouth, you realize that the bite you just took is a little chewy?  It's the nasty fat that the food preparer didn't remove.  Hence, this place does not have that problem.
author: Victoria S.

description:
This place provides welcome respite from the waste land of the Castro Mexican food. Here we have lard in the beans, the carnitas well-fried and the good sense to grill the tortilla instead of the steaming it like so many impostors. The staff is so friendly and the decor is a welcome minimalism from the explosion of rainbow kitsch found at its only real rival, Taqueria Cancun. 

I recommend the carnitas torta, an excellent deal for under five dollars. The warm carnitas grease soaking into the bread is a luxury no man should be ashamed to enjoy. The vege quesadilla  is another winner, over two inches thick and well-stuffed with fixins. I would suggest asking to hold the salsa and applying some yourself, as the extra liquid tends to make the finished product a bit mushy on the bottom.
author: Veljko S.

description:
El Castillito-
I tried the salsas at the salsa bar. The Green salsa is Money.....  The green salsa had just the right color, consistency (not running not too thick, not too jelled), taste, the right blend of tomatillos, avocado, jalapenos, onion, garlic, salt, everything. Taste just like my Mom made with garden fresh tomatillos, cilantro and lots of Jalapenos. My wife commented the salsa had the aroma of her Dad's jardin (summer garden), and my father in law (abuelito to the kids) has been growing all the essentials for great fresh salsa since my wife was a baby. Any food that can evoke a memory like that is worth talking about; I hope you get the same outcome we did. We gave the salsa 6 out of 5. This is a first! Better than a 5 out of 5. I just wish I would have ordered a carne asada taco to smother my green salsa in. My advice is take lots of containers of this home with you. The other salsas at the bar were worthy as well, but I just couldn't get past the green to write about them. I had a chicken taco and my wife had a carne asada taco. The chicken tacos only garnered 2 out of 5, and the chicken a2 out of 5. I think we need to go back for another round. I didn't have the fresh squeezed juices, but I'm planning on this the next time. Maybe they can make a juice out of the green salsa for me.
author: Miguel V.

description: Small neighborhood gem. Al pastor tacos were superb, and a great value for the amount of meat laden on the tacos! Pastor burrito, super charged with avocado and spicy sauce were delicious.  Free chips and a traditional salsa bar with great homemade varieties.  Cooks and staff were friendly, efficient and quick. Plenty of seating.  Convenient, just steps away from Muni. Definitely worth a try!  Definitely a top favorite for this neighborhood!
author: Nicolle S.

description: Came here last night for the first time after spending some time at Lucky 13 and was glad I did.  The service was quick and friendly, my torta al pastor was tasty (and cheap!), and the salsa verde was great.  I'll be coming back again soon.
author: Joshua W.

description: These guys get 5 stars because, first, they make a regular vegetarian burrito exactly the way I love it, and 2) their salsas are Tasty! For the burrito, the cheese  isn't too cheesy, the beans actually have flavor without being "meaty", the rice is perfect in that perfect-rice-on-a-burrito way, and they know how to wrap it. The salsas clinch it for me, as they don't have that smoky chipotle thing overtaking their dark salsa, and their green salsa is spicy and flavorful like salsa would be in Heaven.  I would be lost without my El Castillito.
author: Noelle O.

description: On the basis of the Al Pastor super burrito, of which I've now had more than enough for an acurate measurement of quality and consistency, and a larger wasteline caused by said burritos, which are like a masterpiece of tangy al pastor action, I give them a five. Seriously, an alpastorgasm every time.
author: MeatMaster X.

description: The chicken here is to die for.  I don't know what they do to it, but get it in anything, and you'll be happy.  I would give them 5 stars, but they don't make their own chips- they use the nastiest store bought chips I've ever eaten.
author: C. W.

description: After I turned my back on Cancun due to non vege rice I rediscovered this place.  The vege burritos here are so good it makes me want to cry.  The staff is friendly, you usually get your food pretty quick even if there's a line and the bar seating at the window makes for some quality people watching.  If you like burritos and don't eat here you are wasting your life.
author: Britton R.

description: Why doesn't every tacqueria grill their tortillas?  The horchata could be better, but the other frescas are great. Heck, sometimes they even have Fresca and/or Squirt!
author: L W.

description: Very tasty burritos, we shared a Super Burrito minus the sour cream.  For about $7 you get a huge fat burrito.  It's really tasty but also oily..I think the chicken chunks were literally sitting in a vat of flavored oil until they scooped it on top of the tortilla.  It doesn't sit too well in your stomach (especially when you're hung over) but hey its tasty! I'd like to try their other items next time.
author: Emiko M.

description: Good, hot pozole (soup) with healthy accoutrements like celantro. There's a place to stretch out and watch soccer games on a flat-panel in the back.  And what looked like a garden in the back. My companion thought the order taking could have been more accurate. They were very friendly and their Spanish was OK. I say this because many times people are equally challenged in their native tongues as they are in English, and this can translatie to double-trouble for customers.  Highly convenient access as it's at a major transportation crossroads. I'll be back.
author: Robert F.

description: I'm very yummy and have a pleasant friendly staff.  I even have a salsa bar with fresh salsa.  Yes it's true, and occasionally I have fun dinner specials like a fresh chile relleno that are excellent to pick up on your way home from work.  Sometimes there can be belligerent homeless people here trying to use my bathroom and eat out of the salsa bar, but my friendly staff will remove them promptly.  Please come by and enjoy a tasty burrito.
author: Claire C.

description: Most memorable part was the super happy staff, fresh ingredients, and super huge burritos.  Flavor-wise they were pretty good but not crazy amazing.
author: Melanie C.

description: Definitely the best tacqueria in the Castro. And maybe the best carnitas in the city. Make sure you go to Church not 18th Street.
author: patrick g.

description: Had a regular carne asada burrito with black beans and it was ok. Jaw ran into two pieces of grissle which were ejected. Salsa bar is very good and fresh. All there salsas were tasty. The al pastor meat looked  really good on the roteserie spit. May try them out next time. I would go back only to knock two birds with one stone. Safeway is next door with ample parking so if I find myself in need of a Safeway run and hungry I would consider. But if craving only a burrito I will make the trek to el Farolito on 24th.
author: Carlos N.

description: Eh...went here twice and it was just ok...had chicken enchiladas and chicken burritto on both visits.  It was a very busy restaurant and the staff was very nice.  The food however was very, very greasy and I didn't feel that great afterwards.  I do like how they grilled the tortillas.
author: Denny R.

description: This is a semi legit establishment (not sure about the workers) that make great food.  I only tried the tacos so I cant comment on anything else, but they tasted great.  I think it's more one of those dirty places you go to eat, if your hungry after work and get off at that muni stop.
author: christopher h.

description: Best burrito North of Market St.  Period.  Their Carnitas are awesome and their salsa verde has some serious kick.  The super burrito is easily two meals, and for only $7.04, that's some serious bang for your buck.
author: Josh L.

description: The burrito guy likes this place, and I have to say I agree. I always get the full size super burrito. One thing to add, is that they ask if I want fresh avocado. Everywhere else I have to ask them. I go out of my way to stop here and pick up a burrito. It's my current fave.
author: Anna B.

description: Sliced cheese on a burrito! WTF? The rest of it was overpowered by ice-cold, onion-dominated salsa that made the entire burrito tepid. Casa Mexicana, although not my favorite taqueria, is much better.
author: Wendy C.

description: Definitely the only authentic taqueria in that immediate area. It's my favorite burrito in SF - ask for real avocado not guac. I used to get the Quesadilla Castillito which is basically a nicely grilled burrito but with no rice. It's solid. Their tomatillo salsa is the best around and this place is super cheap.
author: Bill R.

description: The flirty (lecherous?) men behind the counter, I understand. But carrots in the rice? SLICED deli cheese? These ingredients do not compute, and therefore, I choose Casa Mexicana down the block, every time!
author: Stumbalina b.

description: The best burrito place ever.  Hands down.  Maybe someday I will update this review with actual details, but for now take my word and go there.  Soooooooo  Good!!!!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Castillito has some of the best burritos in the City! I've lived in the Mission for over 5 years where there is plenty of great Mexican places but when I want absolute fulfillment, the Carnitas Regular Burrito is where I go.
First, they GRILL the tortilla (rather than steam) so that it is not soggy. Second they grill up the carnitas with a little oil until they are golden brown. The little bits of crunchy meat are absolute perfection! I have seen other reviews that complain about occasional chunks of pork fat in the mix. Yup, that happens occasionally. This is Mexican food, not the Boulevard. Finally, they throw in chips at no charge and the salsa bar is the tops! If you like it mild, go for the diced tomato and onion, every other selection is spicy!!
At this point I've had at least 20 burritos here as well as a smattering of the other dishes. I've never been unhappy. Fair warning: don't expect to have your hand held when it comes time to order. Know what you want before you walk up and bark it out clearly! They get a bit pissy with folks that dilly dally. 
PS: I've also been to the Mission location and been happy there as well.
author: Alan L.

description: Fuck yeah!!! Only get burritos here though. Great for veggie people as well in my opinion. Ask the person making it for some tomatillo sauce in your log for a little kick.
author: Boxxxman J.

description: Darn good burritos. Juicer than most. Definitely in my top 5.
author: Scott F.

description: Burritos are huge, tasty, and they have a juice bar. Pretty awesome. Although, it'll never beat my local Mexican food in San Diego, it was still nice.
author: David H.

description:
What can I say about this fine establishment?  Well, I can say that you wont find a better burrito west of the Mississippi.  I can say that if this burrito could talk, it would run for President...And win...In a landslide... And end The War!  This burrito is so good it can cure Hotchkiss disease (the good kind of Hotchkiss).  I usually get the steak burrito here, but yesterday I rolled the dice, per Elenor's suggestion, and went with a chicken super burrito with spicy salsa on a spinach tortilla.  It was better than good.  It was better than great!  It was like all my wants and needs in life were consolidated into one thing: This holy grail of burritos!  My one concern is that we don't have more Castillitos in the world.  I would argue that if the West Bank, Baghdad, or the Kashmir region of India/Pakistan had Castillitos, they would be a much safer and happier place.  BTW, don't go to the Lions Pub in Pac Heights!  I know it has nothing to do with burritos or Castillito but that place is RACIST!   Please refer to my review of it a couple of months ago.  You can find it on my profile.

Cheers!
author: Trevor J.

description: The only thing worth eating here is the vegetarian quesadilla. Seriously. It is absolutely amazing. My partner in crime and I have been on a veggie quesadilla binge ever since we discovered this place.
author: Juliana S.

description: So, I was thinking this location would be as good as the Mission St. joint.  Was wanting breakfast around breakfast time, but this location doesn't open 'til 10.  Had a coupon from the Safeway across the street for $1 off breakfast order.  Walked into an empty restaurant around 10:30.  Proceeded to counter-register to place my order.  The cooks, cashier & manager were all looking and ignoring me before the cashier lady finally told me to just order with the cooks.  Bespectacled cashier lady then proceeds to passionately argue with me for what seemed about 5 minutes over the coupon, claiming that it wasn't valid for my breakfast order of huevos rancheros.   Owner-manager finally assured her that the coupon was valid for the order.  Damn, is the dollar coming out of your own pocket lady?  I took the order to go and set it aside for awhile.  When I got to it, it was a congealed mess of a plate, but still edible I guessed.  I've had much better huevos before.  I didn't care for their refried beans, which were off-color, watery and generally milky in taste & texture.  Reasoning that serving breakfast isn't their specialty.  Since learned that this location isn't owned or operated by the same folks that run the Mission St. joints.  Probably won't ever go back here due to the stingy coupon incident and the blah food.
author: Darrin K.

description: I LOVE their burrito, its like crack only less addictive, i get in my car on a rainy night, day, snowstorm etc, to go to this place and eat. I get the super  burrito, and YES it is super, with pastor and all the extras...fucking best burrito ever. Trust me I'm norwegian. actually had one today, still feels like I ate a small baby, thats how big they are. super good and super size, yum.
author: Christian B.

description:
was here today for the first time
great burritos and quick service!!
got the regular with carne asada. couldnt finish it but it tasted great heated up 4 hours later
wish the tables and chairs were a little cleaner though...
author: Deka M.

description:
i went to el castillito for the first time last nite. i got the taco salad with chicken. it was fantastico. i was blown away.

i am giving it four stars for now, until i can go back and try some of their signature dishes. but i am definitely going back. and soon.
author: Maveric V.

description: Can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet. This was my favorite dirty taqueria in all of SF! When I was veggie and working across the street at the now-closed Gap; when I was getting one "para to go" on the way home from the gym and finishing the chips on the way up Fillmore; picking up twin chickens with refired beans and spicy salsa to share at Greg's; getting them "para for here" and Coronas with Max, never ever got a bad one. Open 'til midnight, too. You owe it to yourself to try this place.
author: Billy A.

description: "No queso without beso!" Cheap burritos, always good, and the only vegetarian burrito I know of in town that actually includes VEGETABLES (instead of your standard rice/beans combo).
author: Anika K.

description:
My friend Mat and his friend Kyle (both vegetarians) took me to this oft-overlooked (well, by me I guess) underground (literally) taqueria at the transfer (that's what I call the corner, not referring to the bar).  
Enough parentheses.  I was convinced to eschew the dead animal selections for a veggie burrito.  Not "veggie" as in beans and rice with some sauce, "veggie" as in broccoli, peppers, mushrooms and all the fixin's.  While a little watery, which is expected with such real vegetable contents, the burrito stood up to my gastronomical demolition until the very end, thanks in part to its sturdy foil wrap-job.  And darn was it tasty.  They add some red sauce to the vegetables to lend flavor, which mixes well with the beans and rice.  Like its cousins, this Little Castle (probably not what the name means) serves fresh-ish premade tortilla chips and three or four very fresh very spicy salsas.  The service is fast and efficient, and watching your burrito made from close up feels like some sort of 5th grade fieldtrip.  Bravo!
author: Eric S.

description: Hands down the best taqueria in The City ... maybe even the world!
author: Brandon H.

description: My favorite burrito in San Francisco!  There, I said it.  Right there, across the street from the Castro Safeway, is the best chicken burrito you will find in SF.  Seasoned meat, great balance of ingredients, lots of choices (even an option of avocado or guacamole), and decent prices.  Free chips, and great salsas, especially the green one! Last time we went, the salsa bar also had roasted whole jalapenos, which were a divine treat when chopped up into a (massive) taco.  A friendly and efficient team makes your food, wraps it up, and sometimes draws you a little picture on the foil (if you take it to go).  Oh, and they are very patient with you if you happen to be using this opportunity to practice your Spanish.  Yo quiero El Castillito.
author: Julie L.

description: The best pastor in San Francisco, period, end of story, no room for discussion.  I will hunt down and kill anybody that says otherwise.
author: Justin R.

description: The only place in my immediate neighborhood where I can have a moderately healthy, satisfying vegetarian meal (veggie taco) for $2.16 AND not feel like the victim of a truck-stop egg-salad sandwich when all is said and done.  Their salsa is amazing, too.
author: Patricia D.

description:
A lot of people talk about the best taquerias, or best burritos, but don't justify the claims with anything concrete. I'll try and do that/ w El Castillito.Their burritos are the best in the city because:

1) They grill the tortilla itself. They don't use the press/steam machine; it's always warmed up on the grill, which adds flavor and texture to the burrito.
2) They throw the meat, or veggies -- whatever the content of your burrito goodness -- straight onto the grill, too. So that you get a hot, hot burrito. So unlike the vast majority of other taquerias, none of your burrito filling is sitting in a vat, being "warmed" by the water beneath it, and then dumped into a steamed tortilla.
author: Aki T.

description: I come in here when I have a hankering for some nachos on the way to my boyfriend's house.  The chips are ok, but the toppings are impressive.  Salty with beans, and cheese. Just the way I like it.
author: Joanna S.

description: Oh, El Castillito.  My most favorite burrito joint in the world.  Back in LA, I'm still dreaming of your super burrito.  It contains an generous amount of all that is good and right in the world--plus jalapeños.
author: Jan D.

description: Best burrito on the block!  Obviously, I enjoy the "all meat" option.
author: Marcus C.

description:
i will eat your burritos, and yes i want the marijuana you clever little cilantro weilding man.

i will eat your tacos, and yes i want them SUPER, do i look like i'm on a diet? no i didn't ask if i look like i should be, that is altogether a different subj- oh what kind of beans? clearly whatever is re-fried. mm fried.

i will eat your nachos, and yes i want jalapenos up in there even though i am a gringita who knows how to speak spanish but will not fall prey to your charms to get me to do so although it might mean you give me more maryjane, i mean cilantro. i mean maryjane. i just traded my old chips for a dimebag with a homeless dude outside. or did i? oh FUCK, am i already in food coma from discussing this precious food? somebody get me some pico de gallo before i really lose it.
author: shaine h.

description: i dont normally write this but OMG!!! tacos al pastor on the same machines they use in mexico!?! i have been searching for a place like this since i moved to sf a year and a half a go always go with at least one taco al pastor just to try it just to see how it feels it wont dissapoint!!!
author: hank g.

description: I've been hanging out at Church/Market for nearly 15 years and ate here for the first time just in the last couple of weeks.  It's cheap, fresh, friendly, and delicious.  'nuff said.
author: Mariana P.

description:
damn, this is the best carne asada quesadilla ever.  it's greasy, but not in a gross way.  the tortillas are never soggy, and it holds its shape when you eat it.  this got me through several wedding seasons at photoworks, so if you need a big protein kick...eat this.

the tortas are also amazing.
author: Patricia M.

description: Whoever doesn't like Castillito is a FOOL. Better than Cancun.. sorry you poor saps. It's one of the best veggie burritos you'll ever have and that's THAT!
author: Kat S.

description:
THIS PLACE IS BOMB AS MIMI-CHING CHING!! No joke the best mexican in the Castro. Their burritos are awesome... ah man I want one now! I always get the super with carnitas, oh the porkliciousness of it! 

The staff is quick, you're in and out in no time and can enjoy that big thick burrito you've waited your whole life for.
author: Jesse V.

description: My favorite Duboce/Castro burrito joint.  The Super Veggie Burrito is my favorite.  I hear the BBQ pork burrito is also very tasty.
author: Tessa M.

description: This place is definitely enough to satiate your craving for some Latin love, but the real lovers are in the Mission. The main reason I go to El Castillito is for its location and decent Mexican food in the Castro. The meat is consistantly juicy and there are different options to what sort of tortillas you can choose from. Good taqueria for the lack of choices in the area.
author: I Love Beef C.

description:
i can't seem to pass this place without stepping in for one of their carnitas tortas or tacos...

great mexican, great prices, great people!
author: Jill k.

description: When your poor and hungry or cheap and hungry or just plain damn hungry, this is a great spot to eat. I like to park in the Safeway across the street, walk in, walk out, sneak across the street and then buy a fat veggie quesadilla or burrito with all the fixins in a spinach tortilla. I lived on these for months at a time when I was living on the cheap in the mission. It's about 3 bucks and they give you chips and if you smile they give you lot's of chips and then you can take a water cup and fill it up with they're spicy avocado salsa(which is muy delicioso). It's great watching all the same people who eat there every night. Just nod and acknowledg that y'all know the down low.
author: Phil M.

description: Like so many, I was on a quest to find the best burrito I could find in San Francisco. Definitely go to the Church location and not the one on 18th Street--the meat on Church is (re)grilled to order, and the burritos overall taste better. The quesadillas--which can get monstrous as well--are also excellent. Love the whole wheat burrito--a nice and (who knows, deceptively?) healthier alternative to the flour variety. And sorry to the vegetarians out there, but this place is all about the meat. How can you resist a mountain of raw beef staring at you from behind the glass?
author: Aaron L.

description: Fuck, I can't remember what I had last time I ate there, but it was tasty as hell. Same with the time before that. Sorry I'm not more helpful. I dunno, try the tacos.
author: Brandon B.

description: Absolutely the tastiest burrito in town with many other terrific options available on the menu, including great enchiladas and quesadillas. Perfect for that night when you're tied, just off the MUNI at Church Street station, and in no mood to cook. You pop in, the usually long line moves quickly, and the counter staff make you feel very welcome. I love it... in, out, home, eat, full, and satisfied. My favorite here is any dish with carne asada.
author: Marc S.

description: Service is a great. Fast and friendly. Burritos are outstanding. Fresh ingredients and great flavors. Difficult to get a seat though, with all the poser hipsters, but if you can get it to go, you've got it made!
author: El Gato D.

description: Best super burrito evah!  I have been coming here since '96 when I was lucky enough to have El Castillito right around the corner.  The staff are nice, funny and fast...and the food delish!
author: Stevie N.

description:
When I first moved to the City for a no name town up North I came in search of one thing. The perfect burrito within walking distance from my little hovel in the Projects in the Lower Haight.  El Castillito fit that description to a T.  
   The Place is just a little hole in the wall which I can't stop going to.  Even now, when I don't live in the Lower Haight, I'll still ride my bike over here, grab a burrito and sit and watch the dogs play in Duboce Park.
   It should be said that I only get one thing here (since they do it so well I rarely change my order). A Carnitas (just a little crispy) burrito on a tomato tortilla, with cilantro, salsa, and enchilada sauce.  I'd been going to this spot for over 2 years with roughly the same handful of guys making my burrito, when they finally admitted to me that it was a good combination.  
  It's a small place and you order from two guys who are making everything right there in a little-ass window, but they crank out superb food day after day, and believe me it's totally worth it.  
  One thing to be mentioned is they raised their prices recently from $5 to $6 something for a burrito.  Now I know some of you don't like change and this was a great spot for a $5 burrito, but seriously, $6 ain't that much.  I'll spend more on a drink in most bars, and a shot is rarely filled with wonderful Carnita-ness (got that would be awful if it was).  For my money I'll be back again and again.
author: Nathan C.

description: Don't judge this place by going to their Mission sister taqueria. This location has sooo much more character than the one down in the mission. Not only is this my favorite burrito place in the city, the guys here know that I'm trying to learn Spanish so they take it really easy and slow on me on their native tongue and are helping me to get my whole Spanish food vocabulary down.   I love the burritos with no bean and rice with whole slices of avocado and one of the most kickin ass green salsas in town.
author: Mazi S.

description: This place used to be good. I used to love it. something happened. It's sooo inconsistent now. Seems like if you don't go during peak lunch/dinner times, you'll get a cold, flavorless burrito with old ingredients. The last few times I ate there I had this horrible taste in my mouth after that I had to somehow mask with gum/chocolate/whatever so I wouldn't throw up. 3 stars cuz they used to be good, and I'll probably go there again at some point but only during dinner times when the grills are hot and the ingredients are more fresh.
author: Dave R.

description: I absolutely love this place and everyone who works there is so much fun.  I always get the wet burrito and it's delicious. The guys themselves all think themselves comedians and making ordering a burrito quite interesting.  Their tacos are yummy too....they're extra hot salsa is not for the faint of hear but if your willing to take the ride it's superb. Burrito mojado, red sauce, grilled chicken, pinto beans, marijuana(as they like to call the cilantro...which threw me off at first) and pinto beans yummmmmmmmmm
author: Marie B.

description: ALL I can say is get the Carnitas. "Roast Pork". I have purchased one ever 2 weeks for 2 years. very good..
author: Charles P.

description: One of the best burritos in the city.  Grilled tortilla with fresh ingredients.  Try the super veggie burrito with black beans on a spinach tortilla, spicy salsa and everything on it.
author: Alex T.

description:
The food here is amazing.  Huge portions at a great price.  The location is very convenient for me.  I usually go after shopping at Safeway.

Everything is awesome from the wet burrito and the shrimp dinner playes.  The tortas are nice.  Their Quesadilla Suiza with Al Pastor is the best. 

The staff is really nice; they work quickly and always make you smile.  Watching them work is awesome, especially on those dinner plates.  Beware of the occassional cat screams!

They have raised their prices like most other places, so I have branched out a bit.  However, I still go frequently because I am willing to pay extra.  They are that good!
author: Matthew O.

description: This used to be my favorite tacqueria in SF, but with the new management prices have gone up and food is not as good as i remember it.  Still, when i have a wet-style burro craving, i come here.  My favorite is with carne asada and extra cilantro, or al pastor - chicken is also good.  carnitas can be fatty, but still tasteee.  Plus the cooks are on top of their game, faster than cancun or El Farolito.  They also have all-you-want salsa (very important) and now have a juicer - fresh squeeze orange/carrot/etc.
author: chad n.

description: Yum!  The al pastor and chicken are both very flavorful.  Even the rice has a good flavor to it!  The burritos have a good balance of ingredients and are really filling.  And those men behind the counter know how to wrap a burrito.  They never fall apart.  Very important!
author: Christina D.

description: I love their quesadilla's!  I've been coming here for years and this place is consistently awesome.  Great service and super salsa bar.  Their tomatillo salsa is the best.  Staff is excellent and organized.
author: Joni S.

description:
I really try to avoid this place..I do, otherwise I would eat it every day and end up like some of the people you see hanging around outside of El Castillito.  One day, successful young professional commuting downtown to the Financial District, the next...a broken-down homeless man, destitute and broke, having blown all savings on Super carne asada burritos, now reduced to begging for Castillito scraps and spare chips...the place is just that good.
I dig everything about this establishment.  The gentlemen you order from at the grill are hilarious, come here late night for an entertaining show.  When they're dishing up the finishing touches on your burrito they like to mix it up:
"Onions?...Guacamole?...Salsa?...Fresh mar-e-juana? (cilantro)..."
That's usually after one of the cooks performs his deadpan angry alley-cat hiss that always turns heads.
They grill all your meat right there in front of you so that your burrito is piping hot and the meat is juicy and delicious.  Their burrito construction is impeccable and quick and the ingredients are always evenly dispersed. 
A super carne asada burrito with tax runs $7.04, chips and fresh salsa from the salsa bar are on the house.
My only complaint is that they have a breakfast burrito and it has absolutely NO redeeming qualities.  It contains 3 things: tortilla, eggs and chorizo.  No cheese?  No NADA?! I was not pleased, because I love breakfast burritos...
The staff is very friendly and funny, I come here by myself and am always entertained while I eat by their banter with each other/customers/street vendors/homeless people.  
Castillito makes me wish I hadn't given up on Spanish class so I could join in on their conversations with customers and each other...if you don't want to make the trip to the Mission, or if you live in the triangle like me, come here and get your fix! Ask for extra mar-e-juana!
author: Josh T.

description:
yep. the best burrito place on church. no forget that.

BEST BURRITO PLACE IN SF. 

they are open late, sell beers and have really good burritos.

their veggie burritos are EFFING GOOD, the service is quick and theres usually a place to sit.
author: Ameigh F.

description: OMG, this places makes a fantastic super-burrito.  I'm wondering if "super" means "huge", cause that's what it is.  I thought that it meant that I was getting guacamole and sour cream, but I also think that they up the size.  So...the smart thing to do is to cut in half and eat two meals out of it.  Muy practicale.  I don't even know if that's a spanish word or not, but I thought that I would wing it.  One star off for making it huge so that people with no will-power will eat the whole things and feel uncomfortable.
author: Stacy M.

description: Best burrito I had in SF.  I've tried 3 or 4 of their meats and have always been pleased.  They have several tortilla options to choose from: wheat, sundried tomato, green, and regular.  Also, they have agua refresco (watermelon, cantaloupe, or horchata).  All worth trying (and I've tried them all).  Occasionally, the SF Weekly has a coupon for a free agua refresco with purchase of a burrito.  All of the staff is friendly.
author: David L.

description: oh my god you guys! this place makes delicious burritos.  I really like the different hot sauces that they make.  the green salsa is pretty much my favorite, i like it on almost every bite of my burrito.  its so delicious! I parked my new 72' Ranchero right outside and I was sitting at the counter just eating by burrito and looking at my shiny car and i was just thinking to myself like "this is so delicious".
author: Hector of Hector's Automotive X.

description:
After reading all the other reviews, I'm still wondering if I ate at the right place.  
My boyfriend confidently brought me to this place, noting it was a solid burrito joint when he lived in the city several years ago.
We knew we were in for trouble when they placed my wet burrito into the microwave to melt the cheese.  Call me picky, but I can reheat my own food at home for a lot less money.
The wet burrito was a total disappointment, in fact, calling it a soaking wet burrito would have been more appropriate.  This beast was dripping with sauce, salsa and mushy guacamole that dominated any other flavors.
While I thought the carne asada in my BF's all-meat burrito was infinitely tastier than the chicken I had, it still wasn't superb.  All their meat is pre-chopped and then reheated on the grill.  So much for freshness.  I did appreciate the way the tortilla was crisped up on his burrito, but that was the only thing that really stood out to me.
Overall, I would be hard pressed to go to El Castillito again, with the abundance of taquerias in the city I'm pretty sure I can get more bang for my buck somewhere else.
author: Stephanie C.

description: This place has gone up and down in quality in the years I've been going there, but in the last year or so seems to have gone up again. Every burrito should be a grilled burrito. I used to be addicted to the quesadilla el castillito. I still may be addicted to their mighty-spicy avocado salsa.
author: Heather R.

description: Have you ever heard of happiness? Well you havent truly felt the presence of god until youve tried their Super burritos! Since I am Asian, the idea of FREE anything intrigues me. On top of cleanliness due to the majority of Homosexuals around and their unlimited amount of salsa, which you can abuse freely without predjudice.  Cleanliness, good food, unlimited salsa, and the possibility of seeing very attractive girls(hopely not lesbian) frequently is the high point of this restaurant! 5 stars!
author: Jimmy K.

description: I have been going to this place for years and I still love it. The al pastor is a staple of mine whether it be in regular or super burritos or in the tasty tacos. The green salsa is off the hook and the chips are nice and light. Even had the tortas? Off the chizzaine homie. The quesadillas are great too. Work your spanish when you order and get some extras. They always give me avocado and don't charge me for it! On top of the great food they've got a jukebox with mad amounts of banda on it. Heaven on earth ese. The topper is the scene outside. The corner of Church and Market being one of the big crossroads of the city makes this area ideal for people wathching. Go to this place. You'll get a great taqueria experience...roaches and all that ; )
author: Steve H.

description: My favourite burrito place in town. Try the Super Vegie Burrito with spinach tortilla with avocado, you'll love it.
author: toto h.

description: This is my favorite burrito plave EVER! I love, love, love their green salsa! I brought a bunch of their burritos for a work crew at our house and no one could get enough of the green salsa!
author: Denise L.

description:
The first time I walked into this place I didn't want to eat.  It was a few years ago and little dingy.  But now I love my neighborhood taqueria. 

Everything I've ever ordered from there has been delicious.  From the veggie/chicken burritos, carne tacos, nachos, enchiladas and tomales.  

Anytime anyone comes to my place I always recommend this place for real good burrito.
author: Serena T.

description: Absolutely the best chicken tacos in San Francisco! Thank you not only for the deliciousness but for letting me practicar mi espanol tambien!
author: Josie C.

description:
BEST  BURRITOS!!
Get the super carnitas burrito.  If you like it spicy,say no to the regular salsa and yes to the "orange sauce".
Super. The best.  I'll never be able to eat another burrito.
author: Alulubeth O.

description:
My favorite SF burrito, particularly the veggie (the meat can be amazing or just pretty good depending on the day)...excellent ingredients (good flavors, textures, and proportions), good construction (the cheese is grilled onto the tortilla rather than steamed or thrown on), good salsas, and obscene portions.

I used to live near this location, but I worked near and thus also frequently ate at El Castillito in the Tenderloin near Civic Center...the Church Street location is, for whatever reason (the neighborhood perhaps?), an order of magnitude better...oh, and ask for fresh avocado rather than guacamole when you order a super.
author: M O.

description: My favorite San Francisco mexican restaurant.  Hands down the best steak queca's in the area. I'm also a big fan of the carnitas burrito with black beans and spicy salsa, and the best part of it all is a relatively inexpensive place for a full meal.
author: Marcelo B.

description:
talk about stuft burrito! this place is yummy, the ingrediants are always fresh and they will customize every order to your liking. the staff is fun and playful - they even put up with my horrible attempts to speak spanglish.
this is the best place to get a burrioto outside the mission.
author: Jenny B.

description: The food here is awesome!  I love the camerones rancheros.... and I don't do seafood lighty.  If the place looks even the slight bit sketchy, I'll go vegetarian.  The cooks are also super nice, and very accommadating.
author: Cynthia B.

description: My favorite taqueria in SF. I get the vegetarian quesadilla every time. It is actually more like a burrito, cut in half. They may call it what they wish.
author: Yes P.

description:
why do i love mexicans so much? because one star or 5, they are the chefs in america.  and they were generous enough to bring their tradition to us!  love this place, love the guys making my food, love that they have freshly squeezed oj, love the diner style stools, love that i can people watch, love that i'm not in line at safeway across the street.  no me deja!

oh, a side note; i saw the "other" place a few doors down has their meat delivered from the low cost meat market on haight, and i will never ever EVER go there.  ever.         ever.
(ever.)
author: regina k.

description: All the dishes they serve vary from good to amazing flavor grenades. I highly recommend the Tortas.
author: Alexander H.

description: Good prices, fresh ingredients, never a long wait and open late. Don't charge extra for avocado like El Torro or Pancho Villa.   I think that super veggie burrito is phenomenal!
author: Dmitriy S.

description: This is one of the top 3 burrito places in the entire city, slightly further from the mission area it is sometimes overlooked.  And because of its location and small lines it is not packed with yuppies eating somewhere because it is the "cool spot".  I conducted a survey with 100 friends and 90 out of 100 voted this place as number one.  Their food is great and there prices are perfect.  Their fruit frescas are among the best around, I suggest the strawberry, and get the large bucket sized cup.  This place offers total customization of your order, I suggest getting fresh avocados instead of guacamole and asking for sautéed onions, you can also do half black half pinto beans, so many options! GO HERE, its great.
author: Cornelious B.

description: I can basically only review their carnitas tacos cuz I can never convince myself to get anything but. I've had their burritos and they are good but the carnitas rocks - crispy, hot, yum. I like that their tacos are just meat, onions, cilantro and hot sauce. No cheese, sour cream and other stuff to get in the way. They are also cheap - nice. I use their carnitas as my benchmark, still looking for something that beats it. Salsa bar is very nice.
author: Natalie T.

description: I have been on the hunt for the bet burritto in the city, and I always have to come back the castle.  I just had there veggie special and a pepsi, and i don't think you can find a better deal for under 7 dollars.  Fresh ingredients, good cheese, and friendly service, oh yeah not to mention they have modelo especial in a bottle.  Damn tasty mexican beer if i do say so myself.
author: brian m.

description: Consistently tasty burritos and tortas in a no-frills environment (even compared to other taquerias!).  Although line can get long, it moves rather quickly.  Some table and counter seating available but not much.   Personally, I like the burritos "al pastor" which is spicy marinated pork.
author: Christopher K.

description:
This is definitely a spot to go to if you're nearby and trying to eat some burrito.
